PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Haines (from 83 citizens) and Jessop (from 195 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally:
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal System; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of Australians.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Television, Illawarra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That a Government decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, will place in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

Your petitioners request the Senate to protect the interests of the hundreds of thousands of television viewers within the area from Wollongong to the Victorian border served by WIN TV, by preventing the Government from taking this unwarranted and discriminatory action which disadvantages both viewers and advertisers on the South Coast to the benefit of the metropolitan networks.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that woodchipping and clearfelling will destroy the Otway Forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect the Otway Forests for the future and refuse any licence to export woodchips from the Otways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had hoped that the Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 would provide for a dynamic organisation, motivated to produce an efficient, sophisticated, economic approach to airport management and development without impediment. What we have is a limp piece of mumbo-jumbo designed to get the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) at arm's length from unpopular decisions, to give Senator Walsh another milking cow and, inevitably, to increase the costs through an even greater bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: There are so many areas that are totally incomplete that I really wonder how the Government got around to producing the Bill at this time. There are many questions to which the Minister for Aviation has not attended. The sorts of immediate issues that require attention are arrangements for the State and Federal governments and the issue of capital structure, which is not even determined at the time the legislation is before us but is to be determined afterwards.
The whole basis of the required payments by the authority is just so unwieldy and unreasonable. I refer to the authority of the members of the Corporation and so on.

The legislation creates yet another statutory authority designed to distance the Minister from direct responsibility so that the blame can accrue elsewhere as a result. The Government admits by this effort, that the dead hand of big government, is hamstringing efficiency and dynamism across the various sectors. The Government, by transferring the responsibility to an airports corporation, is just having two bob each way. What is the motivating force behind the new organisation? The government is inferring that commercialisation is the answer. There is no more commercial motivation in the Corporation as it is proposed than there is in the Public Service; in fact, if anything, there is less because of the hamstringing involved. There is certainly no profit motive or efficiency motive. What incentive is there for the Corporation even to try to balance its books?

The legislation and the Minister's tabling speech show that there will be hamstringing right from the start by the Corporation being forced to take on everyone in the existing organisation who wishes to join. There is no provision for anything else; this is stated clearly in the Minister's tabling speech. As a result, how do we get new top management? Will new staff be on different terms, conditions, pay, superannuation and so on, from existing staff? Where do we get this infusion of new blood? At least for the first two years there will be staff ceilings. The Corporation will not be able to retrench inefficient and unnecessary staff; it will have to wait for natural attrition before any changes can be made. How long are the Public Service conditions referred to to last? Whether they are appropriate to the new organisation or not; how long are they to last?

Of course, the worst problem with giving an organisation like the Airports Corporation the authority to proceed is that the Government has really given it nothing. It must follow the objectives set down by the Government, irrespective of whether those objectives are right or wrong. The Corporation has to do three years forward program planning. I do not mind that, except that it is as directed by the Government. These requirements, exercised at a strategic level, suggest fairly frequent interference from the Department. I believe it is unacceptable to form a corporation, say that it is important and then provide it with really no powers of any significance. That is quite unacceptable.

The question of capital structure is laid down to be discussed between the Ministers after the passage of the legislation. But it is very difficult for a corporation to feel very safe in the hands of various Ministers when, for instance, clause 44 (2) states:

Interest is not payable to the Commonwealth on the capital of the Corporation, but the capital of the Corporation is repayable to the Commonwealth at such times, and in such amounts, as the Minister determines.

Does this mean it may be $10m or $100m, or that after the end of the first year the Government may say that it has given the corporation capital of $1 billion but that it will take the first $1m back monthly and that the Corporation can raise the money wherever it likes to pay the Government back? There is nothing in the Bill to say that that is not the way it could be handled. I think it was referred to in the other chamber as being a hollow log. Is this to be one of those bodies to which governments have access whenever they are short of money; they can just demand a capital repayment so that it becomes another source of revenue? As far as the dividend is concerned, clause 46 (3) states:

The Minister shall, before the expiration of 30 days after the receipt by him or her of a recommendation made by the Corporation under sub-section (1) in relation to a financial year, give notice in writing to the Corporation-
(a) where the recommendation is that the Corporation pay a dividend to the Commonwealth for the financial year-
(i) approving the recommendation; or
(ii) directing the payment by the Corporation . . . of a dividend of a different specified amount.

So the Corporation, adopting whatever financial care that it may, may declare what is a reasonable dividend to keep the business operating but the Minister can override that at any stage by requiring an additional or alternative amount. What is the point in the Corporation's budgeting? What is the point in its declaring dividends if it does not have any say in how it is going to be administered? It is clearly to be a milking cow so that the Minister for Finance can have another source of revenue, one that has so far been unavailable to him.

The Government insists that the Federal Airports Corporation represents commercialisation. I do not know what commercialisation really means. It is not privatisation because there seems to be more government intervention now than previously, but the legislation is apparently designed to achieve the benefits the Government would see if the Corporation were commercial without in fact letting it become commercial. I doubt that those benefits are possible. I noticed a comment in Lloyds Bank Economic Report for January 1986 concerning this matter. In a paragraph on public or private ownership it said:

We believe it is not the ownership of an organisation which should be the focus of attention. The real question which needs to be answered is how efficiently managed is each Federal or State government-owned organisation?

In other words, what is required is for the efficiency and accountability standards of the best of the private sector to be introduced into the running of a large number of government-owned enterprises. If this was to take place then the issue of privatisation becomes an illusion; badly managed organisations and highly regulated ones are not necessarily improved because the ownership is altered.

We are looking here at an illusion. I cannot see anything in the legislation or in the Minister's speech that demonstrates at all that the situation will actually be improved. The Corporation is a phoney business enterprise. It has no profit motive; it has no chill breeze of competition; no staff whose performance and promotion is based on its economic growth and prosperity. Why are we going through this charade to change things and call this body a Corporation, except to get it at arms length from the Minister so that he does not have to bear the acrimony that goes with it when things turn out wrong? One of the ways to free it up-we would all, particularly on this side of the chamber, appreciate that-is to relieve the organisation of the problems that go with being saddled with the Public Service Board and the Department of Housing and Construction. This is an absolutely damning indictment of both organisations and their effect on the commercialisation, prosperity or economic capacity of any operation the Government has anything to do with. Let me make it blatantly pointed: The only way to succeed is to sever the connections with these two organisations, and this certainly requires considerable attention.

The Minister claims that the Corporation will be free of restrictive Public Service staffing conditions. But it will not be free of Public Service staffing conditions because it is left to take over the existing organisation on terms at least as favourable as those now existing. I do not know what is the intention. I do not see why it is necessary, in creating a corporation and giving it various authorities, to apply many of these restrictions. I am sure that this particular restriction relating to staff is a typical case. If the Corporation finds that it is necessary to engage additional staff to perform additional duties or to perform duties better it is prevented from doing so. If, on the other hand, it finds that it can operate better, more efficiently, more profit-ably and more economically it is still prevented from doing anything about that because of the riders in the legislation.

I would like now to come back to the Minister's tabling speech because it clearly raises more questions than it answers. I would like the Minister to be able to provide answers to the various questions that I now wish to raise. In the first paragraph of the Minister's speech he stated:
When the Government came to office in 1983 it had as part of its platform a policy for improved administration of major airports.

We believed that placing this responsibility with a largely independent statutory authority would offer significant advantages to the travelling public, taxpayers, the aviation industry and airport administrators. Subsequent analysis has clearly confirmed that view.

I would like to know what sort of an investigation was carried out. Was there a public inquiry? If so, what are the results of that inquiry and how are they measured? If the whole premise is based on that I believe we need to know how it was based.
In the next paragraph of the speech the Minister stated:
Departments of State are of necessity bound by the Government processes which inhibit commercial flexibility and responsiveness.

I wondered whether this was particularly applicable to the Department of Aviation, whether it was just another average case, or whether there were any specific areas that needed to be brought before the Parliament to demonstrate it. A little later, dealing with the same matter, the Minister stated:
Additionally, governments in the past have unduly influenced the priorities for aviation infrastructure development for reasons unrelated to economics or efficiency.

Will the legislation change in any way restrictions on operation and the necessity for the corporation to follow so strictly the instructions that are laid down? I cannot see that any major decision of any consequence can be taken by the Corporation that cannot be overridden by the Government or where the decisions that it takes do not have to fit in with government policy in one form or another.

I am not quite sure why it was necessary to mention the review of the Opposition's 1981 two-airline agreement which is under way or what effect that has on the legislation, but I did notice that the Minister found it necessary to include it. I wondered whether that had any bearing on the legislation and I would be obliged if the Minister could say where that fits into it. For a piece of hotshot jargon, the next paragraph would take some beating in any piece of legislation I have ever seen:

In framing the legislation the Government has had to face the task of balancing the need for autonomy and entrepreneurial management with the need for public accountability to maximise public benefit. This approach fits in with the Government's policy of public enterprise-efficiency, consumer responsiveness and successful management. I believe that we have achieved that balance.

Time alone will show what sort of balance we have achieved. I see nothing in this legislation that would go to support such a heap of claptrap as undoubtedly that passage is. I do not know who could have produced it. I feel sure that it would be difficult to blame the Minister for it, but I am sure that it brought a laugh to many people.

The next question I want to pose relates to the disclosure of results and for publication of indicators which year by year will show the performance of the Corporation across the range of its activities on an airport by airport basis. How will this change anything? What are the criteria on which these airports are to be judged? What is the performance on which they need to be dealt with? Is it possible to compare Adelaide and Perth and, if so, why? What is the need or advantage in doing things of this sort, if in fact they can be done? The next paragraph of the Minister's speech reads:
The Government has set objectives for the Corporation covering social, financial, management and efficiency aspects.

What is left for the Corporation to do? The Government has set social, financial, management and efficiency aspects, and yet this Corporation is said to have a need for autonomy and entrepreneurial management with the need for public accountability and all that sort of thing. Why do we try to pretend that we are producing what clearly is never the Government's intention in the first place? The Minister's speech continues:
The Corporation will be required to put forward to the Minister for Aviation-

and so on and so forth, but it is required to do all this within the constraints the Government itself has laid down before the Corporation starts. There is no doubt that this is nothing more or less than a cup of tea committee. Provided that the Corporation agrees with what the Government lays down, it will be allowed to continue. Later in that speech, the Minister says:

This legislation will provide a framework for the operation of airports more efficiently, more commercially and in a manner in which the Corporation's performance will be able to be judged by its owners, the people of Australia.

Again, I would be obliged if I could be told what that means. Then the speech goes on to say that there will be no net increase in staff and that the Corporation will offer positions to all staff whose functions are transferred. It continues:

While the Corporation will have power to set conditions of employment for its staff, it will also be required to provide, at the time of the transfer, offers of conditions of employment to transferring staff at least equivalent to those which they apparently enjoy in the Australian Public Service.

Does this mean that we are looking to form another organisation which will be seeking conditions better than those in the Public Service? Does it mean that we can ultimately recruit people for this service on conditions less than those that apply to the Public Service? Does it mean that matters such as superannuation and other benefits, maternity leave, time off and so on will be on two different levels? Does it mean that one group will come in with one level of employment conditions while another group will be at a different level?

TALK.START.PARA: —Knock it off.
—I will knock it off when I am finished. I want answers to these questions. The Minister says a little later:

SPEECH.PARA: I will be consulting with my colleague the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) before determining an initial capital structure for the Corporation.

Is that likely to be $1 billion, $5 billion, or $10 billion? What is the purpose of it, except that it is now the obvious intention of the Government to try to recover it by declaring that the capital shall be returned to the Government in such time and in such a way as the Minister for Finance will determine. I think we all know Senator Walsh well enough to know that he is a very generous soul and that he is probably not going to want it very quickly! He probably is not very worried about any potential loss in fuel revenues and things like that! So we are not likely to have any difficulty with him! However, the next Minister for Finance may not be so generous! The second reading speech states:

. . . the Government's requirements on a variety of issues . . . will not be subject to recovery. Included amongst these will be, for example, the payments of ex gratia payments to local government . . .

The arrangements with local and State governments are inadequate. The legislation does not provide adequately for them. I find it very difficult to determine the Government's intention. We come back to the commercial question. I am not sure how we go about determining where we fit in with the operation of the Corporation on a commercial enterprise basis. What about the cars, shops, bars, hotels, parking and those sorts of things? Who will determine that? The legislation is totally incomplete. Towards the end, the second reading speech states:
. . . the financial performance of airports will be measured and results made available to airport users.

So what? That is not what it is all about. The Corporation's aim should be to see that we get the best service possible in the best and safest way. Where is the autonomy that is supposed to be vested in this Corporation? It is certainly not in finance. It is certainly not in decision making. It is not in staffing. It is not in the objectives. It is not in the working conditions. Provided that the Corporation does whatever the Government lays down for it to do, it has autonomy. But I can see no other way in which autonomy arises at all.

I believe that the legislation falls far short of minimum standards. I would like the Minister to provide some information on the matters that I believe are important and unresolved. It is the Opposition's intention to vote against the legislation. Should that be unsuccessful, we will move that it go to a Senate committee so that the vast areas of incomplete detail can be dealt with and brought back to the Parliament so that we can deal with the legislation with more knowledge of what it is all about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that we have here another example of the Opposition opposing for the sake of opposition. Furthermore, it has not done any homework. Senator Archer has taken 25 minutes of this chamber's time showing that he has not done his homework. He has asked questions. He has gone through a speech and said: `What about this, what about that?' That material exists. If he had taken the time, as we have done, to go to the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and say `What about these points,' he would have the information he required. Instead, he sits over here with his colleagues and says: `Sure, we will oppose it. It is simply a Labor Party policy matter. We will oppose it automatically'. He has exposed himself and his Party as simply lazy.
—They are fighting amongst themselves all the time.

—I suppose that they cannot get a decent conversation that way. One certainly would not get an intelligent conversation that way. The point is that, if the honourable senator is to be in this chamber, he has to do some homework. He has to earn his pay. The people who elected him expect him to earn his pay and he has not done it in this instance.
—I would like to have your experience.
—I am sure the honour-able senator would.
—I ask Senator Sanders to speak to the Bill.

—I am sorry. We have here a Department of Aviation quango. The honourable senator referred to quangos as an evil thing and they are; but, unfortunately, they are a fact of modern day life. A quango is a quasi-autonomous government organisation. A standing rule with quangos is that a young quango is better than an old quango. A young quango is more efficient than an old quango. I think we get about five years efficiency out of a quango. When a quango is set up it is full of new people who are full of vigour and they are enthusiastic about their job. They will take off and do something to reform the system as they see it. They know what the deficiencies are because they have come from some stuffy old organisation. The Federal Airports Corporation will be a quango but it will be a young one. I think we will see some good things coming out of it for a little while. Hopefully, we will see some changes that will keep it on its toes. In the first five years of its development I think it will probably be a very worthwhile structure.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have with the present Department of Aviation? We have one of the most ossified bureaucracies in the country. If this bureaucracy is broken up in any way, shape or form into any other smaller, newer quangos that will be a very good thing. To the ossified bureaucracy of the Department of Aviation aeroplanes are a nuisance to the smooth flow of paper work. They interfere with the smooth operation of the bureaucracy. Speaking as a pilot, my impression of the DOA is that it would be quite happy if all aeroplanes were permanently in hangars with their doors welded shut. If that were the case it would not have to worry about people such as me in the aircraft industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is understandable.

—Perhaps it is. There are a number of areas of aviation which will have very little to do with the proposed Federal Airports Corporation and I will not go into them in any detail, but I would point out that the Department of Aviation is under attack as never before in areas such as its air traffic control procedures and its various procedures of consultation with the industry. It is the impression of the industry that the Department of Aviation is inflexible in dealing with aviation matters. I will give just a small example of how the Department of Aviation looks at pilots. An acquaintance of mine was lost in the air over Strahan, Tasmania. He got on the radio and said: `I am lost'. Of course the Department could not help him much. He went back to Strahan and landed. When the weather cleared he flew to Hobart. When he arrived there he received a radio message to ring the tower. He rang the tower and he was told that his licence had been cancelled because he had got lost. This is an example of the DOA's response to a person who was in an emergency situation. It cancelled his licence until he took another examination because he got lost. That is not the way in which an organisation that is truly interested in aviation should conduct its affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Aviation is inflexible, inefficient and completely unrealistic. I have heard from a manager of an airline at Tullamarine Airport about what would happen there in times of security difficulties. In other words, if there were a hijack attempt at Tullamarine, do honourable senators know who would be in charge of the operation? By DOA standards, the guys who drive up and down the runways in yellow cars to see that the runways are free of debris, would be in charge of all of the military or police personnel during a hijack attempt because it is their job to control the airport aprons. That shows how unrealistic the DOA's bureaucracy is. Anything the Federal Airports Corporation can do to rectify that situation is very needed indeed.

On the DOA, we find that there has been a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure on the Darling Harbour fiasco. that is the title of it. It is called `No Port in a Storm'. The Darling Harbour fiasco basically involved a heliport, a helicopter landing pad, in Sydney. This inquiry has been rightly called the Dick Smith inquiry, because Dick Smith, the pilot and former owner of Dick Smith Electronics, got this Committee to look into this matter. When the Committee let it be known that it was investigating the Department of Aviation, it got 800 submissions from all over the country, not just on Darling Harbour but 800 submissions on inefficiencies, inadequacies and downright stupidities of the Department of Aviation. So it goes on and on.

We find that Senator Archer, with all his questions, did not bother to read the second reading speech by Senator Grimes. I do not think that he did, because some of his questions, at least, would have been answered in it. Senator Archer said that there is to be absolutely no scrutiny of this Corporation by anybody. The second reading speech in relation to all of the Corporation's activities states:
. . . be subject to close scrutiny by aviation users and the aviation industry.

. . . this scrutiny will be enhanced through requirements in the legislation for consultation, disclosure of results and for the publication of indicators which year by year will show the performance of the Corporation across the range of its activities and on the airport by airport basis.
What could be better than that? It goes on to say:

Additionally, the Corporation will be required to put forward to the Minister for Aviation each year a three year forward program including its budget for the following year and details of its corporate plans.
I think the Government is taking a very brave step in the following, because it says:

To enable the Corporation to operate as autonomously as possible, it will be freed from the requirements of: Staffing under Public Service conditions; the requirement that it utilise the Department of Housing and Construction for its capital works-although it will be expected to provide the opportunity for that Department to compete for such work on a commercial basis.
The Government will also remove:
. . the need for its day to day land dealings to be administered through the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services.
In other words, it will be a very streamlined and efficient organisation, and I think that Senator Archer, if he had done his homework, would have to agree with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department will be the next to do that.

—The Minister interjects. One of the objectives-I welcome this-set by the Government is that the Corporation be a good neighbour to the communities it serves. This has been of very great importance to us. We have had representations by councils, by mayoral committees, to the effect that they wanted to make sure that their rights would be preserved. I believe that, with some amendments that I hereby foreshadow, this legislation will in fact protect the interests of all the users, the travelling public, those living in proximity to airports and the industry itself.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also very important that this new Corporation protect the rights of general aviation. General aviation is the poor relation of the aviation industry in Australia. Unfortunately, the airlines get all the publicity and most of the gravy. The DOA, being a large quango, sometimes listens to the airlines, but never listens to general aviation, and general aviation actually flies far more hours than the airlines do. I believe it will be up to us in the Senate and in the general aviation area to make sure that the cost recovery program does not put general aviation at any disadvantage. For instance, under noise abatement programs, it would be very unrealistic if general aviation were lumbered with any of the jet noise abatement costs. We will have to watch this very closely.

The Bill, I think, is timely; it is necessary. Opposition members have come up with a number of criticisms which really do not hold water. They have variously said that they want the airports to be privatised. We all know what this would mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—In the media release from Bruce Lloyd, shadow Minister for Aviation and National Party member for Murray, dated-he did not even bother to put the date on it.
—It is eternal.

—It is eternal. I guess the Opposition just rolls it out every time there is anything it wants to oppose. This would be one thing it wants to oppose. The media release states: `Federal Coalition to oppose Federal Airports Corporation Bill.' It goes on to say that it would like privatisation. It says that there are no efficiency performance standards. The release has a number of errors in it. It says in one area:

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the British Airports Authority there are no efficiency performance standards.
Actually, the performance standards are spelt out in the Bill, and so it goes. Opposition members simply have not done their homework on their media releases or on their speeches in this place.

The Bill is worthy of our support. It certainly has the support of the Australian Democrats. I think it will have the support of the people in the areas surrounding the airports. It will have the support of the industry and general aviation if-and this is the main requirement-in fact the Government, the industry and the Corporation all work together to further aviation in this country. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal objections which the Opposition has to this legislation can be categorised in two ways. The first is that it creates yet another unnecessary statutory authority and, as Senator Archer has said, the aim of that is simply to put at arm's length from the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) and from the Government the necessity to make some difficult and at times very controversial decisions about the administration of aviation in this country, about matters such as the location and operation of airports and the provision of facilities at airports. We believe that these are the types of responsibilities for which direct ministerial accountability ought to be retained.

SPEECH.PARA: I give as an example of the Government's failure in this sort of matter the prolonged failure of the Government to come to grips with, make a decision and make a public announcement on the location of Sydney's second airport. People at both Wilton and Badgery's Creek have been told time and time again that a decision is imminent; that it is about to be made. They were told once again just prior to Christmas of last year that a decision was about to be made, and that decision has yet again been shelved. This is an example of the way in which the present Minister for Aviation has treated his responsibilities in this area. The second general criticism I would make of this legislation is that what is claimed in the second reading speech, namely that this is in line with general international practice in the operation of airports, is entirely incorrect. I shall come back shortly to the question of the way in which administration of airport facilities in the United Kingdom and the United States of America has been handled in recent years.

This legislation indicates once again a failure by the Government to start to move on the more significant aspects of policies of reform and deregulation of airline operations and, in particular, the pricing structures and the access to the aviation sector, which ought to be substantially increased. No serious case has been presented for the haste of this legislation. This legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives yesterday. It is brought to the Senate within a matter of 24 hours of its passage in the House of Representatives. It is brought before us for debate with absolutely no statement being made as to why this is a matter of essential urgency. This Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 has been languishing around for some time. It has been brought on ahead of various other debates and yet there is no indication of why this is a particularly significant matter to be dealt with at this stage.

A number of references are made in the Minister's second reading speech to inquiries which have dealt with the question of the structure and form of aviation regulation in Australia. One of those which is mentioned is the Bosch Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, which reported in November 1984. If, however, one looks at the recommendations of the Bosch Inquiry, and in particular to the summary of those recommendations on page 17, one finds that what Bosch called the National Airports Authority should be given certain responsibilities, including being given `as much commercial freedom as possible in undertaking its operations'. I want to come back to that at a subsequent stage in my speech.

The interesting thing about the Bosch Inquiry was that it was never given the opportunity to discuss the whole question of whether the establishment of the National Airports Authority now provided for in the Federal Airports Corporation Bill was a good step. It is certainly true that the Australian Labor Party indicated in its last election policy that it would move to the creation of such a statutory authority, but I believe there has been no argument as to the particularity of the merits of having such an organisation as distinct from the continued operation within the Department of Aviation. Similarly, in terms of talking about the response of the Department of Aviation to a number of matters which have been raised, Senator Sanders, for instance, touched upon the House of Representatives inquiry. If one looks at Dick Smith's own publication entitled Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom one will find that there are a very large number of publications which the Department of Aviation has simply failed to respond to and failed to answer. Not just public criticisms by those who like to get stuck into departments, but public criticisms made by people who are knowledgeable and experienced in the aviation industry have not been answered.

I suspect that one of the functions that the Federal Airports Corporation will come to assume is the Minister's ability to say, whenever a lot of these problems are raised: `Oh, that is not my responsibility any longer, you have to take that up with the Corporation. The Corporation will have to give you answers as far as that is concerned. Of course, I cannot direct the Corporation or require the Corporation to do very much to be of assistance to you.'

The most serious charge that I think can be made is that the Bill and the second reading speech fail to indicate in any substantial way that are to be the efficiency performance standards required of the Corporation. I want to come first to the question of the raising of revenue. On page 8 of the Minister's second reading speech it says:

If, however, the Corporation engages in activities in competition with private enterprise it will be required to do so through a subsidiary and thereby in respect of those activities be liable to taxation.

As I say, that relates to the comment which I read earlier from the Bosch Inquiry. Nevertheless, we do not know the extent to which the subsidiaries of the Federal Airports Corporation are in fact going to be allowed to operate with some inbuilt government-backed advantage against the interests of private competitors. This brings us, for example, to the way in which the Government deals with matters arising under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act 1959. For some time I have pursued inquiries with the Minister on the question of the operation of the Airports (Business Concessions) Act. On 15 May 1985 I put down a question to the Minister dealing with this matter. The reply to these questions was printed in Tuesday's Senate Hansard. It has taken from 15 May 1985 to 11 February 1986 to provide a particular answer. I asked, in terms of the way in which the Government has fiddled operations under the Airport (Business Concessions) Act, this question:
How many contracts awarded specifically under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act have been renegotiated after their original awarding?

One would have thought that where contracts were entered into and subsequently renegotiated-these are competitive contracts in which bids are put in, a tenderer is selected and a contract is let-the Government would have maintained a fairly close eye on the renegotiation of those contracts. The answer from the Minister is as follows:

Contracting parties commonly alter the basis of their relationship if agreement can be reached. From time to time my Department has re-negotiated provisions of contracts awarded under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act. Variations are only agreed to by the Department of Aviation where they are deemed to be in the best interests of the Commonwealth.

Some of the areas in which variations to contracts have been made include the financial consideration payable, extent of goods and services offered, hours of operation, extent of leasehold improvements to be effected, pricing of goods and services and extension to the duration of contract itself.
There is no record kept of the number of contracts re-negotiated.

A government authority tells us that it lets and varies contracts but does not bother to keep a record of how many contracts it renegotiates. That is scandalous. If that were to occur in relationships in the private sector, if somebody were to allow contracts to be renegotiated and kept no records of those renegotiated contracts, people would claim that that was absolutely untenable and improper. Nevertheless, the Department of Aviation thinks that that is a perfectly valid way to conduct its business. The legislation says that the Federal Airports Corporation will be able to set up subsidiary companies to undertake business. We do not know whether it will be able to do so at some commercial advantage, backed by the Government, and whether it will be able to enter into and renegotiate contracts, and, presumably with the same sort of sloppy attitude currently held by the Department of Aviation when it cannot even tell the Parliament what contracts have been renegotiated, tell the Parliament that it does not even bother keeping records of how many contracts have been renegotiated.

If, as Senator Archer says, an attempt is to be made to use the Federal Airports Corporation as a revenue raising instrument rather than as an instrument designed to improve the efficiency of airline operations, the Government ought to be able to address and answer those sorts of problems. The next matter put forward in the second reading speech is:
We-the Government-believed that placing this responsibility with a largely independent statutory authority-
I note the qualification `largely independent'-
would offer significant advantages to the travelling public, taxpayers, the aviation industry, airport administrators.

Within anything put out by the Minister no attempt has been made to demonstrate at any stage where the advantage to the travelling public, taxpayers, the aviation industry or airport administrators would accrue. One thing which reinforces our belief that this Bill is simply an attempt to get the Minister out from the hot seat is admitted in the Minister's second reading speech. He said:

Additionally, Government in the past have unduly influenced the priorities for aviation infrastructure development for reasons unrelated to economics or efficiency. Indeed many of the decisions taken in the past have inhibited economy and efficiency in the industry. This legislation will go a long way towards rectifying these problems and will enable the Corporation to act more readily to meet the changing needs of the travelling public and the aviation industry.

Are we supposed to believe that the Corporation will be in a position where the Minister can influence its decisions without taking the responsibility for influencing its decisions? Looking at clause 9 sub-clause (3), clause 10 sub-clause (1), clause 11 sub-clause (1), clauses 23, 27 and 34 and clause 35 we see a list of ministerial powers of direction. Let us consider in particular clauses 39 and 40. Clause 39 (1) states:
The Corporation, when setting its financial targets to be included in a financial plan . . . shall consider the following matters:
(a) objectives and policies of the Commonwealth Government known to the Corporation and any directions of the Minister.
Clause 40 (1) states:

Without limiting the generality of the Minister's powers under sub-section 41 (2), the Minister may direct the Corporation to vary financial targets of, and performance indicators adopted by, the Corporation.

In other words, the Minister has the power to require the Corporation to fiddle the books in order to change the targets and the performance indicators to meet whatever specification the Minister happens to direct so that the results come out the way that the Minister wants. In the meantime, in setting those targets in the first place, the Corporation will have regard to the objectives of the Government which they know about-presumably that implies that there are objectives of the Government that they do not know about-or any directions of the Minister.

Undoubtedly, when my colleague Senator Kilgariff participates in this debate he will have something to say about the sorts of decisions that were made about the Darwin Airport and my colleague Senator Watson will talk about aviation decisions-airport location decisions-made in Tasmania. The important thing is the implication that airport administration and airports exist solely for economic or efficiency purposes. One thing of critical importance in this country is the social value and the important sociological decisions made about the location of transport and transport centres. It is absolutely clear that the development of Australia as a nation has been largely predicated on a number of decisions made about the location of transport facilities, which were not justifiable on the grounds of economics or efficiency alone, but were justified on the grounds of national development and their social worth to particular communities in a country with as many difficulties and as much isolation of communities as we have.

The admission by the Minister simply reinforces my fear that this legislation is an attempt to avoid the proper political responsibilities and decisions which governments ought to make by putting them into the hands of a corporation and saying `Of course, the Corporation will make these decisions' when in other areas of potential embarrassment to the Government the Minister will retain a power of direction and the Corporation will have to act in line with the Minister's directives. The Minister claimed in his second reading speech that this was being undertaken in line with international practice. I do not believe that to be true.

I indicate to the Senate that a close study, for example, of the operation of airport authorities in Great Britain reveals that this is not the case. In a publication by Carsberg and Lumby entitled Privatising British Airports Authority-policies, prospects, procedures there is a lengthy discussion of the British Government's successful attempts to move the administration and control of British airports out of the hands of the British Airports Authority. I say quite clearly that I do not subscribe to all the fanciful claims about deregulation of the airline industry as they touch upon key areas of safety. I do not believe that there is any justification for them. Some recent experiences of aviation policies in the United States I believe are quite negative and need to be very closely examined. The actual administration of airport facilities is a different matter. The British Airport Authority is responsible, or was responsible, for the administration of Heathrow Airport, Gatwick Airport, Stansted Airport, Glasgow Airport, Edinburgh Airport, Prestwick Airport and the two airports at Aberdeen, the fixed-wing airport and the helicopter airport. The operations of the British Airport Authority have been moved progressively from the Airports Authority into the hands of private sector operators. The Minister formerly responsible for airline and airport matters in the British Government, Mr Iain Sproat, indicated:

Our job as regulators and legislators is not to run an industry, nor to show how it should be run. Our job is to create the right climate for expansion and provide as many opportunities as we can for industry to flourish.

The Government set the general objectives for the private operators-safety, security, capacity, efficiency and respect for the environment. The whole trend in both Britain and the United States of America has been for the administrative control of airports to pass out of the hands of governmental authorities and into the hands of private sector operators. Therefore, the Government is simply incorrect in claiming that what it is doing is in line with the general thrust of international practice. The report of the Civil Aviation Authority released in London in May 1984 entitled `Deregulation of air transport: A paper regarding the experience in the United States' and prepared by the economic regulation group of the Airline Economics Branch of the Civil Aviation Authority, is indicative of the overseas trends.

I turn very briefly to the comments made by Senator Sanders. Senator Sanders said that basically he believed that quangos are all right, provided they are young quangos. Of course, the well-known dictum of Galbraith about the life cycle of regulatory bodies will undoubtedly apply to this body. It will not take very long for the Federal Airports Corporation to become simply an arm and an integral part of the industry that it is supposed to regulate or supervise.

I want to nail Senator Sanders on a couple of matters, quite simply because I believe honourable senators on this side are getting a little fed up with the tedious misrepresentation that Senator Sanders seems to have as his stock-in-trade. Do honourable senators remember the famous Press release on which he could not find the date? He could not find the date on it because he could not turn over a page. That was the real difficulty-the sort of physical and intellectual difficulty he had in turning over a page in order to find the date on the thing.

The second point is that the Press release was supposed to be a statement-Senator Archer challenged him on this-in which, Senator Sanders claimed, the Opposition stated that it wanted to privatise this operation. I will read the Press statement. It is headed `Federal Coalition to oppose Federal Airports Corporation Bill' and states:

The Coalition Opposition Parties will oppose the Federal Government Bill to establish a statutory corporation to take over the management of seventeen of Australia's major airports from the Department of Aviation.

The Coalition Parties believe that another ``Quango'' or statutory authority, subject to excessive Ministerial direction, is not the best way to achieve greater efficiency, and public accountability of aerodromes such as Mascot or Tullamarine.

Airline industry representatives question the degree of autonomy the Corporation will be allowed. Its ability therefore, to operate the aerodromes on a stable commercial basis is in doubt. The Minister can alter the financial base of the authority, require government policy directives to be followed without compensation, and interfere with airport charges.
There is concern that airport charges may have to be significantly increased to cover these Government directions, and this could lead to more expensive air travel.

Unlike the British Airports Authority there are no efficiency performance standards. There is no requirement for ``common user'' terminals for a more deregulated domestic airline system, and there are no satisfactory provisions in relation to local government authorities adjacent to airports.

The Opposition believes that there are too many statutory authorities, and that the better way to efficiently manage our major airports is to establish individual boards of management. This would create a body that is separately accountable and would allow more independent management decisions.

That is dated 27 November 1985. Madam Acting Deputy President, you were paying very close attention to that as I was reading it and you undoubtedly would have noticed that the word `privatisation', or indeed any similar attempt to use the word `privatisation' or anything like it, does not occur in that Press statement. Yet we hear Senator Sanders braying away. But we expect that. Senator Sanders, in a most interesting article which he wrote for the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 January 1986 about the operation of the Senate, said that he believed that the Senate `would take its role seriously'. In the article he states:

I might as well have stayed in Hobart. The Senate joyfully wallows in trivia like a hog in mud. Debate takes the form of personal vilification, and interjections have all the intellectual qualities of braying donkeys, thus completing the farmyard atmosphere.

He has already given proof to his own words. With his personal vilification of Senator Archer and with his braying interjections, I suppose he at least has made some attempt to give substance to his claims. This is a wonderful article. You should read it, Madam Acting Deputy President. There is the story of how interested the Press was when his motorcycle was run over by a backing Pajero and everybody came out to photograph it and how significant it was. But, of course, he had nothing to do with it. This just happened to have taken place outside the window of my room. I well recall watching Senator Sanders, the crumpled motor-bike and the photographer. Senator Sanders was astride that motor-bike in more different positions than in the illustrated Kama Sutra. More positions were given to that motor-bike than one finds in an Australian Democrats' policy statement.

I appear to be straying from the purposes of this legislation. I simply want to say that, in terms of Senator Sanders's contribution to the debate, his deliberate attempt to misrepresent what the Opposition has said about the Bill can be effectively demonstrated simply by a study of Mr Lloyd's Press release on the matter.

I believe there are many opportunities for building on the developing success in financial and other aspects of the aviation industry in Australia. The September 1985 publication of the Department of Aviation entitled `Outlook for the Aviation Industry: An Information Paper' shows the growth which has taken place in airport operations. With the exception of the airports of Brisbane and Hobart, one sees that the relative balance between various commercial operations which are run at the airports does in fact give the opportunity for airports to be run on a fairly efficient and indeed commercially viable basis. But it is the belief of the Opposition that that will not be achieved within the structure proposed within the Federal Airports Corporation Bill.

I conclude my remarks by saying once again that we are opposed to the creation of this new quango. We believe that it is an attempt to get the Minister out from under the necessity to make difficult and politically hazardous decisions from time to time. We do not believe that there has been any demonstration of the benefit that will flow to the airline industry or the travelling public, or indeed to revenue, by the establishment of this Corporation. We believe that there are significant unanswered questions, particularly about the financial undertakings of the corporation through its subsidiary companies. We do not believe that it is necessary for this legislation to be rushed through in the way proposed. We believe Senator Archer's proposal for some further investigation is warranted. For those reasons the Opposition will vote against the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 but not at the length that some of the former speakers have done. I will avoid that by not quoting great slabs of the second reading speech which both speakers from the Opposition seemed to think was fairly important. Like Senator Sanders, I have read the second reading speech and I know what is in it. I assume that other senators also know what is in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill has been clearly outlined in that second reading speech and I just want to mention a couple of features which are relevant to the remarks I wish to make. Firstly, the Corporation's establishment will for the first time place Australian airports on a commercial basis. This is a step in the right direction and one which has been a concern of Estimates committees over the years. This concern is satisfied by the Federal Airports Corporation Bill. Associated with that is the fact that there will be a proper disclosure to the Minister for Aviation and the Parliament of the operating and financial performance of the Corporation. That is the sort of thing that we in the Senate have always asked for-that quangos, as they are called, must respond to and report to Parliament, through the Minister.

The second point, which seems to be overlooked by members on the other side, is that the Corporation will be financially self-supporting and will operate with a great degree of flexibility and responsiveness. I notice that the latter was mentioned by one of the Opposition speakers, but in a critical sense of not wanting to have in it the sort of people who would perhaps enable the Corporation to act with a greater degree of flexibility and responsiveness.

We ought to note that the Government's decision, as usual in these matters, has followed a study by a departmental task force over a period of some 18 months. It is not something that has been rushed forward. The Bill may have come into this place a little earlier than we had anticipated, but the proposition has been in front of us and has been discussed and debated for some time. I make the point again that, as usual with the Government, an extensive consultation process has been conducted throughout the Federal Airports Corporation study.

We know, by reading the material given to us as background to the Bill, that several formal consultative arrangements were established to make sure that there was appropriate and proper consultation. We know that discussions were held with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the unions and the staff associations so that they could talk about the transfer to the Corporation-a most necessary step to make sure that the Bill is acceptable to the people who are most involved in the first instance; that is, the people who are working in the Department of Aviation at the moment and who may be working in the FAC if this Bill is successful. Most importantly, although this was rejected by one speaker on the other side, there have been discussions with the aviation industry and general community interest has been expressed through the Aviation Industry Advisory Council, the National Airports Consultative Council and the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council. I make the point that the Minister for Aviation has made in the other place, that the views expressed throughout these consultations have been most helpful to the Government in its deliberations on the matter.

My concern in this matter, as in all other matters, is how the plan affects the Northern Territory. I notice that the State capitals plus one or two other cities are included in the initial stages of the Bill; in other words, Darwin is not included. There are two reasons for this. One is perhaps that it is a Territory capital rather than a State capital, and the other more important one is that the facility is shared between the RAAF and the civilian DOA. The RAAF move to Tindal will surely reduce some of the pressure on the Darwin Airport and when the total airport situation is looked at in three years, as is promised in the Minister's speech, some decision will be able to be made about whether Darwin ought to be included. I would think that at the time, depending on the decision made by the RAAF on what parts of the Darwin Airport it would like to retain, there will be the possibility that Darwin be included in the airports under the control of the Corporation.

I make the point, then, that Darwin is the responsibility of the Federal Department for at least the next three years, as of course are Alice Springs, Tennant Creek, Katherine, Gove and Groote, although Tennant Creek has taken a most important step. We will all be aware of the aerodrome local ownership plan and I know that the Tennant Creek town council has been looking very closely at accepting responsibility for the Tennant Creek airport. It has entered into negotiations with the Department of Aviation to take over and control the airport. I commend it for that and I do hope that the Department will take on board the fact that the people of Tennant Creek are getting a little restive. The Department has yet to finalise certain investigations and make certain decisions, and I call on it now to see whether it can resolve the difficulties which appear to be facing it and get the ownership of Tennant Creek airport transferred as quickly as possible under the local ownership plan to the Tennant Creek council. I know that Alice Springs and Katherine will be looking carefully at developments. They will be looking at the experiment of Tennant Creek to see whether they might again consider the possibility of taking over their own airports. They have looked at it in the past but up until this stage have rejected it. I am sure that is because they are not certain how it will operate. So the Tennant Creek project will be an experiment at which the other two major towns will be looking.

As I have indicated, the Darwin Airport is not included in the plan but I must take this opportunity to mention a couple of factors about the Darwin Airport that I have perhaps spoken about before. I trust that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, will not call me to order on this. I feel fairly confident because if Senator Puplick can get away with discussions on the Kama Sutra I should at least be able to get away with the Darwin Airport, which at least mentions the word `airport'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not as interesting as the Kama Sutra.
—That may well be but my interest is much more in the Darwin Airport at this point of time.
—You are getting old.

—Not that old; may-be less athletic. I refer honourable senators to speeches which I have made in this place and which my colleague Senator Kilgariff has also made, and will make again today, since 1976. It is no secret that the Darwin Airport needs upgrading. The airport itself is basically the same as the building I first went into in 1949. There have been superficial changes and it looks quite different but basically it is the same old building. I will not comment on which government has been in power for most of the 37 years since 1949 but I note that it was not a Labor government, and it seems to me that it is a Labor government that is trying to do something at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Two aspects of the Darwin Airport need to be looked at-the runways and the terminal building itself. I will not dwell on the runways because they are quite clearly a matter for the engineering people but I am assured that investigations have been held and cost assessments have been made of the upgrading of the runways to the required standard. I know that the Minister himself is looking at the matter and I understand that he is going to go again to the Territory within the next few months once again to look at the airport and terminal and see what can be done. We all know the problem that the Minister faces; that is, the problem of financial constraints. The Government has undertaken a policy of fiscal responsibility and quite clearly we in Darwin cannot get the building that the people of the Territory had hoped for. We had hoped for something along the lines of the Townsville or Brisbane airports or some of those that have gone to our neighbours to the east. The Minister is aware of the problem, as I have indicated before. He has studied it and he has had his Department prepare for him several proposals that he is considering. I am confident that in the near future he will come up with a plan for the Darwin Airport. My confidence is reinforced by an extract from a letter which the Minister wrote to one of my colleagues. He said;

The Government is aware of conditions in the existing passenger terminal and is committed to the provision of improved passenger facilities at Darwin Airport. My Department has now substantially completed a study of options for development to determine which most adequately meets the needs of Darwin Airport at minimum cost to the travelling public. Hence, the Government will soon be in a position to make a decision on future development at Darwin Airport.

I make the point again with no apology that the Darwin Airport is extremely important to all of us in the Northern Territory. Tourism is vital to the Territory. Our economy there is becoming more and more dependent on tourism and, while one might criticise this development, it is a statement of fact and I do not intend to criticise it at this stage. The decision has been made by the Northern Territory Government, and that is the government elected to make this decision. If we are to have tourism as one of our major industries, we must have an appropriate terminal. I am heartened by the use of the same words in the Minister's letter-`an appropriate terminal'. We are the gateway to Asia. This has been said in this place many times and it is becoming more and more so. Quite clearly we must have a terminal, particularly an international terminal at the Darwin Airport which will not give the wrong impression to overseas visitors. Those of us who have been to Darwin in the last few years will know that overseas visitors coming in would wonder what sort of country they have come to when they are herded into the international section of the airport at Darwin.

I would like to move again slightly outside the actual Bill to mention the Gove control tower. It is related to the whole development of the system in the Northern Territory. There has been some criticism of the Government because the recently completed Gove control tower has not been put into operation. It has not been commissioned and people have not been appointed there. I remind honourable senators that the decision to build the tower was taken in 1982-prior to the election of the present Labor Government. I simply say that the Labor Government continued with the plans laid down by its predecessors. Let me say in all fairness to those who recommended this decision in 1982 that it was based on the anticipated traffic which would flow through in the next few years.

The decision not to open the tower at this time has been taken for three reasons. Firstly, the airlines have notified a reduced anticipated level of movement by their companies through Gove. They have indicated that, where they had asked for a certain number, they are now happy with a reduced number. Secondly, I am assured by the manager for South Australia and the Northern Territory and by the people working at the Gove Airport, with whom I have had discussions, that the present requests by the airlines can be handled by the current procedures. We do not need the tower operating to handle the sort of traffic that wants to pass through Gove at the present time. Let me make the point that, when we have tight fiscal control, we certainly do not want to appoint a lot of people to Gove Airport if they are not required simply to keep up some sort of image for the people who are asking: `Why is it not being used?'. The third reason why the tower has not been opened is that there are improved meteorological services available with the new station which was opened last month by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones). So with the amount of extra meteorological material it is felt that the Gove Airport tower need not open.

But let me make the point which the Minister made at the time, that is, that the opening of the tower will be looked at once again when the airlines indicate a need for an increase. When the airlines come to the Department and say `We anticipate that there will be a greater flow of through traffic', in the near future then it will be looked at again. At that stage there will be discussions not only with the companies concerned but also with the people in general aviation. I am obliged to Senator Sanders for raising the fact that the general aviation group, particularly in the Northern Territory, is a significant body. The majority of movement of people operating out of an area as isolated as Gove Airport quite clearly is general aviation. We must look to the general aviation people, particularly those who are flying their own planes out of their stations and from the missions, to get an indication of whether they want the tower opened.

Finally, I would like to mention what has become known as the Dick Smith inquiry. I do not share Senator Sanders's view that the Department of Aviation is ossified. I believe that there are many dedicated officers within the Department and many are attempting to implement what up until now have been fairly stringent and sometimes complex rules. I remind Senator Sanders that, in the last few days, there has been a change of permanent head. No doubt, as always happens with the change of a permanent head, the new broom will make some changes which will perhaps reduce what Senator Sanders sees as the ossification of the service. The emphasis of the Department has always been on safety. I am not a pilot as some honourable senators are; I am just an ordinary member of the travelling public. While the emphasis is on safety I am quite happy about that. I am quite happy to put up with some inconvenience if I can go on board the aircraft and have reasonable confidence that I am going to get off at the other end.

I remind those honourable senators who need reminding that the record of safety within Australia is commendable and one of which we need not be ashamed. I make the point also that, if problems are identified by the inquiry, I have no doubt that the recommendations which will come out of the report will be closely looked at by the Minister and by the relevant Caucus committee and recommendations will be made by the Minister for changes which will improve the quality of the service provided by DOA if this is necessary.

I am particularly pleased to see the response from people all round Australia to this inquiry. I understand that over 4,000 submissions have been received. I know that quite a large number have come from the Northern Territory. I have read those and I am pleased to see that, while there is some criticism of the Department, there are a few bouquets as well as brickbats. I look forward to the public hearings which will arise out of the inquiry. After attending some of them I will look forward to reading the report. I commend the Bill to the Senate and I invite honourable senators to support what I regard as a most worthwhile piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 which is before the Senate today seeks to establish yet another statutory authority. As has been said before, this statutory authority will manage 17 of the major airports in Australia. It is noted that they are the capital city airports of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Canberra. It is to be noted that Darwin is not included. Perhaps there is some reason for that but I will go into it later. There are the others at Launceston and Coolangatta and the general aviation airports at Bankstown, Essendon, Hoxton Park, Camden, Moorabbin, Archerfield, Jandakot, Cambridge and Parafield. There are other aerodromes in Australia which have a very considerable air movement, such as the one at Alice Springs where it is extremely high. One wonders too why Alice Springs, like Darwin, has been left out.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not believe that the creation of yet another statutory authority will necessarily be beneficial to the aviation industry. It does not believe that the proposed Corporation will allow the level of freedom for the industry which was envisaged by the report of the Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery. Indeed, significant recommendations contained in the Bosch report appear to have been disregarded. The need for a thorough investigation of the entire aviation industry has been highlighted recently by Dick Smith in his publication Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom. People may agree with what Dick Smith has had to say or perhaps they do not, but the fact is that he recounts numerous examples of bureaucratic fetters on the industry. Dick Smith claims that the fetters that he has outlined do not impair Australia's air safety standard of which all Australians can be justly proud. Nevertheless, I think the point has been made. An inquiry is taking place and one would hope that something of importance and something concrete will come out of it.

The Bosch report has said much regarding cost recovery. Indeed, cost recovery on aero- dromes in the aviation industry throughout Australia is now very considerable. The cost recovery that has taken place eventually comes back to the air traveller. It is the air traveller who pays in the long run for the cost recovery. I believe it is reasonable, while this is taking place, for the matter of the administration of the Department of Aviation also to be looked at to see whether it too can be made more efficient because surely what is good for the goose is good for the gander. While there is undoubtedly a need to review the management of some airports to free them of departmental restrictions, it is the Opposition's view that the legislation requires further consideration. Referring the legislation to a Senate committee may be of some assistance in dealing with more contentious sections of the Bill. I think it would also enable people from outside the Parliament to put their viewpoint.

While the Opposition is opposed to the Bill for the reasons I have outlined I must express my personal reservations concerning the Federal Government's management of the two major airports in the Northern Territory at Alice Springs and Darwin. Senator Robertson, who spoke before me, mentioned this matter but, of course, there are various sides to it. In the three years since the Australian Labor Party has been in government these two airports have been left to stagnate. It is quite correct to say that, as far as Darwin is concerned, that matter was investigated many years ago. The Public Works Committee considered the matter and made recommendations, which I will refer to later, but still nothing has happened. I think it is fair to say that the Federal Government has shown little interest in proceeding with upgrading the airports in spite of the clear and urgent need for improved facilities at both terminals. The saga of the redevelopment of Darwin Airport goes on while we await the outcome of the reappraisal of the project. Criticism of the reappraisal is that it is taking so long when initially it was the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) himself who said that the reappraisal would take some six months. In fact, one wonders why a reappraisal was considered necessary in the first place. I believe that is difficult to fathom.

Anyone who has ever passed through Darwin Airport terminal will be aware of the appalling state of the facilities there. The terminal is, as Senator Robertson said, an old World War II hangar, with no air-conditioning, totally inadequate baggage collection facilities and equally inadequate customs facilities. This results in lengthy delays to those returning from overseas. It is a most incredible place. The roof of this old hangar still shows the scars of its having been bombed and shot up in World War II. Businessmen coming from overseas from Singapore and arriving at Darwin must wonder what is happening when they see such dreadful conditions. What a poor welcome to these visitors who are so essential to our tourist industry. The Public Works Committee had no doubts about the need for redevelopment of Darwin Airport. It concluded:
(a) Facilities at Darwin Airport for international passengers and aircraft are grossly inefficient and measures designed to rectify the situation should be implemented.
(b) The staged northern development option for the development of facilities at Darwin International Airport has operational and cost advantages over other options examined and is supported.

(c) The Committee is satisfied that the factors which contributed to the design of the proposed new terminal and associated aprons and taxiways at Darwin International Airport were rigorously examined by Commonwealth Departments and reflect realistic forecasts and spatial requirements.

The Public Works Committee-a joint parliamentary body-went on to make other recommendations relating to the upgrading, but it is clear from the three statements I have listed that the Committee recognised the need for the upgrading and found the proposals to be realistic. Yet despite all this, the Federal Government took the decision to abandon the improvements which were well under way by early last year. Perhaps it flowed from the cost of the project. Nevertheless, that decision was taken, despite the fact that the Federal Government had already spent some $12m to $15m on the project.

In pulling out in this way the Federal Government caused considerable disruption to the industries and businesses in the Territory which had been involved in the redevelopment and had geared their operations to take account of the redevelopment project. Indeed, some operators wrote to me expressing their concern at the cancellation of the project, because they had refused other offers of work on other projects on the basis of their commitment to the airport project-only to find that, out of the blue, their contracts had been cancelled at, I understand, some considerable loss. So far as I am aware, Darwin is the only capital city where the airport has not recently undergone or is not presently undergoing some form of major redevelopment. That may not be entirely accurate because I note that Canberra, too, has some problems. But I am not aware of any other redevelopment project which has been ditched in the same way as has the Darwin Airport project.

Many statements have been made about the Darwin Airport, and I do not believe that the situation at the airport can wait another three years for us to see what will happen. It is true-and perhaps this is the reason why it has not been included as one of those capital city airports coming under the proposed Federal Airports Corporation-that perhaps one reason, which has been stated, for the present state of affairs is that Darwin Airport is a defence airport.
