The land comprising the airport, which is very extensive when one considers the presence of defence aircraft, commercial aircraft and the general aviation section, covers a vast area, but it is all owned by the Department of Defence. It seems to me that there is a simple answer. I am sure that everyone agrees that the commercial operation of aviation in the northern area will remain at Darwin Airport and that Tindal at Katherine when work is completed will take some of the aircraft. The Mirage squadron from Butterworth is there now and when replaced by the FA18 aircraft will have its permanent home at Tindal. Therefore, quite a lot of these activities will be transferred-not all but a good deal of Royal Australian Air Force activity will go from Darwin to the Tindal air base, a very commendable project.

At the same time there will still be a defence area within Darwin Airport, there will be a transport area which will involve many aircraft that come through Darwin from overseas, and there will always be a RAAF presence in Darwin. It seems to me that if the Authority intends Darwin Airport to remain the property of the Department of Defence-and I do not have much quarrel with that-I suggest that in order to remedy the situation and to overcome the problem an area should be excised out of the defence area for the commercial operation of Darwin Airport. I believe that this would be a very sane way of curing the problem and getting on with the job.

Darwin is the front door of Australia through which many overseas visitors gain their first impressions of Australia. The Territory Government and private investors in the Territory are doing their best to build world class facilities to attract vistors from overseas. It is interesting to note that the number of visitors coming through Darwin and Alice Springs into Australia is growing quite rapidly. In 1984-85 a total of 53,000 overseas visitors and 311,000 interstate visitors came to the Northern Territory. Some 155,460 of these visitors came to the territory by air. This does not include use of the airport by Territory residents, which of course would swell and perhaps triple that number. The point is that with the existence of the national parks of Kakadu and Uluru - Kakadu in Arnhem Land and Uluru at Ayers Rock - the number of visitors is greatly increasing. For instance, in 1984-85 Uluru had 110,162 visitors and the number of visitors to Kakadu came close to that figure. I seek to emphasise that the swell in the number of tourists coming through Darwin and Alice Springs points to the necessity for urgent action at these two airports.

It is the aim of the tourist industry in the Northern Territory as assisted by the Territory Government to continue to attract visitors to the Northern Territory. I believe that a realistic promotion is now progressing directed at attracting one million visitors to the Northern Territory by 1994. This is reasonable for the tourist industry in light of the international facilities that are now being built in Darwin and Alice Springs, but investors must have some qualms, not as to the ability to bring visitors to these two areas but because of the fact that to an extent investors have been sold down the drain. When the plans were being made to invest many millions of dollars in the tourist industry-in international facilities, hotels and what have you-investors thought that the international airport was really going to come about. As I have said previously, when international visitors see the incredible situation that exists now and pass through the old hangar they must wonder where on earth they have arrived. It is a very poor situation.

The Territory is already building up its world standard accommodation facilities with the construction of the Yulara complex, the Sheraton Hotels in Alice Springs and Darwin and other international facilities. The feasibility studies for all these projects were conducted by well regarded professional accounting firms. The consultants' studies and the Territory Government's decision to act were based on some fundamental premises which included the prompt upgrading of the Darwin Airport facilities to facilitate the direct flow of international tourists to the Territory in accordance with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Parliament's Public Works Committee and the Commonwealth upgrading of the Alice Springs Airport and its terminal to cater more adequately for increasing domestic traffic and wide-bodied aircraft. On both accounts the Federal Government is letting the Territory down and, in doing so, jeopardises the Territory's prospects of improving its tourism industry. Improving its tourism industry increases the Territory's revenue, which makes it more able to stand on its own feet.

I believe that Darwin Airport and Alice Springs Airport could be run by a company, although not necessarily a corporation, as has been envisaged for airports at other capital cities in Australia. To get these projects moving and on the road, which is most essential, a company could be formed, perhaps along the lines of Cairns International Airport, that would at least manage and operate the facilities. It could be a shared responsibility between the Federal Government, the Northern Territory Government and private enterprise.

The Alice Springs Airport is in a most dreadful situation. At times five jets are crowded on the tarmac. I commend the Department of Aviation for having put up security fences. Having so many jets crowded in such a small area makes the airport prone to accidents. There is only one airstrip to take wide-bodied aircraft. The strip is quite insufficient. It is also quite inefficient for use by the Department of Defence. One must be very concerned when one sees the movement of defence aircraft, such as Mirages, across the country arriving in a place such as Alice Springs with their fuel practically extended and with only a few minutes to land. The result is that they come in, one after another, as one can see them do, at a tremendous pace and all land on the one strip, gathering at one end of the aero- drome. That, too, is very conducive to a major accident. So the Alice Springs Airport must be upgraded for defence and developmental reasons.

I believe that there have been some discussions among the Aviation Department, Federal authorities, the Northern Territory Government and the Alice Springs City Council regarding the upgrading of the Airport. There is really no argument. All parties are willing to accept responsibility and a type of local ownership. Local ownership in this regard should be in the form of a company that could manage both airports.

Senator Robertson spoke about the aerodrome local ownership plans in the Northern Territory. He mentioned Tennant Creek. Tennant Creek is a small town some 300 miles north of Alice Springs. It has struggled to bring about a reasonable existence from the many years of mining, from tourism, abattoirs and such. The town has applied for local ownership of the airport. The Tennant Creek Town Council received a letter from the Minister dated 7 February. The letter says:
The Department is continuing to maintain the airport with all repairs where possible taking place when no flights are scheduled in or out with minimal disruption.

There are considerable problems with the tarmac and the surface of the strips at Tennant Creek. The letter continued that an agreement in principle to the Tennant Creek Town Council taking over ownership was reached on 14 May 1985 and that, following consultations with the aviation industry, a study is now being conducted. The letter states that the Minister for Transport expects to make his decision at the end of March, that an engineering survey is now being conducted and that the consultants think there is a good chance that Tennant Creek Council will get ownership. It also states that the airport is at the moment operational as there has been no rain for several weeks. It is quite common in Tennant Creek for there to be no rain for several weeks. When there is rain, the airport is in a very dire condition.

I hope that Alice Springs Airport and Darwin Airport receive immediate attention. It is no good for the Minister to go on saying that he will give his advice in six months. I think it has been some nine to 12 months since he said that. It is no good his saying that there will be a survey and that he will watch the situation for three years. As he has the Federal responsibility for these places in the Northern Territory, the time has come for him to meet his responsibilities. In closing, I reiterate the coalition's present election policy on the management of major airports:

We will ensure that all major airports seek to recover their cost from operational income and, whenever possible, derive a profit for future works programs. We will set up management boards for each major airport. These boards will have wide powers of management and will be instructed whenever possible, to operate on commercial principles. Their membership will include business leaders and other qualified persons. These boards, subject to Commonwealth Government approval, will have the power to borrow on the commercial markets for the purposes of financing airport works.
The Opposition believes that this policy of separately and-I stress this-accountable airports is superior, therefore, the Opposition opposes this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 which seeks to establish a Commonwealth statutory authority to maintain and operate selected aerodromes and associated facilities. The airports are the capital city airports together with a number of other nominated airports. Two of those airports are in my State of Tasmania. I have particular concerns in that State. I note that during much of the debate my colleague on the opposite benches, Senator Grimes, has been reading a copy of the Examiner the headline of which reads `Airports in Crisis'. No doubt he feels somewhat embarrassed not only by that headline, but also by his Government's lack of concern for the needs of the northern Tasmanian community.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that we have been shortchanged by this Federal Labor Government. We note from the record that it put forward a program for cutbacks in meteorological services which affected the area. Proposals were made for cutbacks in night fire fighting services. I note from the Examiner that Ansett Airlines of Australia, the largest air freight operator out of Launceston Airport, which is one of the major air freight airports in Australia, has announced that it has written Launceston out of consideration as a base for a possible international freight service from Tasmania because airport facilities cannot handle the type of aircraft that would be needed to operate this type of service. So we have certainly been shortchanged. Much of the economy of the northern Tasmanian community depends on the continued expansion of this most important infrastructure in our area.

While this legislation is full of platitudes and generalities, it is very short on specifics. Mention is made in the second reading speech of the need for the appropriate gearing ratio, which obviously depends on matters such as the value of assets being vested in the Federal Airports Corporation, its future investment programs, the levels of working capital required and the level of financial flexibility necessary for proper management. It has been suggested by a colleague in the other place-the honourable member for Bass, Warwick Smith-that this matter should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The very vagueness of these proposals leaves much in question. I support that suggestion.

One of the problems of this legislation is its vagueness; it is not very satisfactory. We are not told the value of the assets that will be acquired. We do not know whether it will be their written down value, their replacement value or their current cost. I think this information is very necessary. It is also necessary for the community to be aware of the values because how can any community make an assessment if it does not have any forward projections from the Government of what is planned for a particular airport or what it is prepared to meet by way of cost so far as immediate capital expenditure requirements are concerned? Senator Grimes has said that Launceston activists made the wrong decision in resisting local ownership and that they would now have to live with it. We will have to live with it: Those are true words. However, the activists were not given enough information on which to make their decision. They were not given the future plans, they were not told of the costs or what the Government was prepared to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is all very well to say `rubbish'. I challenge Senator Grimes to outline those proposals in his speech when he follows me in a few minutes. I would also like him to state categorically whether the excellent garden and parkland facilities which surround the Launceston Airport and which make it such a beautiful airport will be downgraded. Some of his colleagues-former Senator Hearn and others-and I have had to fight for the retention of these sorts of facilities. With the emphasis on cost recovery, et cetera, this will be the first area which will be pruned. The gardeners will be sacked and the facilities will be downgraded. I challenge Senator Grimes to make a statement in the Senate to the northern Tasmanian community that these facilities will be maintained at the highest possible level.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for airport authorities to say that these matters have to take second place to airport safety. This excuse is always used. It is very convenient, when transferring an organisation from ministerial responsibility to a statutory corporation, to transfer its responsibility. It has been argued by my colleague Senator Puplick that this is merely a vehicle or a mechanism to let the Government off the hook from making difficult or contentious decisions. I am concerned about the lack of financial information and financial standards that will be required. The second reading speech states:

In setting the capital structure for the Corporation, particular attention will be given to the balance to be struck between the long term viability and needs for future investment of the Corporation, and the reasonable expectation of the Government for a proper return on the substantial public investment in airports.

What sort of return is appropriate? Is the written down value of assets appropriate? One might take over an old airport which has rundown facilities and is of very low value but which has a fairly high throughput of passengers. In that case it would be very easy to make a profit compared with a modern airport which has updated facilities and high costs. We need an answer on whether there will be cross-subsidisation between airports when this authority is established.

I am concerned about the ability of the Corporation to establish subsidiary corporations because there has been a very sad history, as the Senate has found out, of government statutory corporations establishing subsidiary companies. We need to know whether the same fiduciary relationships will be a necessary requirement of subsidiary companies as they are a requirement for the holding company. Therefore there needs to be some indication from government as to the sorts of values that will be put on the books and the values at which the assets will be acquired. For example, will the Government make a profit on transferred assets? I think we need to know the answer to that question. We should establish within the legislation certain limits on borrowing and the links between short and long term debt. Debt equity ratios can be established. I know it is difficult to foresee all the costs of the assets that will be acquired in any particular period but we could establish certain accounting links or debt equity ratios within the legislation which would certainly make it a much better piece of legislation.

The Government says that the Corporation will be required to forward to the Minister for Aviation each year a three-year forward program, including a budget for the following year and details of corporate plans. I presume, therefore, that all the airports will be taken over immediately the legislation comes into effect. If not, there certainly will be difficulties in meeting this requirement. How do we know the costs and values of the assets that will be taken over if their acquisition takes place over a prolonged period?

Although there are requirements for the disclosure of results and the publication of indicators, there will be problems because I can see the need for a certain amount of cross-subsidisation, particularly at certain stages of the development of airports. If we require each airport each year to make a profit or a reasonable return, there could be difficulties. There is also the possibility in establishing a statutory government operation that it could be starved of funds. We have seen how governments have virtually drained funds out of such organisations to the point that they make them bankrupt. In subsequent years governments have had to pour enormous amounts of money into those organisations to make them viable again. It could be that certain airports will suffer disastrously as a result of this measure.

Although the Government says that there is a need to establish a statutory corporation in order to meet the requirements of a dynamic market, it also says that it is not being critical of the Department of Aviation. Surely there is an inherent criticism. Certainly employees are concerned about transferring superannuation benefits. I ask: Why not change the administrative processes for the whole of government operations or the Public Service if it is acknowledged that they are so inefficient and do not meet the requirements of a dynamic market? In other words, there is a recognition that the Public Service has to be inefficient and that it does not have to meet a dynamic market. But the Government is saying in this particular case: `We will isolate this particular segment of government activity, that of aviation, to meet a dynamic market'. I believe that there is a certain inconsistency in this sort of thinking.

We do have a number of concerns. I believe that we are entitled to a study, particularly in Launceston, funded by the Government, which would indicate the extent of the necessary upgrading prior to bringing the airport into incorporation, to determine the sorts of costs people would be prepared to meet if we go into local ownership. There is also need for a provision-something lacking in the legislation-allowing a community to say to the Corporation: `We are not satisfied; we now want to go under local ownership'. There must also be certain terms and conditions of transfer as regards the value at which assets would be set if such an arrangement were to take place. This is certainly a shortcoming, because if we are concerned about serving the interests of the community, the community must have some rights. If it decides that it has been shortchanged, there should be the opportunity to come back.

The Government must show where there are demonstrable inefficiencies and excessive costs in the present system. The Government's first duty is to do that and to reduce those costs rather than to use this excuse of a new corporation under which it can hide its responsibilities. The Bill is unnecessary. It will not necessarily be in the best interests of the community in which I live. I ask the Minister to answer the allegations I have made and to give assurances to the northern Tasmanian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close this debate and, in the traditional way, I thank honourable senators for their contributions, although I must say that in a couple of cases I do not think that thanks is very much justified. I take up two points that were raised by Senator Puplick because I just want to set the record straight. He castigated the Government for rushing this legislation through the Parliament and for not giving them time to have a look at it. I remind Senator Puplick that this legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives on 13 November 1985, at which time it was given to the Opposition so that the Opposition would have time to study it. It is now into February. If Opposition senators are going to take this amount of time to study a bit of legislation of this type, I take up Senator Sanders's point and say that they should not be here.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the legislation is on the list today is that I put it there. The reason I put it on the list today is that we have a piece of legislation ready for debate dealing with human rights, on which I think about 33 Opposition senators want to talk endlessly. We are obviously in for a few solid days of righteous indignation and all the other emotions that are expressed so well by Opposition senators. I thought that it was fairly sensible to get this important bit of legislation through at the time. Then, in an enormous step, Senator Puplick castigated the Government for being dilatory about the siting of the second Sydney airport. I remind honourable senators that the Government which Senator Puplick supported dilly-dallied on Sydney airport for about 15 years and refused to make a decision because it was too hard. Now Senator Puplick has the cheek to castigate this Government for not announcing a decision when, in about three weeks' time, we will have been in government for only three years.

This legislation is part of the Government's strategy to improve the efficiency of the aviation industry and to improve the level of service to the consumers and to those who use our airports. I think that Senator Sanders and those who have actually read the legislation and talked to the Minister about it agree that this is right. We believe, and apparently some Opposition senators believe, that this would be better done through something other than the present administration by the Department of Aviation. There seems to be not much argument about that. But there seems to be considerable opposition to the establishment of an airports corporation of this type, although we hear precious little from Opposition senators about what they would do-except for Senator Kilgariff, who said that apparently the Opposition would set up management committees all over the country to look after the airports.

We believe that the commercial operation of airports would in fact be better managed by a commercial business enterprise, which would have greater flexibility and greater responsiveness. Part of that flexibility and responsiveness will be given to the Federal Airports Corporation by virtue of the fact that it will not be bound by Public Service restrictions and regulations, or by government departments in its capital works. We thought that this would have been welcomed by these pillars of flexibility, private enterprise and free enterprise opposite. But no, this is all criticised, too.

The Government has undertaken two reviews of the airline industry. We are currently reviewing the two airline agreement. We have made changes to Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd, which have resulted in their making a profit for the first time this year. But still, none of this satisfies the people opposite. They want to oppose for the sake of opposing. They want to oppose any sort of change of this type because, first of all, they did not do anything themselves and, secondly, because they cannot think of anything better.

We have had a fair bit of parochialism in this debate and I crave the indulgence of the Senate to join in, because I come from a town where, as Senator Watson pointed out, some of that parochialism has been going on. I am very happy to take part in it because I think that nowhere else in Australia gives a better example of how stuffy, conservative people who are afraid of change, who are willing to be manipulated by conservative politicians, can lead to a situation where the whole system is paralysed and where no change occurs because of nonsense and fear tactics. The motto of the city of Launceston is `Progress with Prudence'. I do not know who Prudence was, but the way these people go on-they are represented in the Senate and in the galleries here today-would have caused my Irish ancestors to say it was something like `progress with paralysis'. If we compare Launceston with the city of Devonport just down the road, or the city of Cairns way up in North Queensland, we can demonstrate what happens when people like this get into the development of facilities of this type. The Fraser Government said to the denizens of Launceston and other places--

TALK.START.PARA: —Denizens?
—Yes; I think a denizen is a monster, a dark dwelling person or something.
—Someone who lives in a dark wood.

—Yes. The Fraser Government said to them `Look, we have a local ownership scheme in this country. Will you have a look at it? Will you see how this might affect your city?', knowing quite well that we have one of the only airports in Australia that pays its way. They said no; and their local member, Mr Newman, who was a Minister, said no. He set up a local airports action committee, which said no. He put the new member for Bass, Mr Smith, on it, and he said no. They came around to me, as their local senator, and I said: `What do you want?'. They said: `What we want is Launceston Airport upgraded to 747 aircraft standard'. I said: `Good heavens, that costs about $35m; why do you want to do that?' They said: `So that we can fly fat lamb carcasses to Singapore'. I said: `How many times a year?' They said: `About twice a year'. They were willing to spend $35m to upgrade this airport to 747 standard to send two 747s full of lamb carcasses to Singapore once a year. Even they could see that that was ridiculous, so they went back to Mr Newman and to the gurus back there and said `Grimes says that that is a bit rich, that it costs about $35m. The other thing that Senator Grimes said was, ``Will you look seriously at the possibility of local ownership?'' '. They said no. Here is a dreadful socialist such as me, supposed to be a centralist, saying: `For God's sake look at looking after your own airport and developing your own airport'. But they say `No, no, that is a Federal Government responsibility; we want the Federal Government to do that'.

SPEECH.PARA: On the north west coast of Tasmania there are two airports-Devonport and Wynyard. The Fraser Government said: `Will you look at local ownership?' The people of Wynyard-and here I am going to apologise to Senator Archer-have told me, and I have no doubt that it is true, that they went to their local member, Mr Groom, who was also before that a Minister in the Fraser Government, and asked him: `What do you think?' He said: `Do not touch it; do not have a bar of it. It is a plot by Fraser to off-load all of the expenditure.' I accused Senator Archer once of saying that. I was wrong. He actually encouraged them. However, the people of Wynyard said: `No, Mr Groom tells us we do not want local ownership'. However, the people of Devonport, closer to Launceston, with an old Quonset hut as an airport building, said: `Yes, we will give it a go; we will develop our airport.' What has happened is that they have a beautiful new terminal.

If I do a decent day's work in Sydney the best way for me to get to Launceston is to get an East-West Airlines flight at 6.40 at night from Sydney, fly to Devonport and then drive to Launceston. The people of Devonport had the sense to look at the situation, look at the possibilities, look at the facts they were given, as the people of Launceston were given and to develop their airport. All the time back in Launceston, Mr Smith, Senator Watson and Mr Newman were saying: `No, we do not want a bar of local ownership. It is a socialist plot by Grimes. We do not want a bar of local ownership.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is East-West able to fly out of Launceston? East-West cannot fly out of Launceston.

—Senator Watson says that East-West wants to fly to Launceston from Sydney and they could do that but this Government will not let them. The facts are that East-West has to have a licence to fly from Sydney to Launceston if it is a trunk route. Under the two-airlines agreement, put into legislation by the Government that Senator Watson supported, it cannot fly into Launceston. It will not be able to until we can do something about that two-airline agreement which his Government put into legislation. It would be a breach of contract and Senator Watson knows it. Senator Watson has the gall to get up and say in Launceston: `Those nasty socialists will not let East-West Airlines fly into Launceston'. It is a travesty of what is possible to see what has happened in Launceston. I am reported in the newspapers today as having said so and I say so again. Senator Watson, Mr Smith and Mr Newman have repeatedly and consistently opposed local ownership and local control of the Launceston Airport. They have come out and said so over and over again. When we set up the Corporation they came out and said: `But we might want local ownership. We want you now to fund an inquiry to see whether we should have local ownership.' They were adamantly opposed to local ownership. They have consistently opposed local ownership. The present member, Mr Smith, has come out and said: `Do not have a bar of local ownership. It is a plot by the Federal Government.' Now they see what has happened at Devonport. I ask Senator Watson to go and see what has happened in Cairns where the people were given the same facts as the people of Launceston. What happens? They say: `Oh, we might have made a mistake'. All I can say is this: They have made a mistake and, as I said in the paper, they will have to live with it. The other reason I think they will have to live with it is that I have changed my mind, I think, because who would want a lot of troglodytes, denizens, if you like, people of this type, running the local airport? One would not want them running the local airport. If they were a bit forward thinking like the people of Devonport or Cairns, fair enough.
—Or Wynyard.
—Or Wynyard, for that matter. The trouble is that the people of Wynyard were conned by their previous member too. But no, they did not do it and now they bleat. But they do worse than that--
—You have changed the ground rules. That is the difference.

—We did not change any ground rules and Senator Watson knows it. He knows we did not change any ground rules. But they do worse than that; they get up and they go on with the nonsense they went on with in the Launceston Examiner yesterday. They put the fear of God into people using Launceston Airport. As it happens, Launceston Airport is a very efficient, very effective and very safe airport. If one goes on the way Newman has been going on-at least when he is doing that he is not using the Freedom of Information Act to try to find out about the private lives of members of Parliament, but it is not much better-and misleads the people of Launceston, we will get people saying: `Maybe I will not fly into Launceston. People like Watson and Newman and Smith are saying that this is an unsafe airport.' It is not an unsafe airport; it is an efficient and effective airport and under the operational regulations that are applied now it is more than adequate for the traffic that goes in and out of it now.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we come to what happened yesterday. What happened yesterday is that Ansett Airlines of Australia, and Mr Newman, said that it would not put its international freight operations into Launceston because it could not fly 707s in there. Ansett has never made a request to the Department of Aviation or to the Government about a 707 airport in Launceston. What it is really about is its desire to extend its freight terminal, against the plans that have been put forward by this Government and the previous Government for the development of Launceston Airport. Ansett wants to extend its freight terminal in such a way that it would impede the future development of that airport for passengers and for other purposes. It is not willing to discuss it. It is not willing to enter into negotiations about it. It just says: `This is what we want to do and we will do it. If the Government won't agree, we will go to Mr Newman as we know he will kick up a fuss. We will go to Senator Watson and Mr Smith because we know they will kick up a fuss.'

Senator Sanders has said in the past that what has happened with airports in this country, and particularly in Tasmania, is that they have become cargo cult things. If one puts up a big enough runway-or in Senator Kilgariff's case, if one puts up two or three runways-one will suddenly, like a magnet, attract planes from all over the world which will bring in millions of people. I remember when I was on the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania with Senator Peter Rae, who incidentally was also in favour of local ownership, that we took evidence in the north west coast of Tasmania. The people wanted two 747s a day from Melbourne, which would have emptied the whole population of Tasmania in a couple of weeks. That sort of exaggerated nonsense goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is correct.

—It was an exaggeration or hyperbole. I accept that, Senator Archer. What this is all about, unfortunately, is local bloody- minded conservative politicians who opposed for the sake of opposition. Now, the situation having got to the stage where they were demonstrably wrong and when they were made to look fools by the people of Devonport, they say: `We were wrong. Please, will the Government let us off the hook? Please, will you run a big inquiry to see if we were right or to see if we were wrong?' One just cannot play the game that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson had the cheek to get up here in Parliament today and say that the deficiency in this legislation is that it does not give the local people enough say and that the locals should have a say. For the last four or five years we have been battling in Launceston to give the local people a say and it is his ilk who have been saying: No, it is Federal policy.' There is nothing in this legislation which stops local people from having a say. In fact, the necessity for the Corporation to report on an airport by airport basis, the necessity for it to report on all its activities and the necessity for it to demonstrate how efficient and effective it has been will mean that Senator Watson, all the citizens of Launceston and I can get up and say: `We are not getting a fair go; you are not doing the right thing.' But, for heaven's sake, he came in here, when we are talking about efficient airports, effective airports and economic airports, and wanted an assurance from me that the Airports Corporation will not do anything to the gardens outside Launceston Airport. As if the most important things in Launceston are the blooming rhododendrons and camellias outside the airport! I love the gardens. I think they are terrific. I think it was tremendous that we had a Minister for Aviation from Launceston. That is why we got our huge airport terminal and that is why we got our gardens. The wife of the Minister developed the gardens. She designed and developed them and she did a terrific job. In a quarter of an hour speech the most serious point Senator Watson could bring up today is that he wants a guarantee from the Minister representing the Minister in another place that-I think these were his words-no one will prune the gardens outside the Launceston Airport terminal. This is absolutely typical of the nonsense that has gone on.

We have had an example today of Senator Archer asking a whole series of questions: `Why is it? What does that mean?' All the answers are in the second reading speech. I do not have to answer them because Senator Sanders answered them. I thank him. He has spared the Senate from listening to me for 10 minutes. All the answers are there but quite clearly the honourable senator has not read or considered the legislation. Senator Puplick talked about the delay in the legislation and delays in decisions relating to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. That is incredible coming from those opposite who spent as long as they did deciding where Sydney Airport should be. He did not have much to say.

I enjoyed the contributions of Senator Robertson and Senator Kilgariff about airports in the Northern Territory. I am not an expert on them but, having arrived at Darwin at 4 a.m., I appreciate what an apalling terminal that is. Only one terminal used to be worse, and that was at Devonport. Local ownership fixed that problem. The residents now have a decent airport. I hope that the people of Darwin get the airport that they deserve. The people at Devonport did. I sometimes think that the people of Launceston got more than they deserved. I will raise the matters mentioned with the Minister because I have no detailed knowledge of them. I urge honourable senators to take this legislation more seriously than they have. We want to set up a corporation which will own, develop and operate airports efficiently and cost effectively but will, of course, operate them within the overriding requirements of safety and security decided by the Government and the Department of Aviation. The Corporation will operate these airports in the capital cities and it will include in its operation a couple of general airports, Coolangatta and Launceston.

The objectives of the authority will be spelt out in the National Airport Authority's proposal in appendix B, page B1. I will not read them out. If those opposite cannot see in that clear objectives and what the Government wants to do, I doubt their capacity to read. We have demonstrated, in dealing with other statutory corporations, that we want to see them run efficiently and effectively and provide the service that they should. We went to an election with this as a policy. I believe that there is a general acceptance in the industry and outside it that this is an effective way to proceed. I can understand people with little, parochial views, with nothing much to contribute to the world, making a big noise about this matter in their little backyards. But I do not think that it impresses anyone outside those backyards. I hope that those people in Launceston who have been carrying on now realise what a disservice they have done to that community in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an acknowledgment that we are not going to do well under this Corporation?

—I know that the honourable senator is sharp and that he will interrupt with such incisive comments, but he should wait until I am finished. I am as absolutely confident as anyone that the Airports Corporation will look at the airports individually and as a whole and will ensure that they are run economically and effectively, and that the runway at Launceston Airport will be upgraded, as is needed, to cope with increasing traffic and the changes with which it has not been possible to cope in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made no bones about preferring local ownership but I am sure that the Minister has done the right thing. I have had long talks with him about Launceston because a few individuals on its action committee, local politicians and members of the chamber of commerce were trying to screw successive government over and again regardless of needs and economies. If the airport had been taken over by local ownership in the way it was then operating it would have operated inefficiently. That group would have been a bit like Oliver Twist asking for more and more and not accepting responsibility in the way that the people of Devonport and Cairns have. That is a great pity.

Perhaps some time in the future when we have less conservative people in this place, when Senator Watson and I have gone and when a new generation of people are here who can think better we can have another change. As Senator Sanders said quangos probably should not last forever. They are much better when they are younger than when they are older. Perhaps we could look at this matter again in five or 10 years. Something had to be done nationally. That is why we have this legislation. In Launceston something had to be done locally because the people there could not think beyond their backyards. I thank Senator Sanders and others who support the legislation. It is a pity that the Opposition Liberal and National parties do not support the legislation. I would like to have been enlightened as to why they oppose it. I suppose it is the old matter of opposition for opposition's sake. I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I hope that we can get the legislation through quickly.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.
Referral to Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 196a, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Federal Airports Corporation Bill 1986 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes such a proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Archer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I asked a question that I regarded as quite serious regarding the situation of New Zealanders coming to this country, and the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who replied, tried to make a joke of the issue. I assure him and the Senate that a great many people are quite worried about the present open-door policy of immigration that we have with regard to people coming to Australia from New Zealand. Primarily, of course, people are worried about the cost of supporting those New Zealanders who are out of work-and in a moment I will give some figures on just what percentage of them are out of work-which is, by estimates made last year, in excess of $60m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always felt if one can afford to give money away, that is all right; but Australia cannot afford it at the moment. We are deeply in debt. As I have said before, we are more in debt than many of the countries that the newspapers write a lot about. We are more in debt than Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, Chile or Poland and our overseas debt is increasing. Our balance of payments is in a mess; our dollar continues to fall; and yet we are letting New Zealand export its unemployment to this country. I saw written: `Exporting no-hopers is New Zealand's only growth industry'. Let me immediately say that not all of those who come to Australia go on the dole or become associated with drugs or with crime, but an undue percentage of the people who come to this country do. I had a letter from somebody who is working in New Zealand. Attached to it is a photostat of an article from a New Zealand paper-I do not know which paper it was-which is headed: `NZ loses 18,424'. It states:
Wellington, Today.
Latest Statistics Department migration figures show a big rise in permanent and long term departures for the year to the end of November.
There was a net-term migration loss of 18,424 for the period, compared to a loss of 1,806 for the corresponding period in 1984.
That is a factor of some ten-fold. Attached was this letter:
It really is about time that we brought in visas/work permits the same as the UK, it really has got out of hand.
The writer says:

Hell, I'm supporting four Kiwis on the dole in Australia with my taxes, the Government should mount an inquiry into the effects on the Australian economy with the enormous number of Kiwis in Australia, our taxes could go down, in fact they could even abolish the A$20.00 departure tax on the savings . . .

Why should NZ have less and less unemployment at our extent, they don't want to support ANZUS, imagine as an exercise what would happen to the NZ economy if all `excess' New Zealanders were sent back to Kiwiland . . .
The final sentence is:
The NZ Government really gets it easy.

That, I think, sums up the attitude of quite a lot of people in this country with regard to the number of people coming from New Zealand to Australia. Last year, also in New Zealand, there was an article with the byline: `From Tess Livingstone in Canberra', which, in part, reads:
About 11,000 New Zealand-born unemployment beneficiaries cost Australian taxpayers $64 million a year.
The majority of these have arrived in Australia in the past 10 years.
A Melbourne academic who has researched the subject extensively has called for an urgent review of Australia's `open door' policy towards New Zealanders.
A Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology public administration lecturer, Mr Scott Prasser, said the present arrangement meant New Zealanders needed only a passport to live in Australia.
He has published his findings in a social welfare journal, Australian Society.
`They do not have to fit any job schedules, be sponsored by relatives or have a lot of money,' Mr Prasser said.
`They simply hop on a plane for Australia.'
Mr Prasser said the 1981 Census showed 177,000 New Zealanders living permanently in Australia, a 97 per cent increase on the 1976 figure of 90,000.
Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Department records show another 27,000 New Zealanders settled in Australia between 1981 and 1984, including 12,920 in 1981-82, 7,666 in 1982-83 and 6,573 in 1983-84.
The article further said:
The Statistics Bureau August-
that must have been August 1985-
labour force figures show New Zealanders who settled in Australia after 1981 have an unemployment rate almost twice that of the average for Australian-born residents.
The figures show 128,000 New Zealanders in the Australian workforce-with 16,200 of them unemployed.
The unemployment rate among New Zealanders who moved to Australia between 1981 and 1983 is 15.1 per cent.
Among New Zealanders who arrived between 1976 and 1983, the unemployment rate is 13.1 per cent.
As a whole, New Zealand-born people in Australia have an unemployment rate of 12.7 per cent.
This compares with 7.6 per cent for Australian-born people, and an average of 8.8 per cent for those born outside Australia.

That, I think, gives some idea of just how much the Australian taxpayer is supporting those people who come to this country from New Zealand. A more recent article, from the New Zealand Herald on Saturday, 1 February 1986, was headed: `More Off To Australia'. It stated:
The outflow of New Zealanders seeking better jobs in Australia continues to accelerate, with no signs yet of the turn-around predicted last week by the Labour Department.
Statistics released last night show that during 1985 there was a net loss of 19,299 people leaving the country for at least a year.
Under the headline `Since 1979', it continues:
That was the biggest outflow of any calendar year since 1980, when the outflow on a similar permanent and long-term basis was 23,593.

That gives us the situation that more and more people are coming to this country. If we had an open-door policy for places like England or the United States, I am sure that there would be quite an outcry. But there does not seem to be such an outcry with regard to all these people coming to Australia, quite a high percentage of them, as I have stated, going on to unemployment benefits.

Finally, I think I can sum up the situation by quoting from an article in the New Zealand Sunday Times of 22 December last year. Again, we are referring to what Mr Scott Prasser said in an issue of the magazine Australian Society. He said:
. . . we may have been mates in the past but now New Zealanders are acting more like bludgers.
That is a quote from the newspaper; they are not my words. He continued:
Given Australia's continuing high unemployment levels, perhaps it is time Australia's open door to New Zealand was closed just a little.

The fact that some of the 11,000 New Zealanders are receiving $64 million in Australian unemployment benefits makes a review of the present system urgent. By contrast only 450 Australians receive New Zealand benefits, at a cost of $1.5 million . . .

I do not think that Australian taxpayers can continue to support the present open door policy. As I said, when I asked this question yesterday the Minister who replied treated it as a bit of a joke. I do not think it is a joke. The fact that $64m, on an open-ended basis, is being given to those people who decide to come from New Zealand and live here is, as I have pointed out, worrying quite a number of people in this country. I think the Government would do well to look at the situation, to examine it, perhaps to supply the figures that I asked for by way of question yesterday afternoon and, if necessary, to change the situation, particularly whilst we in Australia have a time of such high unemployment. There are many young people in this country who cannot get jobs and cannot look forward to having a decent job in the near future. I do not see why we should allow people from another country open access to Australia under these circumstances.
Sitting suspended from 1.02 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I remind the Minister that in Question Time yesterday he consistently refused to answer my questions about the Government's use of high interest rates to support the Australian dollar. In view of yesterday's comment by the head of the Federal Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, that there was not a lot of scope left for jacking up interest rates, does he now concede that the Government has indeed been jacking up interest rates to protect the dollar? Does he agree with Mr Fraser's further comment that interest rates have had their day as an instrument of economic policy and, if so, will the Government reverse its high interest rates policy and grant relief to Australian home buyers, farmers and small businessmen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of farmers and interest rates it ought to be noted that normally the farm sector is a net lender. That may have changed in the last six months but it has yet to be shown that it has. If the farm sector, as distinct from some individual farmers, is a net lender, higher interest rates will increase the incomes of farmers in total, not reduce them. That is the offset that ought to be noted. In regard to Mr Fraser's speech yesterday, I understand that he has told the Press that the answer reported was an answer to a hypothetical question which posed circumstances which do not in fact exist. The answer given by Mr Fraser to that hypothetical question is in complete conformity with standard economic theory and should have surprised nobody but economic illiterates, which probably accounts for why it has been seized with such glee by members of the Opposition and most of the Press Gallery.

ANSWER.PARA: I happen to have a copy of Mr Fraser's speech with me. In it he described the real world, as he saw it, and what has really been happening as distinct from hypothetical propositions. He said.
Over the years Australia has performed relatively poorly in terms of restraining wage and other cost pressures.
I interpolate that the years Mr Fraser was talking about were the years of Liberal-National Party government, and especially of Fraser-Howard government. He continued:

As a result, it has been necessary for the exchange rate to depreciate to permit us to catch up with our competitors. The approach to wages and prices embodied in the Government's Accord with the ACTU is helping to restrain such pressures. In the past also wage and cost pressures have distorted wage and profit shares in ways which have been inimical to growth. The Accord, and the wages pause which preceded it, have resulted in more moderate growth in real wages and, combined with increases in productivity, sharp reductions in real unit labour costs: . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose wages pause was that?

—I notice that a member of the Opposition asked: `Whose policy was the wages pause?'. There is no secret about that. The wages pause was the last ditch policy of the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government, having walked away from having any wages policy at all in May of 1981, opted for the most centralised wage determination system which can be devised-that is, a centralised wages pause. That was its desperation measure of late 1982. So I ask those members of the Opposition who seem to think that both the policy being advocated by their present Leader-that is, deregulation and five years of industrial warfare, to use his term-is in any way compatible with the wages pause of the Fraser Government. They are, of course, diametrically opposed because on the one hand we have the most centralised wage determination system which can be devised and on the other, so Mr Howard says, we have a free market. Mr Fraser continued:

ANSWER.PARA: The depreciation of the $A in 1985, in a situation of more moderate wage cost increases, has restored Australia's competitiveness to about the levels of the early 1970s (see Graph 3). Although it has not been the only factor, the Accord has made substantial contributions to these improvements in Australia's fundamentals. It represents a different approach to wage restraint and to the handling of the inflationary effects of currency depreciations compared with the past.

I commend to members of the Opposition a study of Mr Fraser's speech. In particular, I commend it to the Leader of the Opposition, who I understand said recently that he is too far away from the treasury bench to understand what is really going on in the economy these days. I have heard a quip along the lines that after he was one day away from the treasury bench he was too far away to understand what was going on. If members of the Opposition study Mr Fraser's speech in some detail they may become somewhat more enlightened about the state of the economy than they are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister for Finance's refuge in the hypothetical question part of his answer and I ask him to address his comments to the real world, to the situation in Australia in February 1986. I ask the Minister: Is there at present scope for any further jacking up of interest rates to protect the dollar or have high interest rates had their day as an instrument of economic policy and is there now room for a reduction in interest rates?

—As I explained yesterday, the Government's economic strategy is supported by three principal legs; that is, a wages policy, which the Opposition does not have and which during most of its last couple of years in government it did not have; we place some emphasis on monetary policy; and we place some emphasis on fiscal policy, particularly expenditure restraint-expenditure restraint, if I may say so, of a degree never exercised by the previous Government and in particular by the previous Treasurer, who is now the Leader of the Opposition. In all of his five years as Treasurer he did not bring in a Budget that held expenditure within the forecast limits or a Budget which held the deficit within the forecast limits.
—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce analysed the latest labour force statistics? What are the major features of those statistics that will affect Government economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be charitable to myself to say that I have analysed the latest labour force statistics in any detail but I am able to give them to the Senate.
—Is this question a complete surprise?

—It should not be a complete surprise to any politician. If I may say so, before Question Time Senator Chipp drew my attention to an article published in a paper in January 1984 which he seemed to think was relevant to me. Today's figures show a 3.4 per cent increase in jobs this financial year. The total figure has exceeded by some considerable amount the Government's projected creation of 500,000 jobs by April 1986, the end of its third year of office. Since coming to office the Government has generated over 600,000 jobs in less than three years-100,000 more than the target it set itself. The figure in percentage terms represents a 3.4 per cent increase this financial year and the largest January to January increase since the start of monthly surveys in February 1978. For the fourth consecutive month the unemployment rate has remained under 8 per cent. I also make the point that three-quarters of the jobs created by this Government have been full time jobs, and the present unemployment rate is 2.6 percentage points below the high point of September 1983. I have mentioned that the unemployment rate remained under 8 per cent for the fourth consecutive month. The rate in percentage terms is 7.8 per cent-the same as last month's figures-and that is attributed to the fact that the participation rate increased slightly from 61.1 per cent to 61.6 per cent in that period.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures again indicate, first of all, a satisfaction of government policies in terms of predictions and a stated intention by the Government. They indicate a further and continuing success in the Government's economic policies and are encouraging to the Government in terms of the steadiness with which the employment rate has been maintained in the last few months. Once again I would say that, in referring to these figures, they are not figures about which any government can be complacent or satisfied. They are figures about which a government and, I believe, members of this Parliament, can be pleased without lapsing into any degree of complacency about their improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to his recent claims that the magnitude and timing of the drop in world oil prices has taken everyone by surprise-even himself-a claim that the Minister has been using to justify the Government's cheating Australians out of the full benefit of the world price reduction. I ask the Minister whether he recalls his speech to the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia on 18 July last year when he specifically referred to and cavassed the difficulties for Australia which would follow a drop in the price of oil to $US20 a barrel or below and also to several other speeches to industry meetings where he canvassed the uncertainties about the oil price. Did the Minister acquaint the Cabinet with the implications of such a lower price for oil when it was considering its 1985-86 Budget and, more importantly, when it was considering its policy which ultimately was announced in the tax statement of 19 September last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The challenge I gave Senator Durack yesterday was to make good his boast that he had foreseen the drop in world oil prices by asking him to indicate where, if anywhere, on the public record he had shown this prescience and perception that he now has in retrospect. I note that he is unable to do anything of the kind. Of course I recall making the CEDA speech and a number of others last year in which the implications of a drop, either suddenly of over time, in the price of oil to $20 or below, were canvassed. That was part of an entirely rational process of policy development and contingency planning which is characteristic of all Government Ministers' approaches to their portfolios and in spectacular contrast with the muddled ad hockery of our predecessors.

ANSWER.PARA: What I am clear about is what I said during the course of debates and contributions to the present controversy over the last few days that, as of the latter part of last year and in the immediate run-up to the price collapse which has occurred in the latter part of January, while there was a general expectation of a price drop to around $US22 or $US23 a barrel, it is simply not the case that in any circles that I have heard about there was a serious belief that there would be a plunge down to of the order of $17 or $18 or below that which we have seen. So I do not resile in any way from the comments that I made during the week.

As to the question of whether I acquainted my ministerial colleagues with the possible price scenario that we have encountered, I did, of course, circulate, through appropriate channels, copies of my speech to my colleagues and I am sure that they read it avidly as they always do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, refers to the lobbying against the Government's Bill of Rights Bill. A consistent claim in letters that I, and I presume others, have received, is that the United States of America and the United Kingdom had rejected the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights but that the covenant had been accepted by what they described as Warsaw Pact countries, implying that the covenant was therefore an instrument of repression rather than freedom. What are the facts on the international agreement to the covenant? Is there any basis to the sorts of claims made by those encouraging people to oppose the Bill of Rights Bill?
—On a point of order, Mr President: Is it not contrary to Standing Orders to ask the Minister to anticipate a debate which is currently on the Senate Notice Paper?
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am indebted to you for that characteristically robust and direct ruling. The obligations in the covenant, notwithstanding so much of the mischaracterisation that has occurred, have been adopted by a large number of countries including many countries which have a political culture or social philosphy very similar to that prevailing in Australia. Australia itself, of course, signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights back in 1972 and ratified it on 13 August 1980 during the tenure and power of the Fraser Liberal-National Party coalition Government. While there are many characteristics of that Government which are reminiscent of the Warsaw Pact countries I do not think it can be said that there was a resistance on the part of the Fraser Government to the principles underlying that particular covenant, although there has been a subsequent resistance to putting them into practice.

ANSWER.PARA: The United Kingdom has signed and ratified the covenant. The United Kingdom was also one of the first signatories to the European Convention which tracks over much the same ground and it should be mentioned that there is currently a Bill in the House of Lords to bring the European Convention into domestic law in the same way as is proposed in Australia with the Bill of Rights. The terms of the European Convention are very similar indeed to that of the international covenant. So far as the United States is concerned it is true that it has not ratified the Bill so far because it has been unable to obtain the necessary 75 per cent of votes in the Senate because of the view of many senators there that the essence of many of the protections in the covenant are already embodied in the United States Constitution. But, notwithstanding that, the United States has signed the covenant and one would expect it to be regarded universally as observing its strictures.

New Zealand has ratified the covenant and in fact is moving now to a statutory Bill of Rights. Canada has ratified the covenant and now has a constitutional charter of rights after having had a statutory Bill of Rights in force for the last 20 years. A large majority of the members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the Council of Europe have ratified the covenant, as have a number of members of the Commonwealth of Nations. It is absolute nonsensical scuttlebutt to claim, as so many have, that the international covenant is something that has only appealed to Warsaw Pact countries or those with social and political traditions at odds with our own. That is a totally misleading falsehood. I should finally add, of course, that simply because some nations adopt obligations which they do not meet, it does not mean that other countries should not meet those obligations or that the obligations themselves are not worthy ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General a question on the campaign against the Bill of Rights. Have Government Ministers, like Australian Democrat Senators, been victims of a vicious, lying, nationwide letterwriting, telegram and telephone campaign against the Bill of Rights? Have members of the National Party of Australia and some members of the Liberal Party of Australia, particularly from Tasmania, primarily been responsible for exploiting decent, innocent Australians with untruths, distortions and lies? For example, does the proposed Bill of Rights in any way compel or allow homosexual marriages, as is being claimed by members of the National Party? Does the proposed Bill, as claimed by the letter writers to me, even by the stretch of the most perverted imagination, force or encourage communism in Australia? Does it threaten freedom of worship? Does it threaten the family structure? Do the people who are whipping up this frenzy understand what social engineering means? Will the Minister tell me what it means? Does the Bill bring this about? Is the Bill of Rights being opposed by hypocrites?

—On a point of order, Mr President: A little earlier in Question Time a point of order was taken by Senator Puplick about anticipating discussion, and you ruled that point of order out of order. I raise the same point of order under standing order 99 with respect to some of the specific parts of the question asked by Senator Chipp. We have on the Notice Paper a discussion of the human rights Bill and Senator Chipp is asking a series of quite specific questions about the effect of the Bill. He is asking the Minister to say whether the effect of the Bill is this, or this or this. I suggest that in the form of question there is a clear request to the Minister to anticipate matters which will be under discussion in the Senate probably later today, but certainly within the next few days. I suggest that the specific questions that are being asked are precisely the sort of issues that will be the subject of debate, or some at least of them no doubt will be the subject of debate, and I ask you to rule the question or those parts of the question out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President: I am bringing to notice the distorted, lying campaign raised by certain people to distort the debate that will take place in this chamber. I am not talking about the debate or the Bill per se, but about the campaign that is being waged outside this chamber. I have in my hand, for example, a paper from the Australian Festival of Light written by a J. K. Bowen, BA, LLB, a barrister at law who says this, in short:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Bill appears likely to offer nothing but harm to the ordinary law abiding decent and hard working citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask Senator Chipp to address his remarks to the point of order.
—On the point of order, I want some light thrown on to this distorted campaign that is being aided and abetted by members of this Parliament before the Bill is debated in this chamber.

—Order! On the point of order, as I understand it from Senator Chipp's question, he was raising allegations or remarks contained in correspondence that had been written concerning the Bill and in that respect I think he is entitled to ask his question. However, I suggest that he should be careful concerning the detail in his question as regards the matters that are in the Bill. In allowing the point of order, I would ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General to pay heed to my remarks so that he will not go outside the relevant standing order. I would ask Senator Chipp to bring his question to a conclusion.

—Thank you, Mr President. Is the Bill of Rights being opposed by those who support the most outrageous gerrymander in the Western world in Queensland, which allows a government to be returned with a vote of only 35 per cent of the people--
—What about the preferences, you--
—Order! Senator Chipp, will you ignore the interjections and get on with your question? I would remind Senator Chipp that the question is getting very long and I ask him to bring it to a conclusion.
—One is not interrupted often by the original missing link. The vote is much lower than that gained by President Marcos of the Philippines.
—I would ask Senator Gareth Evans in giving his answer to heed the ruling I have given on the point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that Government Ministers have been receiving letters and other communications on the Bill of Rights. Indeed, I have been receiving them personally for about the last 10 years. Although the Government has received a great deal of support for the proposed Bill, it has to be acknowledged that a great many of the letters we have been receiving are, I believe, properly characterised in the terms identified by Senator Chipp. To capture perhaps some of the flavour of this correspondence, may I indicate a couple of the kinds of missives which have recently come to my attention. One is in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Dear Senator, I don't like the sound of the Bill of Rights.
I object because of Article 21: `Any person who is arrested shall be informed of the reason of the arrest'.
Yours sincerely.
Another one, which perhaps indicates that we proponents of legislation cannot be relied upon to be entirely objective, reads:

It is noteworthy that the vast majority of subversives who are the main energisers of this Bill and the ID card lead unsatisfying sexual lives and show it in unsatisfying married lives, if ever they get round to that formality.

There are many more illustrations of this kind, Mr President, but I do not want to trespass on your patience. I am not aware of the precise source of all the serious misconceptions about the Bill that exist, but it is no doubt true that those afraid to protect the basic rights and freedoms of Australians would be interested in propagating such ill-informed beliefs.

The honourable senator has identified some of the worst prevailing misconceptions about the Bill. It does not force communism into Australia, and I have no idea how anyone can be led to that perception. It does not threaten worship, nor does it in any way threaten family structure, nor can it be associated in any way with social engineering, whatever the understanding of that term as it is employed by our various correspondents. It does not threaten. It does not do anything other than provide expressly that every man and woman has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex, quite exclusively. Yet we still hear allegations, as Senator Chipp has said, that the Bill allows or encourages homosexual marriage. Far from the Bill threatening freedom of worship or the family structure, it will embody for the first time in Australia's history a general protection of the right to adopt and manifest a religion, a general prohibition on government discrimination based on religion, and recognition of the natural and fundamental role of families in our society.

I shall not trespass any further into the subject matter of the Bill. I think the truth of the matters I am asserting is well enough apparent to sensible members of this chamber. Of course, Senator Chipp is correct in pointing, as he finally did, to the hypocrisy of many of those opposing the Bill. I can be as confident as he appears to be that those who support and indeed tend to rely on massive gerrymanders are exactly the kind of people whom one would expect to be lined up against the Bill, which protects the voting rights, among many other basic rights, of the people of Australia. I assure Senator Chipp and the Senate that the Government simply will not be swayed by misrepresentations and falsehoods of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy to table the papers from which he has quoted, in particular the documents about which he was so disparaging, particularly the first letter which seemed to me, as I heard it, to contain a perfectly sensible statement of principle. I would ask him to table those papers.
—Order! Does the Minister table those documents?

—On the understanding that Senator Chaney regards as a perfectly sensible statement of principle that people ought not to be informed of the reasons for their arrest, I am very happy to table the papers. I do so in conjunction with Senator Chaney's contribution.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Could the Minister advise the Senate of the current state of proposals to transfer nursing education from hospital schools to colleges of advanced education in Queensland? Further, how has the Queensland Government's response to Commonwealth initiatives on this issue compared to other States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all States, except Queensland, the transfer of nurse education from hospital schools of nursing to colleges of advanced education is either under way or planned in the near future. As Senator Black will know, nurse education has traditionally been a State responsibility. The Commonwealth in these transfers offered to assist the States with the transfer of provision of $1,500 indexed per student, plus tertiary education assistance for eligible students. In addition, the Government has committed a further $7.3m for nurse education and retraining, and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations will administer an extra $4m for the retraining of nurses.

ANSWER.PARA: All States have submitted proposals under these programs, with the exception of Queensland. It is significant that one of the reasons given by the Queensland Minister for not putting in a proposal is the requirement that employers in fact make a contribution in this scheme. Clearly, the Queensland Government as the main employer, is just not interested in making any contribution to the training or retraining-which is more important-of nurses in Queensland. However, the Federal Government is willing, and my colleagues Senator Ryan and Dr Blewett are always willing, to continue negotiations with Queensland on the matter of nurse education because we believe, as does the nursing profession, that educated nurses will enhance the status of nursing and, what is more important, will improve the quality of health care in Australia. We will continue to negotiate while the Queensland Government resists change of this type. However, I suppose that eventually, even if the existing Queensland Government stays in power, the Queensland Government will have to catch up with the rest of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the light of a likely 1985-86 balance of payments figure that will easily top $12 billion, does the Government not agree with Mr Bernie Fraser, the head of the Federal Department of the Treasury, that the tight monetary policy pursued by the Government through Reserve Bank activity in the market-place `has had its day'? Is this not an indication that its attempts to keep the Australian dollar steady have failed? In view of the fact that, despite an occasional rally, the Australian dollar has remained close to a trade weighted index figure of 60 since November, does the Government agree that, if the dollar remains at this level or falls further, it should renegotiate the prices and income accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to combat the resulting inflationary effects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the key features of this Government's economic management has been the historic agreement on prices and incomes with the trade union movement which is embodied in the accord. I would have thought that now, after nearly three years of those arrangements, most commentators would recognise the success of the accord in terms of overall economic strategy. Mr Fraser's comments contain no new revelations about the current account deficit or possible policy settings. He emphasised in his speech, as I understand, that he believed that the Government's policies would be successful in turning around the current account deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has never, at any stage, precluded the possibility of further discussions and negotiations relating to the accord, nor has the trade union movement. On the basis of a successful period of economic management, in which the accord has been a centrepiece, there is no current plan or proposal to seek any renegotiation of the accord. At an appropriate time last year, when the first impact of the devaluation was felt, it is well known that the Government entered into a series of negotiations with the trade union movement about the provisions of the accord and the possibility of discounting the effects of a devaluation. This arrived at a result which, it is anticipated will produce discounting in the current wage case. On the basis of that historical performance, if it becomes appropriate at any stage-the Government at the moment does not believe that it will-the Government would be prepared to enter into further discussions with the trade union movement. No such plans are currently in the offing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Leader of the Government: What point would the trade deficit need to reach before the Government considered it necessary to re-enter negotiations with the ACTU?

—That is a silly question. I cannot answer it, and nobody in his right mind would anticipate that I could. That is a matter for judgment by the Government in the light of a whole range of circumstances. We have not operated at any stage on the basis of some sort of check list of desirable economic performance indicators chalked up somewhere by the Liberals to see how we are going. We will never do that. That is a matter for consideration at the appropriate time. The Opposition must not be impatient about these things.

—Has the Minister for Education seen the article in the latest Bulletin which outlines the recommendations of the report of the Victorian Education Department's Task Force on Peace Education? Does the Government intend to alter its approach to peace education in the light of the recommendations of this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.
