TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have explained to the Senate previously, in answer to earlier inquiries, that our Government has taken a very careful and thorough approach to developing material suitable to be used in schools where those schools wish to incorporate the study of peace into their curriculum. When we first came to office, I asked the Curriculum Development Centre of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, which we re-established, to assess and investigate what was available in terms of peace study curriculum throughout Australia. It did that. Following that, and upon submission from various education authorities, the CDC funded two major pilot programs concerning peace education, or education for peace, one being carried out by the New South Wales Department of Education and one being carried out by the Victorian Catholic education system. Both of those pilot studies are just about complete. The Curriculum Development Centre will be considering their results at its next meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: I have made a number of speeches on the subject of peace education in which I have made it quite clear that, while our Government wishes to facilitate and support schools or teachers who wish to incorporate the study of peace into their curriculum, we do not have any particular view on how that should happen. We do not, for example, advocate the development of a new subject called peace studies. We believe that, as issues of peace and issues surrounding peace, such as the possibility of nuclear war, are of such concern to young people, it is appropriate that the Government respond in a positive and helpful way to assist young people and their teachers to investigate these subjects in a proper and scholarly fashion. I am pleased to note that the Victorian Government similarly has taken a constructive approach to this matter. I have not yet had time to study its report, but I expect that it will be along similar lines to the approach undertaken by the Commonwealth.

I think it is very important for those who want to slip easily into unfair and ill-informed criticisms of this development to remember that our response is a response to concerns expressed by young people. Any survey done of the attitudes of young people in recent years has shown that the matter of peace, of the security of their future, is something they always nominate as being of major concern to them. If we were to ignore that concern and were not to provide some assistance to teachers to deal with that concern, I think we would be failing in our responsibility, particularly in this all important Year of Peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the Transport Workers Union in the Australian Capital Territory has imposed a series of restrictive practices that prevent the use of more than 62 concrete agitator trucks to deliver an estimated 350,000 cubic metres of concrete this year, which is almost half the number of trucks which delivered a lesser amount of concrete eight years ago when 123 trucks delivered 315,000 cubic metres of concrete. Is the Minister aware that, if one is an owner-driver of a concrete truck in the Australian Capital Territory, this monopoly practice will enable one to gross in excess of $110,000 a year? Is he aware that the Builders Labourers Federation and the TWU have imposed bans in the Australian Capital Territory that require all trucks on building sites to be unloaded only by members of their respective unions? Finally, I ask: Does the Government propose taking any action to rectify this outrageous monopolistic practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Lewis will be surprised to learn that I did not know any of those things, at least until a few minutes ago when I received a note from the Minister on the matter. I will refer the matter to the Minister to see whether he wishes to add anything to what I have to say. I think I should make a few comments. The figure of $110,000 a year which Senator Lewis referred to, even if correct-I am not in a position to say whether it is-ought to be seen in the context that it is the return for quite a substantial capital investment and cash operating costs, as well as a return for the labour of the driver. It is in no sense comparable with wages.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think it is quite accurate to call this practice a monopoly. If it has been accurately described by Senator Lewis, it is an occupation into which entry is restricted. That may or may not be a good thing but it is certainly not unique. For example, in Senator Lewis's State the quantity of milk which can be sold is laid down by regulation and nobody who does not have a milk quota is allowed to sell milk at all. The same can be said for eggs and taxi licence plates in the Australian Capital Territory, and probably in every other capital city in Australia, too, for all I know.

Restricted entry, the purpose of which is to maintain prices above those which are likely to have prevailed in a free market situation, may or may not be deplorable. Judgments about that are usually made in accordance with whether the people who are making the judgments benefit or lose from them but that situation certainly is not unique. It is by no means restricted to this industry.

The only other comment I want to make at this stage relates to the third part of the question which Senator Lewis asked and that was about the requirement that only members of the BLF or the TWU unload trucks. Senator Lewis may have his view on that matter, but it is not an unusual practice for certain tasks to be designated to, or reserved for, members of particular unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to his comment during Question Time yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition is advocating policies that throw away anything up to $1 1/2 billion in revenue and spend an extra $1 1/2 billion revenue via that irresponsible shopping list of promises he has made and that these policies would lead to `a blow out in the deficit of the order of $3 billion or $4 billion'.
—Get your facts straight.

—That is a direct and accurate quote from Hansard. Will the Minister provide the Senate with further details of these proposals which would add substantially to Government spending or would substantially cut Government revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know, Senator Cook has quoted accurately what I said yesterday. I have one amendment to make, however. The statement was qualified by a prior statement that the list I presented was by no means exhaustive. I want to amend the figures which I gave yesterday of around $1.5 billion being added to the deficit because of expenditure increases and another $1.5 billion being added because of tax relief promises. That was a quite serious understatement because if all the promises that have been made by the Opposition over the last three years on tax reductions and expenditure increases were to be implemented, the deficit would blow out by more than $5 billion. In other words, the deficit would be even higher than the prospective deficit of $9.6 billion which this Government inherited from Mr Howard's last Budget. If the hypothetical Howard Budget were to be put together now the actual deficit would be even higher than that.

ANSWER.PARA: I can give a few details-for example, the Opposition's policy on income splitting. Granted it is open to some interpretation but the way in which it is most commonly presented is that the Opposition would allow any couple to divide their income equally for taxation purposes and pay tax accordingly. The cost of that in 1984 was $1,800m; the cost today would be at least $1,900m. The child care rebates promised by the Opposition would cost the revenue $180m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have not sought to take a point of order on the fact that the Minister for Finance cannot comment on any policy that might be announced by the Opposition, but he is misquoting those policies. Those policies, as announced for the election, clearly indicated that there would be a phasing in of the various policy objectives, including those to which he has referred, and, in particular, income splitting. That was specifically costed during the election campaign and limits were placed on it. This is a total misrepresentation of the Opposition's position.
—There is no point of order. I ask the Minister for Finance to be as brief as possible in his answer.

—Certainly, Mr President. Within the next few days I intend to issue a comprehensive list of the irresponsible spending and taxation policies of the Opposition parties and the effect that those policies, if implemented, would have on the deficit. So today I am giving only a sample. The Alice Springs-Darwin railway would add some $600m to outlays. Admittedly this would be over a period of years. The jewel in Mr Howard's crown is the off the top of the head policy he announced a few months ago that young recipients of unemployment benefit should be required to attend tertiary institutions for at least three days a week in order to receive that benefit. The cost of that, assuming they all attended technical and further education institutions where per capita costs tend to be lower than they are in other tertiary institutions, would be an additional $600m per annum to outlays.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the 3 per cent productivity increase included in the accord mark II is based on Australian Council of Trade Union determinations? If not, on what basis has the Government determined this increase? How can this figure be predetermined before a case has even been considered by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Does the Government consider that itself and the ACTU are in contempt by pre-empting any decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of a 3 per cent productivity increase which would cost in the order of $4 billion to $6 billion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just contemplating the alleged costs which Senator Parer gave. Certainly the figure of $6 billion is much too high; I suspect the figure of $4 billion is also too high even if the 3 per cent increase were spread across all wage earners in one hit. It should be borne in mind that the cost to employers of a productivity increase of that size is less than the cost of an equivalent wage increase because there are no add-on costs, as is the case with wages.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer referred to a determination of 3 per cent and asked whether that figure was determined by the ACTU. Frankly, I do not know. I will ask Mr Willis whether he has anything to say about that; but I do not believe that the use of that sort of term is appropriate in these circumstances. A judgment was made by the ACTU and the Government together that, spread over a period of two years commencing July 1986, a figure of about 3 per cent for productivity increases would be an appropriate alternative to a wages claim for productivity gains. Ultimately, as Senator Parer suggested, the Arbitration Commission will either endorse that assessment which has been made jointly by the Government and the ACTU or it will make its own assessment. The arrangement or agreement between the Government and the ACTU is that the Government would support a productivity claim of that size spread over the two years commencing July 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the derelict and vandalised state of Veterans Park in the national capital, a park which is meant to be a place of remembrance for those who died in the wars after the Second World War in South East Asia, particularly the 424 Australians killed in Vietnam? Has the Minister any plans for refurbishing and developing that site so that it provides a fitting remem- brance to the many Australians who gave their lives in those conflicts?

—I do recall Senator Tate asking me a question about this last year. I am aware of the fact that subsequent to that the Department of Territories gave the developer of block 3 section 26 in the city permission to use part of the Veterans Park as a staging area for the construction of a building. The National Capital Development Commission intends to upgrade the park following the completion of the building, which, unfortunately, has fallen behind its schedule, with a contribution being made by the developer towards the costs of such upgrading. Whilst it is not expected that the building will be completed before the end of April, the NCDC has indicated that the task of reconstructing or upgrading the park should be completed by October or September of this year. The work will include the installation of a water fountain, flagpole and plaques honouring those servicemen who served in Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. Advance trees will be planted in order to make up for the lost time as a result of the usage of the park, and extensive landscaping will be undertaken. The NCDC has also taken steps to extend the park through to Mort Street, so the net result will be a much improved addition to Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What does the Government propose to do with respect to its defence co-operation program for the Philippines Army in the light of the Cooksey report? Has the Government considered the argument that the only way the communist New People's Army will be defeated will be by the actions of a reformed Philippine Army, and that a valid case therefore exists for continued support by Australia to the training of the Philippines Army on the proper, professional and ethical base which has characterised our past support?

—I think, on balance, it would be appropriate if I referred that matter to the Minister for Defence to seek a considered reply from him. There is much that I could say about the defence co-operation program with the Philippines, and certainly I could make the comment, which has been made often enough before by the Minister for Defence, that the Government would not accept any proposals under that program which threatened human rights. What our response will be in the light of the Cooksey report to which Senator MacGibbon refers, which I am not sure has yet been made officially public, is something that the Government has yet to determine, but I will seek a response and let the honourable senator know.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister therefore inferring that previous Australian aid training programs for the Philippine Army have lacked respect for human rights?
—I am not inferring anything of the kind. I have no idea what tortured cells lurking in particular back corners of Senator MacGibbon's brain led him to make such an allegation.
—Order! Before I call Senator Coleman, I am sure all honourable senators join with me in wishing her a warm welcome back to the chamber.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to correspondence directed to honourable senators from Michael Tooth, President of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, in which he has included an assessment that 40,000 farmers will be affected by the quarantining of farm losses? Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of that assessment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did receive such a letter, addressed `Dear Senator', from which I assume it was received by all senators. It evidently was received by a number of senators, anyway. It was a covering letter which enclosed photocopies of the front page of a publication known as `Farm Investment Letter', which is published by Primary Investors Pty Ltd. It said, among other things:

ANSWER.PARA: In FIL's view, the National Farmers Federation appears closest to the mark when it says that 25 per cent of farmers (about 40,000) will be hurt by the tax proposals to go before the Federal Parliament in February.
The tax proposals referred to are the quarantining of farm losses. It continued:
The NFF figuring is based in grassroots analysis by country accountants, not on a rather idiotic sampling of tax information used by BAE and Treasury.

I do not know whether the National Farmers Federation did in fact assert what this publication claims the national Farmers Federation asserted, but the assertion made in that publication was clearly endorsed by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association when it sent the covering letter.

I make these comments. For a farmer to be hurt by the quarantine provisions, he must both have off-farm income in excess of $20,000 and be operating a tax loss farm. In other words, if the claim is true, something more than 25 per cent of farmers, and probably a much greater percentage, are in receipt of off-farm incomes in excess of $20,000. If that were true, I think it is inescapable that at least an equal number would be in receipt of off-farm incomes of between, say, $10,000 and $20,000. So we would have reached the point where between 25 per cent and 40 per cent of farmers-or possibly 50 per cent if these assertions are correct-would have to be in receipt of off-farm incomes of $20,000, and the overwhelming majority of farmers in receipt of off-farm incomes of at least $10,000, and the greater part of those off-farm incomes in excess of $20,000.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimate of net farm income for this financial year is $6,700, and it is important to note, as I mentioned on Tuesday, that that figure is certainly not comparable to wages, because it does not include any allowance for what should be imputed as income received by farmers and not received by other groups. It is agreed by anybody who knows anything about this that that figure, to be compared legitimately with wages, needs to be increased, although there is less agreement on the amount of the increase. Nevertheless, the $6,700 figure is used by the LGPA-or I understood it was used by the LGPA-as a claim for financial assistance to farmers because of the very low incomes. I therefore find it surprising, to say the least, that the LGPA should be backing an assertion that off-farm incomes are of the size and of the prevalence which is asserted in that publication. If that claim is to be accepted as correct, it must cast doubts over the legitimacy of any needs-based claims for financial assistance to farmers based on the estimated $6,700 average farm income, to which has to be added some imputed income and the alleged very high and prevalent off-farm incomes which the LGPA explicitly endorses.

I am puzzled by that and I have therefore written to the President of the LGPA seeking his comments on what appears to me to be a serious discrepancy between a claim allegedly made in this publication, by the National Farmers Federation, about the effect of quarantining farm losses on farmers and the other inconsistent claim made by the same organisation that farmers' incomes are extremely low and farmers therefore are entitled to very favourable consideration from the Government for financial assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. The Minister for Social Security said in the House of Representatives yesterday that his Department hoped to save about $90m by 1988 in a new program for limiting social security overpayments; that is, an average of $30m for each of the next three years. How did he arrive at this figure and how is it credible when the Minister has claimed that the net level of overpayments detected by his Department last financial year amounted to less than $20m in one year and should be expected to fall further? Also, will there be any increase in the number of Department staff employed to detect social security fraud as a result of the new measures? If so, how many?

—As Senator Teague says, the Minister for Social Security did make a statement yesterday about overpayments and he did quote some figures in putting forward his proposals to cut down the amount of overpayments and fraud in the Department of Social Security. He does expect the amount of savings to be generated to be of the order of $90m by 1988. I think that was the figure quoted in the statement, which I have only partly read. It was my understanding, from a reading of that statement, that the net level, as the Minister said, of overpayments detected by the Department of Social Security last financial year fell below $20m, but he also pointed out that there was still some $76m in accumulated overpayments and, in passing, compared this to the $2.9 billion which is outstanding in taxation. In the statement, from memory, the Minister did not give details as to how the estimate of the calculated savings would be made. I certainly cannot estimate it off the top of my head. I will seek accurate information from him and give it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. In referring that question to the Minister for Social Security, could there be a breakdown of from which benefits and allowances the overpayments will be saved, which will amount to $90m?
—I will seek that detail. I am sure it must be available in the estimates that have been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Gareth Evans read from two letters which were addressed to Senator Chipp and which related to the Bill of Rights. When I asked for the tabling of those letters I indicated that I thought one of the letters contained a statement of principle with which I agreed. I have checked what was said as against what was in the letter. I make no complaint about the fact that Senator Evans read part only of the letter to which I was referring. I would like to quote what that part was and to explain my attitude to it. According to my note, Senator Evans read out:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator,
I do not like the sound of the Bill of Rights.
I object because of Article 21. Any person who is arrested should be informed of the reason of the arrest.
Yours sincerely.
In fact the letter is a longer letter than that. I will read the same passages but I will put in the additional parts which make it more sensible. It said:
I object because of Article 21. `Any person who is arrested shall be informed of the reason of the arrest'.
I would like to make it quite clear to the Senate that I regard article 21 as a sensible and, indeed, unexceptionable statement of principle which I support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next business I draw the attention of honourable senators to the length of some of the questions that have been asked in the last day or two and I also draw attention to the length of the answers that have been given by Ministers. Some of the lengthy questions, naturally, involve lengthy answers. Already there are a number of senators who have not had the opportunity to get themselves on the record since the Parliament resumed sitting. I urge all honourable senators to give consideration to the length of their questions and to the necessity to ask supplementary questions, and I would also remind Ministers of the desire on their part to be as brief as possible in providing the answers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 13 February, from Senator Peter Baume:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move `That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth Constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth Constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights.

It is urgently necessary, for the sake of the Australian community, that the Labor Government abandon its present commitment to use Commonwealth constitutional powers to achieve uniform national Aboriginal land rights as it has set out in its policies. It might be worthwhile examining some of the expectations which the Australian Labor Party raised before it came into Government, in its policy documents and in the statements by some of its spokespersons over the years. I remind honourable senators first of the actions of Senator Susan Ryan when in Opposition. Senator Ryan, as the Labor Party spokesperson on Aboriginal Affairs--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very good one.

—`A very good one', says Senator Gareth Evans. I imagine that he is committed to uniform national Aboriginal land rights as well. Senator Ryan pledged herself to Aboriginal land rights in 1983. She promised that the first action, the immediate action, of a Labor government on election would be the enactment of land rights legislation. Of course, it has not happened. The Labor Party promised that legislation when it was canvassing votes. Senator Ryan went out and bought votes with the promise and has not delivered. Senator Ryan criticised the State of Western Australia. In January 1981 Senator Ryan said in a Press release:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Western Australian Government is not prepared to protect these rights then the Federal Government has no moral or constitutional alternative but to legislate to protect them.

Those were Senator Ryan's words then. Those were her views about the place of the Commonwealth then. They are the views enshrined in Labor Party policy. They are the views which the Labor Party put to the Aboriginal community. We have a situation now where the Western Australian Government is not prepared to enact Aboriginal land rights and where Senator Susan Ryan, consistent with the statement she made in 1981, should be calling on her colleagues and her Government to enact the kind of uniform national Aboriginal land rights which she was seeking then. Indeed, in August 1981 the honourable senator came into this place with her own Bill to bring down land rights in one of the States. She produced the legislative framework. We do not want to hear any argument that the delay has been due to any legislative difficulty. The Government was able to draft legislation in Opposition and Senator Ryan was able to promise then that uniform national land rights legislation would be the first action of a Labor Government. Of course, it has not been.

The policy document of the Australian Labor Party makes clear its commitment. It makes clear its desire that Aboriginal people should have secure land tenure. As I will say later, we agree with that. It says that it should be done by the States, and I go on to quote the Labor Party document:
. . . where this is not introduced-
that is, by the States, it will-
use Commonwealth constitutional powers and legislation to achieve these objectives.

That is the policy of the Australian Labor Party-a policy promised before election and not implemented since. The Labor Party has made no secret of the fact that it would be prepared to override the States, the rights of the States and the actions of the States. Its promise was to do so immediately upon election. Where are we now? It is three years on and we have not even seen from the Labor Party any sign of the legislation which it promised or about which it trumpeted so much.

We have seen some progress. We have seen the Labor Party produce what it calls its preferred national land rights model. I will have a bit more to say about its preferred national land rights model in a moment because that model has been rejected by everyone. We have seen the Labor Party talking about five principles to be observed, but in relation to the promises which were made, and made so clearly, we have seen no action. Indeed, the Government policy is now in disarray. The Australian Labor Party is in disarray on land rights.

We know the policy. I have indicated what it contains. It is clearly wrong-headed. We knew it was wrong before the Labor Party went to the election. We have taken a different approach and continue to take a different approach. But the Labor Party policy remains. Whether in the form of its preferred model or as a policy document it has been rejected by the Aboriginal community. The Aboriginal community said that the preferred model was a sellout of Aboriginal interests. Its members said so on national radio and television. I have the statements. I will not bore honourable senators with them but they referred to the policy as inadequate, as a sellout and as conferring fewer rights upon Aboriginal people than does the Northern Territory legislation which was introduced by the Fraser Government and for which many honourable senators on this side of the chamber voted and worked. The Labor Party's preferred options have been rejected by Aboriginal people not once, but many times. Indeed, the National Aboriginal Conference, while it still existed--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to that?

—Indeed; while it existed it was invited to set up working parties to deal with the Government. The NAC voted to boycott a steering committee meeting because it believed that the Government was guilty of inadequate action and bad faith. It made it quite clear that the Government, quite apart from its rhetoric, was offering something weaker than what the Liberals had introduced and implemented. This approach by the Labor Party has been rejected by State colleagues. One has to think only of the Labor Premier of Western Australia. Mr Burke said: `I'll quit if land rights legislation is brought in'. That is what he thinks of Senator Ryan's and the Federal Party's approach to land rights. He would rather resign as Premier of Western Australia than have anything to do with what those opposite and people like them have proposed as a solution for the land tenure problems of Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: This policy has been rejected by the community. Single-handedly the Australian Labor Party at Federal level has managed to turn around the opinion polls. At the time we lost government the general acceptance level of some form of land rights was about 80 per cent. The latest opinion polls show that the community is dismayed and about 80 per cent oppose land rights. That is indeed an achievement from people like Senator Ryan who promised so much and delivered nothing to the Aboriginal people. News- papers have reported today that the Labor Caucus has demanded that the Federal Labor Party implement the policy of land rights to which the Party is committed and which it has refused to touch.

TALK.START.PARA: —After a State election in Western Australia.

—As my colleague says, after that election. The Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Charles Perkins, spoke out today. Being a loyal officer of the Australian Public Service he would not speak on his own account. He would speak only to echo government policy so he called for land rights to be enacted this year. `Act now on land rights' says Perkins. Is he speaking for the Government? Mr Gerry Hand spoke out asking that the Party adhere to its land rights policy. Today on the AM program Mr Gayler, the honourable member for Leichhardt and Chairman of the Caucus Committee, demanded that the Government start to implement the policy and get on with the job. At the same time, the Secretary of the Labor Party in Western Australia made it quite clear that such action is not on and is not available to the Government.
—How long have they been in government now?

—It has been three years. This was to be the first and immediate action of a Labor government upon election. Its whole approach to land rights was rejected even by some of its Caucus colleagues. I have a Press clipping in which Mr Graeme Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, had something to say about the inadequacies of the policies which his party proposed when it went to the Australian people-rejected even within the Federal Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke has refused over the past year to authorise a public awareness campaign which was sought by Mr Holding to make available information on land rights. It is an open secret that Mr Hawke blocked the allocation of money which was necessary to mount that campaign. That is his commitment. Mr Hawke promised to fix the matter when he went to Western Australia. During the 1984 election campaign, Mr Hawke backed down on a central part of the Labor Party policy in relation to the mining veto. We think that the policy is wrong anyway but all I am trying to do is to illustrate that it has been a disaster for the Labor Party. It has been a disastrous performance by the Labor Government. We know that there have been broken promises to Aborigines across the board. It might be worth reminding honourable senators of something said by Mr Pat Dodson at the National Press Club recently when he was talking about the Government and its dealings with Aborigines. He said:

The fact is that at no stage have Aboriginal people or their representatives had any chance to make any meaningful contribution to the development of the Government's preferred national land rights model.
That is terrific. Aborigines are the people involved. They have had no chance to make a contribution. Mr Dodson continued:
The Minister's supposed consultations with the now defunct land rights steering committee demonstrates clearly the shallowness of his undertakings about consultation and negotiation.

He said other things about the Government's failure to honour its promise of adequate consultation and structures for consultation. It abandoned the National Aboriginal Conference, the only national consultative body which the Aborigines had and it has done it at the time when Aboriginal land rights have moved back to centre stage and when at more than any other time Aboriginal people required a national voice with which to deal with government. The NAC went leaving Aborigines with no single national voice to talk for them.

The substance of this motion is that we believe that the Labor Party should move away from its commitment to a national land rights model. That is what it has been pushing in theory for years. Of course, it is what it has avoided doing. But it is not about doing; it is only about talking before elections and making promises when it wants votes then doing nothing about it. It has had legislation ready, has promised immediate action and has stated exactly what it will do. Our policy is different. It is clear. Our record is clear. While the Labor Party talks we act and implement. Two major pieces of land rights legislation in this nation have genuinely advantaged and advanced Aboriginal people. They were implemented by a Liberal National Party Federal government and a Liberal Party State government in South Australia. The two Acts are the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which was passed by this Parliament under a Liberal-National Party government, and which two of us here had the privilege of administering as Ministers, and the South Australian Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Act, introduced and passed by a Liberal State government. Our record is one of achievement and of actually putting land rights in place.

We believe that the approach to secure land tenure will differ in different parts of the country. The Northern Territory, where 25 per cent of the population is Aboriginal and where many traditional communities exist, that calls for one legislative model. In the light of experience that legislation requires some amendment but the core of the legislation is still appropriate for the Northern Territory. In South Australia, which has a different situation, a different model of legislation is required. Of course, a Liberal Government put that legislation in place. In New South Wales we have seen the Wran Labor Government put into place what is a mockery of land rights legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It amounts to nothing.

—It has amounted to nothing. It has not advantaged the community and it has brought land rights into disregard. We have the record. But our policy still states that we oppose uniform land rights strongly, not out of some blind ideology but because we could foresee what has happened. We opposed the attempt to impose upon Australian communities and Australian States any uniform national model of land rights. It will be disastrous for the whole movement for secure land tenure. It will be disastrous for the efforts to advantage Aboriginal Australians and it will be disastrous for any sense of accommodation between different groups in Australian communities on this difficult matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the States have a responsibility to meet their obligations to the Aboriginal people. The States will independently adopt policies which will seek to take account of the particular social, economic and cultural needs of their Aboriginal communities in respect of access to and tenure of land. We believe that our colleagues in the States will move. When I was Minister we had some difficult negotiations with the State of Queensland. But that State, as a result of negotiation, was prepared to move on the issue of tenure in relation to the Aboriginal reserves in that State. I suggest to Senator Ryan that, with the best will in the world, a uniform national land rights model would be the very worst thing that could be offered to the State of Queensland.

This Government's policy has been wrong from the beginning. Senator Ryan knows it has been wrong because she has not implemented the policy. I say to Senator Macklin, who I know supports the Government's policy, that Senator Ryan will not implement the policy and the Government will not implement it. The time has come for the Government to recognise that it has gone down a wrong track, a blind alley. It should re-examine its whole approach to the needs of Aboriginal people and recognise that the approach of its political opponents has been more successful, more productive, more positive and more beneficial to the Aboriginal people in Australia.

Our policy is clear; it is better and it is fair. Our policy will work and our legislation has worked. This Government has had no legislation. All we have had from this Government is rhetoric and betrayal. We have implemented land rights where Labor has not. We have dealt with the States; Labor threatened the States and, when any State has stood up to it, Labor has given in.

The history of this country shows that since white settlement most of the original settlers from Europe were given grants of Crown land. They received, as it were, land rights to enable them to establish themselves in Australia and to start their life in this country. The move to grant appropriate land tenure for Aboriginals, as has been contained in the Liberal-National Party Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act or as has been contained in the Pitjantjatjara land rights Act, is merely an attempt to give some Crown land in an appropriate fashion to Aboriginal communities for their benefit and for their advancement. We have been able to do so without dividing the community, as has been the case with the Government and its rhetoric.

The federalist approach to land rights is the only sensible approach-to recognise that we are a federation made up of a number of different autonomous governments and States. Let us consider the situation if, as Senator Ryan and her ideological colleagues wish to assert, the 1967 referendum gave the Commonwealth power to make laws in relation to Aboriginal land tenure. Land management and land tenure are State responsibilities. We could end up with a situation in which, if land tenure for whites were involved, it would be a State matter but, if land tenure for Aboriginals were involved and we listened to members of the Government, that would be a Federal matter. That is clearly ridiculous. For the sake of Aboriginal Australia and of national consensus, we urge the Government in recognising its abject failures to take note of this motion of urgency, to abandon its policies which have failed and to go down the more appropriate path, the one which endorses the Opposition's policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the chamber, the Government of Australia, have become very used to the confusion and internal fueding within the Liberal Party of Australia on all the major issues of our time, be they privatisation, industrial relations or land rights. There is never a single coherent view that emanates from the other side of the chamber. We have become very used to this yet, inured as we are to the confusion, contradiction and wrangling that has characterised the performance of the Liberal Party in opposition in the last three years, I am amazed to have heard what I have just heard from Senator Peter Baume. Even I was amazed to hear Senator Baume come out with so many contradictions and so many absurd claims and allegations as he has just done.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand, he has chosen to lecture us, the Commonwealth Government of Australia, about the meaning of the Constitution and to advise us to abandon constitutional responsibilities which reside in the Constitution because of the will of the Australian people. On the other hand, he has chosen to boast of the performance of his Party in respect of land rights when it was the Federal Government. On the one hand he says that we must leave these matters to the States and that we the Commonwealth have no role in this crucial issue of land rights. Yet, when we look at the State in which there have been the most recent attempts to legislate for land rights, Western Australia, what do we find? We had the very moderate, the very sensible and very cautious legislation put forward by the Burke Government and passed by the Burke Government in the lower House where the Burke Government is in control. What happened in the Upper House? The political colleagues of Senator Baume and Senator Chaney rejected that legislation. Of course, Senator Baume chooses to ignore that. He chooses to ignore the disgraceful performance of the Liberal Party in Western Australia on this issue.

Senator Baume, in his typically dishonest fashion, raised the fact that there is a lessening of public support for land rights. Of course, that is a matter of great concern to us. But what is the reason for it? The reason for it is the fearmongering, dishonest, disgraceful campaign waged by the Liberal Party of Western Australia and supported, of course, by the mining interests in that State. What does Senator Baume have to say about the performance of the Liberal Party in Western Australia? What will Senator Chaney have to say?

TALK.START.PARA: —If you sit down, I will start talking.

—Senator Chaney is offering to say something about it. I will be very interested to hear Senator Chaney's comments and his defence of the performance of his Party in Western Australia. I will be very interested to hear what Senator Chaney has to say about the action of his comrades in the upper House in Western Australia in rejecting the extremely moderate and cautious land rights legislation of the Burke Government. It is simply unacceptable to us and to the Australian public for the Liberal Party, which has not been able to find a single point of agreement on the land rights issue or any other major issue, to come in and lecture us about our lack of unity or coherence on this issue. I suggest to Senator Baume and Senator Chaney that it is the job of the Opposition to work out its position on land rights. On the one hand, there is a new shadow Minister-I think the third in three years-for Aboriginal Affairs.
—What is his name? He is an excellent bloke.

—Actually, I know what his name is. I had to check before this debate began. I would not have known it from any public performance or activism by him in this respect. Mr Connolly has said that he supports the official Liberal Party policy, which is to pursue land rights. Even Senator Baume and Senator Chaney cannot pretend that that view is shared by, for example, their comrade, Mr Sinclair, the Leader of their coalition party in the House of Representatives, who has said publicly in recent times that he is ashamed to have voted for the very Northern Territory land rights legislation about which Senator Baume was just boasting. The Leader of the coalition partner of the Liberal Party in the other place says he was ashamed to have voted for the Northern Territory land rights legislation. It is time that Senator Baume and Mr Sinclair were introduced to each other. I comment in passing that this is probably the first act about which Mr Sinclair has ever admitted shame.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we had the performance of the Western Australian Liberal Party and of Mr Hassell, who has actually been quoted in Melbourne as saying that his understanding of land rights-he was referring to the extremely moderate and cautious Burke proposals-was that people in the suburbs of Melbourne have to understand that their back yards could be affected as much as any in Western Australia. Mr Hassell said that publicly. Where was the brave retort from Senator Peter Baume then? Where was Senator Baume's proud claims that his Party has the greatest record in land rights of any party in this country? There was no response to that ludicrous, dishonest statement that the backyards of people in Melbourne were in danger because of something that might happen in Western Australia. I understand that Senator Chaney was similarly silent. It is one thing for them to come into this chamber, where there is a great deal of support for land rights, and boast about their record in government; it is another thing entirely to enter into public debate when their comrade from Western Australia says that the backyards of people in Melbourne are threatened by land rights in Western Australia. I would be much more impressed with Senator Baume's rhetoric and boasting if he chose to say a few things in a public place at a time--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Mr Hawke in Western Australia?

—I am pleased that Senator Chaney interjects by referring to our Prime Minister because it reminds me that I must correct one of the more spurious allegations made by Senator Peter Baume in the course of his remarks. Senator Baume alleged that the Prime Minister blocked funding of a public awareness program. I must put it on the record that that is wrong. Advertising campaigns are not approved or disapproved by the Prime Minister; they are subject to a ministerial committee's examination. That particular campaign has not yet been funded simply because of budgetary limitations. There was no intervention by the Prime Minister in the work of that ministerial committee. On the question of public awareness and public campaigns I simply repeat that it is not good enough for Senator Peter Baume-I can anticipate wearily what we will hear from Senator Chaney-to come into this place boasting and bragging about what they have done and what they are prepared to do when they were silent where it really matters, in the State of Western Australia, when there was an attempt to get the beginnings of a land rights program into legislation. They did nothing to correct the absurd claims of their own colleagues in that State.
—I actually opposed the Burke legislation.

—Senator Chaney is now saying that he opposed the Burke legislation. I am sure that he did. I am sure that he would in effect oppose any legislation in his State. The reason for that is not Senator Chaney's personal values in this matter, as I believe that Senator Chaney does support land rights; but he is powerless, he is impotent, in his own State. He is absolutely unable to persuade his State colleagues, such as Senator Crichton-Browne or the new senator from Western Australia, Senator Knowles. He is totally unable to persuade Liberals of that ilk to adopt a sensible, fair and just position on this issue. Therefore, any boasting or bragging in this place is just so much empty rhetoric. Because time is running out, I will not go through--
—You have plenty of time.

—I want to tell the honourable senator what we have been doing, since he refuses to acknowledge it. I could refer to the kind of comments made by Paul Everingham. People may ask `Paul who?', as well they might since he has virtually disappeared since he came into this Parliament. He used to be the Leader of the Northern Territory Government and used to say things about land rights which I am sure Senator Chaney and Senator Baume found immensely embarrassing when they were dealing with their sort of Liberal. We also have had the Leader of the Liberal Party in South Australia, Mr Olsen, applauding the act of the Bannon Government in extending the Pitjantjatjara land rights provisions to the Maralinga Aboriginal communities. Some Liberals do support land rights and are prepared to support them publicly but we do not have anything approximating a coherent and serious position in this respect from the Liberals and until we do lectures by the likes of Senator Baume and Senator Chaney on land rights are gratuitous to say the least.
—But what are you going to do?

—Before I proceed to tell the Senate what we are going to do, let me say what we have done. Senator Baume, in his usual fashion, decided to make a debate about land rights a debate about Senator Ryan. In some ways I am flattered by this attention but in other respects I think that it is fairly pointless. He suggested that since we have been in government we have taken no steps to implement the policies we developed in opposition. That is simply absurd. As every honourable senator will know, Mr Holding, our Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, immediately set about establishing consultation mechanisms, undertaking discussions with the States and working towards what I hope and expect will be achieved this year, that is, the implementation of our policy. I am sure that no Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has engaged in such thorough and intensive consultation with Aboriginal people throughout Australia as well as with other people who legitimately have interests in this matter.
—Why do they call it a sell-out?

—Senator Baume likes to parrot the comment that the preferred model is a sell-out. The preferred model is very similar to the Pitjantjatjara land rights legislation which 25 minutes ago was the subject of great boasting by Senator Baume. When he talks about the Pitjantjatjara land rights principles being something that people associated with him having achieved it is wonderful, but when they become the basis for our preferred model it is a sell-out. It is just another contradiction of the kind that we are so tired of hearing. Of course there has been lively discussion on the preferred model but I would like to hear from Senator Chaney as to which principle in the preferred model he takes exception to, which principle would he not like to see embodied in legislation in every State and perhaps in Federal legislation, because those principles are the very principles which have been implemented in the Pitjantjatjara and subsequent South Australian legislation. That procedure is still alive; it will come to fruition very soon. That preferred model has been discussed with every interest group throughout Australia, with every Aboriginal group and every other group that has a legitimate interest, and with State governments throughout Australia, and there has been progress. In the Northern Territory, for example, the one area which Senator Baume's legislation left unaddressed-the area of the dreadful need of Aboriginal people living on pastoral properties on their traditional land-is actively being addressed. During the period that Senator Chaney and Senator Baume were Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs, and before them their predecessor, Mr Viner, no progress was made to give land rights claims--
—It has progressed through the Northern Territory Government.

—Senator Kilgariff interjects that there has been progress through the Northern Territory Government. That has occurred following consultation and by agreement with us. There is now progress. We are now virtually at the point where those 3,000 or so most dispossessed Aboriginal people living on pastoral properties will be able to get secure title to their land, but that has come about through the efforts of Clyde Holding, our Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and through the process of consultation and the seeking of consensus which has been characteristic of our Government in this as in every other matter. In Queensland, for example, the deeds of grant have now been passed over to Aboriginal communities and that could only have happened with Commonwealth co-operation and with a commitment by the Commonwealth to allocate resources for the services needed in those communities. If we had done as Senator Peter Baume's motion suggests and refused entirely to accept any Commonwealth constitutional responsibility for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland, those deeds of grant would never have come into being because the Aboriginal Affairs Minister in the State of Queensland, Mr Katter, made it quite clear that his Government's willingness to proceed to this limited form of land rights depended upon active and extensive Commonwealth involvement. We have committed ourselves to that; we have resolved the questions relating to housing, servicing of those communities and so forth and as a result there is now progress in this area in Queensland.
—Following our policy. That is good.

—We are not following the policy. Here we go again. Senator Chaney says that we are following the former Government's policy but the policy which Senator Peter Baume has just enunciated for our benefit is a policy whereby everything is left to the States. Federalism was the theme insofar as there was a theme in Senator Baume's remarks. He said that everything must be left to the States.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a wonderful burst of rhetoric about how we are different States and different solutions were provided in different States. If we had left the situation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander reserves in Queensland entirely to that State-for instance, if we had followed Senator Peter Baume's prescription of getting out of this area entirely-there would have been no progress. We accept our constitutional responsibilities in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provided you do not do anything about that.

—I am not responsible for Senator Baume's ignorance in this or any other matter. It has certainly been a matter of lively debate in Queensland. For those of us who have a genuine interest in the advancement of Aboriginal and Islander people in that State it has been a matter of continuing interest that, with Commonwealth co-operation and support, we have now reached a stage where there has been some advance. I would not say that it was the ultimate in land rights, but there has been some advance in that State and there is now some security of tenure for Aboriginals and Torres Strait islanders in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: In South Australia, of course, the Bannon Government has extended the application of land rights legislation. The New South Wales Government has passed its own legislation and I disagree with Senator Peter Baume when he tries to deride and totally discount what has happened in that State. Everybody knows-certainly Senator Baume should know very well-that the matter of establishing appropriate land rights structures in the States that were colonised first, such as Victoria and New South Wales, is extremely complex. I must say it is a matter in which Labor governments in New South Wales and Victoria have not been assisted by the outrageous claims of the likes of Mr Hassell who has said; `Your backyard will be invaded by Aboriginals if there are land rights'. But that is the kind of complication we have to deal with.

We have had a destruction of tribal communities in those States and, of course, it is very much more difficult to achieve consensus and a workable model of land rights in New South Wales. But the New South Wales Government has certainly embarked upon this. Land is being handed over to land councils. Funds arising from that land rights legislation are now being made available to Aboriginal land councils throughout New South Wales and there is progress. Let us not pretend that the situation in New South Wales now, as a result of the New South Wales Government's legislation, is not better than the situation that prevailed before when there was no such legislation. In Victoria, similarly, there has been progress. The Framlingham community is about to get secure tenure of its land and, in many other respects, the issue of land rights has been considerably advanced during the period of the Cain Government.

Of course, all this adds up to a very clear picture. In each State of Australia where there has been a Labor government-except Western Australia-there has been a serious and an effective extension of land rights. In all these activities those States have been supported and assisted by the Commonwealth Government. In all those activities there would have been less progress if the Commonwealth Government had not been actively involved. The one State in which we have not been able to achieve any progress yet is Western Australia and the blame for that has to be sheeted home fairly and squarely to the Liberal Party of Western Australia. If the Liberal Party of Western Australia had permitted the Burke legislation to pass the upper House there would be land rights in Western Australia right now. Aboriginals in Western Australia would not be dispossessed as they are right now; they would be in possession of land. Because of treacherous behaviour of the Liberals in Western Australia that has not yet happened.

But the failure of the Liberal Party to support that moderate legislation is not the final word. It is not the end of the story about land rights in Western Australia. I predict that there will be agreement between our Government, the Burke Government and the Aboriginal people in Western Australia that will lead to Aboriginals in Western Australia owning their own land as has happened in other States. I simply say in conclusion: If Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney are serious in wishing to see a just and fair settlement of this issue, they should offer some constructive and helpful comments instead of grandstanding in the way that Senator Baume has chosen to do today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion we are debating today as a matter of urgency is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth Constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights.

I must admit to a dilemma in being able to vote on this motion because I do not perceive any commitment to use Commonwealth constitutional powers so I am not quite sure how one goes about abandoning them. Having returned from Western Australia where I was supporting the Australian Democrats candidates in that State I can say that we were the only Party to support land rights in that election and we suffered because of it. But we will continue to push that issue because we believe it to be a matter of justice. We do not intend taking the supine role that the Australian Labor Party has taken with regard to this or the hypocritical role that members of the Liberal Party of Australia have taken by referring to past glories and suggesting that, in future, nothing at all will occur.

I readily admit that, whereas the majority of white Australians are quite happy and support justice in terms of the provision of schools for children, hospitals for those who are sick and pensions for the elderly, in this area of justice there is no move whatsoever. Indeed, there is a gathering opinion opposed to it. That opinion has not just occurred, as was indicated by some of the previous speakers. It has been done quite deliberately and at a very high cost, not only in money terms but in terms of social cohesion in Australia. All that my Party is suggesting is that all Australians should recognise our common responsibility to provide Aboriginals with spiritual and material necessities for them to be able to live a full life in this their country. For the Aboriginal people themselves, in their own judgment, that means land. Without land the Aboriginal people will continue to be dependent upon handouts from the white community. There are no other benefits which are as crucial as this; none whatsoever. It is necessary to recognise that what we are talking about is not a legal gift. We are talking about a moral necessity.

It seems to me extraordinary that people in Australia are saying that the Aboriginals should forget about their past. For a people who have survived a holocaust we are urging on them to forget what happened to them in the past. But in other areas what do we say? It is interesting to note that more Aboriginals died in the defence of their land by white occupation than did our soldiers in World War I and II combined. We say to them: `Forget'. But for other glories and for other defence of our land, we say: `Lest we forget'. The hypocrisy reeks.

What we are looking at is a very simple and undeniable fact that, before the white European colonisers came, the Aboriginals, according to their own organisations and their own laws, occupied this entire continent and has sovereignty over it. For a variety of legal reasons we now have the ultimate absurdity in law in Australia that suggests-it has to suggest-that the Aboriginals invaded British territory. That is the interpretation that has to be given to the current law-an ultimate absurdity. If we do not hold that view we have to hold the view of prior sovereignty. There are no two other ways of going about it. We either hold that view-which is the current legal standing that the Aboriginals invaded British territory-or we have to accept their prior sovereignty. If we do, of course, we come to the situation which is currently the case in the United States of America. By a recent decision of the High Court, which has finally worked out the legal implications of that sovereignty, the Indian tribes in the United States not only have control over the land and proprietary rights over the minerals under the land but also the right to levy their own taxes on anybody who comes on that land, because they have been given recognition of their sovereign rights. That is what sovereignty means. So we go by the legal fiction that the Aboriginals invaded British Territory. I quote former Prime Minister Hughes at the end of World War I when in the Treaty of Versailles discussions he said:

No wrong without remedy. Whatever the nature of the wrong-whether to life, limb, health, property, liberty, of any other right-the wrong-doer must, as far as he can, make reparation for the wrong. As it is between individuals, so it must be between states. That is the reign of law; that is the principle of justice.

That is what ought to occur in Australia. What are we talking about, then, when we speak of land rights for Aboriginals? I would like to put very clearly, because it has not been put so far in this debate, what the Australian Democrats believe is the principle of land rights as it should apply to Australia. It is this, and I quote:

Where a traditional tribal community has continued to reside on its traditional land discharging its spiritual obligations with regard to that land, and that land has never been occupied by any other persons, that community is entitled to a legal title to that land in legal recognition of the fact that they have always lived on that land, land to which no other persons have any moral claim.
There are still tracts of land in every State to which that applies in which that has not been settled, with the exception of South Australia. Secondly:

Where a traditional tribal community has been moved from its traditional land and it is land to which no other persons have a moral claim, that community should be granted title to that land in restitution.
That has not occurred. Thirdly:

Where an Aboriginal community consists of people who have been moved from their traditional lands to make way for pastoral or other development and there is now no question of restoring to them their traditional land because other persons have subsequently maintained their own moral claims to the land by virtue of occupancy, labour and expenditure, that community is entitled to compensation.

I believe they are reasonable principles that ought to be accepted by reasonable people, but we do not have a reasonable debate on land rights in Australia today. We have an hysterical, hypocritical debate about land rights. It has become a boo word, a word to damn. I sat and watched television advertisements by the Liberal Party and by the Labor Party in Western Australia which said, `We recognise the problem in Western Australia and we pledge ourselves to do nothing about it'.

This Federal Government in particular has succumbed without a whimper to that campaign of self-interest. What has it done? It has refused to recognise and abide by the National Australian Labor Party policy. It has denied the right of Aboriginal people to proper consultation or negotiation. It has destroyed the only national voice of the Aboriginal people in this country. It has refused to accept the right of Aboriginal people to withhold consent and impose condit- ions for negotiations. It has rejected and put aside its obligations legally, constitutionally and morally to legislate on behalf of the Aboriginal people in Australia. The Hawke Government has said that it will not implement ALP policy and it intends to change drastically the only major operational national policy, that is the national land rights policy, and to water it down. We have a Labor Party government coming into power on a so-called pro-Aboriginal policy that is pledged now to destroy the only national piece of legislation that was introduced by a conservative government. How things have changed since 1983.

The Aboriginal people of Australia are not asking for charity-they do not want charity. We are moving towards 1988 which will be a bicentenary for Australians. As one Aboriginal said, `We celebrated our bicentenary aeons ago'. I wonder whether Aboriginals will have anything to celebrate after two parliaments led by the Australian Labor Party have failed to implement Australian Labor Party policy. Unfortunately, there are no Aboriginal members of either House of the Federal Parliament, so I would like to read from an Aborigine's view about what is going on because it makes a lot of sense. He said:

You would make a road, then explore and interfere with the place, bringing sickness upon us all. Then your doctors would come to operate on us, to chop us up-because there are great dangers and illnesses in places. We understand this-the need to be careful and not disturb the place. We want to live in a healthy place. This wouldn't be your way- you'd disturb and mess up the land. Then the spirits of the place will settle us all. You're too ignorant to know this. We Aborigines know these things, you're white people and we're Aborigines. Don't come and argue with us again. Let it rest here-please.

It would be nice if indeed in 1986 we would have done something about that particular problem, that we would have recognised the moral right to the land, and would have followed through that moral obligation to legislate to rectify that legal absurdity to which I referred previously.

I quoted previously from a letter by the Catholic bishops in 1869, but I would like to do so again because it gives us pause. We must ask ourselves whether we have gone anywhere yet. This was written in 1869 by the Catholic bishops to the Catholics of Australia:

We have dispossessed the Aboriginals of the soil . . . In natural justice, then, we are held to compensation . . . It is shocking to think of what has, in fact, been done . . . The stain of blood is upon us-blood in needless and wanton cruelty. It is said, even now, that as Europeans progress northwards, blood is so shed.

It is not all that long ago. It is retained within the memories of Aboriginal people today. It would be as well that, instead of looking at what our people, the Europeans, have done in defence of their own land in saying `Lest we forget', we should be proud that our Aboriginal people have still such a longing for and an attachment to their own land that they are willing to fight, and continue to fight, to have their land back. That we denigrate that fight seems to me disgusting, because we do not do that in any other area of Australian political life. We should be proud that after 200 years the Aboriginal people fight on for their own land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The empty chamber that we have before us is ample demonstration that the issues we are bringing forward for discussion today will not be determined in this place so much as in other rooms in this building over the coming months, and in particular in the Caucus room and Cabinet room of the present Government. This is, however, an opportunity for the Opposition to put its very clear view that there is a need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights. That issue was not addressed by Senator Ryan, representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place, who spoke and then left the chamber. It was simply ignored by her. However, that is the significant issue which has to be addressed by the Labor Party. It is our view that it should take the action which is indicated in the terms of our matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Macklin for the spirit of his contribution. I believe that he speaks with great sincerity and certainly with great consistency in these matters. In response to him, I ask him to consider that we are urging upon the Government a course of action which would be politically popular for the Government. We are seeking from this Government a move which would have the support of the great mass of the Australian people. We are not urging on the Government a course of conduct which would bring it unpopularity-quite the reverse. Why should we be concerned to do that? The simple answer to that question is that we think this is a very serious matter. We think that the Government is doing continuing damage in this area and that a change of direction is necessary.

The Government is between a rock and a hard place, because the choices before it are unpleasant. The Government can do what is clearly right and step back from its policy commitment to national land rights legislation. I stress that is the consistent view we have held in government and in opposition. However, it does that at the cost of dishonouring frequent promises to the Aboriginal people. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, come from a branch of the Labor Party which has made many extravagant promises to the Aboriginal people. You and your colleagues sat behind Senator Ryan when she made promises to the Aboriginal people which have been long broken. It must be a very difficult decision for all honourable senators opposite.

We are seeking the exercise of the sort of federalist approach which Senator Ryan used in her own defence, rather than the legislative approach which is currently being urged upon the Government by some of its own supporters, an approach which so far the Government has eschewed because I think it knows that it would be an extremely damaging course to follow. I wish to put a case to justify those comments, but let me very quickly deal with the red herrings raised in this debate by Senator Ryan. Senator Ryan asks what I have to say about the rejection of the Burke legislation in Western Australia. Let me make it quite clear that I would not support in any State or Territory of Australia the enactment of further legislation which left open-ended the amount of land which could be claimed and long periods of uncertainty as to what amount of land was to go to Aboriginal ownership. With the wisdom of hindsight-we have had this view for many years; we have sought to amend the land rights legislation of the Northern Territory for some years-it is quite clear that one of the causes of disturbance in the Northern Territory has been the long period of claims and uncertainty. I contrast that with the relatively clean and painless actions of the South Australian Government. I believe that we should have learned from those two experiences.

I made inquiries of what the effect of the Burke legislation would be with respect to claims. I understand that the legislation in its final form permitted four years to make claims. I was given an estimate of another six years for those claims to be heard. I ask you, Madam Deputy President, and Senator Walsh, who is the Minister at the table but is perhaps not listening to this debate, what effect 10 years of that sort of uncertainty would have in Western Australia. I believe that would have been a very silly proposition and that the open-ended nature of the Burke legislation was proper grounds for its dismissal and rejection.

I have had complaints from Senator Ryan in the debate about Liberal scare campaigns. I can say only that on the occasions I have campaigned in the Northern Territory I have been sickened by the Labor claims throughout Aboriginal lands. The Aborigines are told that if they elect the Liberals, the Nationals or the Country-Liberals, their land will be taken away from them. I am sure that Senator Kilgariff would be well aware of the sort of scare campaigns which are run by Labor politicians when dealing with Aboriginal audiences. I also noted Senator Ryan's claim, when she was responding to Senator Peter Baume's proper description of actions which had been taken by Liberal governments, that the Liberals are impotent. I point out that the significance of this debate is that it demonstrates that the present Government is not impotent. It has never been impotent. It has always had the legislative capacity to take the action which it promised in 1983. The Australian Democrats have always made it clear that they would support Government action. Indeed, they have urged the Government to stronger action. There is no legislative excuse, no upper House to blame. If the Government wished to bring legislation forward-we have heard it quite clearly again today-it would be supported by the Australian Democrats.

The Government has a clear majority in this place on this issue, yet it has not brought legislation forward. I will not be embarrassed by any Labor speaker in this debate because the record is a shameless one of promises made over and over again, votes bought and promises shamelessly broken. It is one of the more distasteful aspects of politics in Australia for the last three years that so many promises were made to so many Aboriginal people and so clearly broken. There would be few honourable senators in this place on the Labor side of the chamber who were not party to the making of those promises and who are now not party to the breaking of them.

Senator Ryan, who spoke without coming to grips with the issues at all, issued notes for candidates in 1983 which repeated the promise she made in this place that action would be taken to take these matters out of the hands of the Queensland Government and that legislative power of the Commonwealth would be exercised if States did not move. Western Australia has said that it will not move; the Premier has said that he will resign rather than move; but this Government still refuses to declare its hand. In the face of an election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) refuses to rule out national land rights legislation but says that he will go along with Mr Burke.

Let me move away from the aspects of this matter which move one to anger rather than to trying to work out what is the appropriate course of action. The Opposition is saying to the Government that there is a need for the Government to step back from the policy commitment, which is clearly set out in its platform, that it will use the Commonwealth legislative power when States will not act. We say very simply that we think that that is totally inappropriate. We believe that it will have a devastatingly bad effect on Aboriginal Australians and a bad effect on other Australians. If the Government persists in the confusion and uncertainty which has dominated this area, virtually ever since Mr Holding became the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, we will get a continual worsening of race relations in Australia. We will get a continuing worsening of the position of Aboriginal people in the community.

There has been a sad lack of progress, and not just in the area of land. Sadly, my last conversation with the late Dr Rowley, a man who contributed a great deal to Labor Party thinking on Aboriginal matters and who certainly was a very valued adviser to the Government and the head of a statutory body-he was a valued adviser when I was the Minister and subsequently-was about the areas where there has been slippage, where we have gone backwards instead of forwards. I have since looked at the research Dr Rowley was doing in the last years of a life that made a marvellous contribution to our knowledge of Aboriginal people in Australia. One finds in that research some of the statistics that concerned him-the gross increases in unemployment, for example, in rural New South Wales over a period of 20 years of effort in which I, other Liberals and Labor people tried to do something to improve the position.

There is a real dilemma for the Government at present. It made excessive promises. Those promises are set out in its platform, in what has been said in this chamber, in what has already been quoted and in the instructions which were given to Labor candidates in the 1983 election. Labor bought Aboriginal votes. There is no question of that. It aroused a massive over-expectation in the Aboriginal community and a massive reaction against the Aboriginal community. There has been complaint in this debate about the fact that the mining industry and others have campaigned against Aboriginal land rights. I do not have time to go into that in detail, but let me say this: The sad fact is that the quiet approach which was adopted by the mining industry at my request when I was Minister and undertook to try to work to get some changes to the land rights Act totally failed. The industry has put that point to me. It has said: `We were asked by you to go silent and nothing changed'.
