That is one of the reasons why the industry went public and why the concerns about the faults in the Northern Territory legislation have become so controversial.

It was the Labor Party which encouraged the Aboriginal community to block any attempts to remove the difficulties in the Northern Territory legislation. In my period as a Minister, in Senator Peter Baume's period as a Minister, and in Mr Wilson's period as a Minister, it was the Labor Party which was making these now broken promises that have blocked change and have produced so much of the reaction that we are now all so worried about.

What is the right course to follow? I have indicated in what I have said earlier that I do not believe there is any totally satisfactory answer. If the Government proceeds in accordance with its policy, if the Government carries out the policy of using its national legislative power, it will simply bring about very great difficulties in the legal field, in the constitutional field, in the political field, in the administration of the lands which are involved and in the community. There will be tremendous difficulties in all of those areas. Those difficulties were canvassed by me and by other Ministers when the coalition was in government, and I am sure they have been canvassed by the Minister in the present Government.

If the Government does not step back from its undertakings, if it acts, I would sadly predict that it will create very great difficulty and confusion in the Australian community, great division and great bitterness. The Government has the difficulty that for it to step back would be to break major promises to Aboriginals. It must behave dishonourably if it is to follow the course that we have advocated but in this case it would be better to break its promises than to wreak further havoc in this area.

We have consistently urged the Government to maintain a Federal approach in this area. I wrote an open letter to the Prime Minister which I had published in the Australian in May of last year. In it I put the views which I have expressed this afternoon but perhaps in a more ordered form. I repeat that the Labor Party should ponder upon the relative bipartisanship which applied to Aboriginal Affairs in the period 1975 and 1976 and ponder upon the reality that it was the Labor Party that destroyed that bipartisanship by developing policies which, in government, it has shown it is unable to implement. If we wish to step back from the division, which, I deeply regret, exists in the Australian community on this issue today, not least in my home State of Western Australia, the Labor Party has to step back closer to the position it adopted in 1975 and away from the extravagant promises which have been made over recent years.

If one looks at the reality of what has happened around Australia one has a perfect demonstration of why a federalist approach is necessary. There has been a lot of talk in this debate about the fact that South Australia devised its appropriate solution for its Aboriginal people. I for one would see the South Australian solution as probably the best which has yet been devised by any State. It learned from the mistakes which we made in the Northern Territory. It is good to see that the Queensland government has moved some way down the track with respect to deeds of grant in trust, and that has had the support of the present Government, as it has had the support of the present Opposition. It is very easy for Senator Ryan to say: `Western Australia has done nothing. Western Australia is the only State where nothing has been done'. I simply remind the Senate that one-eleventh of Western Australia-8.9 per cent-is Aboriginal land. It is held in reserves. Those reserves are secure and the Aboriginal people have access to and use of them. In Victoria there is a very limited applicability of the principle and the Victorian Government has taken minuscule steps to do anything. I notice that it is not under threat from the Federal Government; nor is the Government of New South Wales.

We have a situation where the Labor Party is publicly indicating its internal dissension on this issue. That is not surprising; that is not something of which the Labor Party should be ashamed. However, the pressures which are currently being brought to enact national legislation are flying in the face of experience and realism. It is the firm view of the Opposition that the approach which should be adopted by the national Government of Australia in this difficult but important area should be an approach which is based on working with the States and not the use of those overriding constitutional powers which probably have existed since the 1967 referendum. In a brief conversation with the next speaker she indicated to me that she wanted an approach which is based on more humane and more peaceful sentiments. I join her in those remarks. I believe that the course which is indicated in the Labor policy, the Labor platform, would produce quite the opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Commonwealth's constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights should be used. The powers have been in place since 1967 and they have not been used. Before I commence my few comments I congratulate Senator Macklin on his speech, which I think made abundant good sense. Two States in particular in Australia are backsliding very badly on the land rights issue. Obviously the Queensland Government has no intention whatsoever of introducing land rights. Western Australia, where the stated policy was for Aboriginal land rights before the 1983 election, has now turned completely around, disregarded its own policy and disregarded its own statements. Before the 1983 election Mr Burke said to Aboriginal people that he would grant them land rights. Before the election just last week he and Mr Hassell both bent over backwards to disavow land rights, to disclaim land rights and to say that there would be no land rights in Western Australia, much to the disgust and horror of many European or non-Aboriginal people as well as, of course, all Aboriginal people in that State. They have been completely sold out and they resent that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very obvious from the style of the Burke Government in Western Australia that corporate business has had a big part to play. The mining lobby has been listened to, not the Aboriginal lobby. In 1983-84 the Labor Government put in place the Seaman inquiry to inquire of Aboriginal people, mining groups and other interested groups in the community their position on land rights in Western Australia. The Western Australian Government totally ignored the Seaman inquiry's recommendations. It has made no attempt whatsoever to educate the population of Western Australia about the need for Aboriginal land rights. It has completely abdicated its responsibility to the Aboriginal people. It was incumbent upon the State Government in Western Australia to educate people about the need for Aboriginal land rights and about what Aboriginal people were actually asking for, which was not a total hand back of the State to them.

The Liberal Party of Australia was very successful in its anti-land rights campaign but it was given a completely free run on it. It was not challenged; it was not questioned. I again say that the Burke Government should have made every attempt to educate the population of Western Australia about the real condition and the real needs of Aboriginal people as an abused minority in my State. We need to look very carefully at why Aboriginal land rights are so important to Aboriginal people. Land is the spiritual basis for the Aboriginal people and it is the essence of Aboriginal culture. Aboriginals have been deprived of it by degrees ever since European settlement, and today they are almost totally deprived of it. Land is fundamental to Aboriginal integrity. To deny land rights is to continue the denial of the essence of Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal spirituality to the Aboriginal people.

The Aboriginal people are not asking for Australia to be given back to them: They are not even asking for large percentages of it to be given back to them. They are asking for recognition of their timeless association with the land and for control of parts of it. Largely the parts which they are concerned about are those which are inhospitable to non-Aboriginal people, but that is a side issue. The moral issue here is that the Aboriginal people's prior occupation of this land should be recognised and it has not been recognised.

In this the International Year of Peace it is most important that we consider the minority groups in our community. There can be no peace in the Australian community if there is not social justice. The denial of land rights to the Aboriginal people is an outrageous case of social injustice. The Commonwealth Government has the power to exert over State governments in this respect and I think it is high time it did so. Of course, the present situation in Western Australia is very embarrassing for the current Federal Labor Government but it should not abdicate its moral responsibility to the Aboriginal community.

There can be no harmony in our community, as Archbishop Carroll so eloquently reminded parliamentarians at the church service to mark the opening of this session of Parliament on Tuesday morning. He said that the seeds of peace are within us all and that the community peace, the peace which we seek, should encompass all groups and individuals within our community. Pope Paul VI said that without justice there can be no peace. To my mind it is a matter of grave social injustice that the cause of Aboriginal land rights is being ignored by the Commonwealth Government. I support the use of the Commonwealth's constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights and urge the Commonwealth Government to enforce the powers it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is most unfortunate that here this afternoon we have heard a lot of the usual political grandstanding about what is the most important issue facing this country today. It has been suggested that we should be abandoning our responsibilities to Aborigines. It has been suggested by the Opposition that we should ignore the overwhelming referendum of 1967 which gave the Commonwealth Government powers, as Senator Vallentine said, to legislate for Aborigines in this country. Perhaps even more importantly, it has been implied that we should jeopardise Australia's international reputation and be prepared to abandon Aboriginal people purely because of the various vagaries of State legislation, which can change at the whim of political leaders-I include all political leaders in that statement. As I have indicated before in this place in other debates, the question of social justice for Australia's Aborigines is far too important for the kind of political nonsense that goes on in this chamber and in the other chamber. We should be taking the lead. We should in fact be establishing the priorities; we should be setting the agenda for the debate about the need for social justice for Aborigines in Australia before 1988. Let me stress that we have not got very much longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a congratulatory letter from a gentleman on the Gold Coast in Queensland when I spoke up against the racist statements of the Queensland Premier. I would just like to quote from that letter because the writer made a very sound statement as to whether this chamber should be setting the tone of debate in regard to social justice for Aborigines. He said:
I am one who firmly believes that racism is solely and entirely a political development. No racism can breed in any country without either political sponsorship or political apathy.

I would say that there are guilty people in all political parties. There are guilty people who have put their own self-interest ahead of what is best for Australian Aborigines. For my part, I certainly regret some of the statements and commitments that have come from my own political Party. But let me make it quite clear that for every example that Senator Peter Baume or Senator Teague may give I can match three-fold with examples of conflict and contradiction within the ranks of the Opposition. I know that it is the job of the Opposition to attack the Government and to play on any embarrassing items that may occur. But let us just look at the coalition's policy. I quote from the coalition's policy on Aboriginal land rights, released in August 1984. The policy said in part:
The coalition maintains that the States are in the best position to implement appropriate land rights legislation for their own communities.

The coalition believes that there is a need for positive policies to provide opportunities for Aboriginal people who have a close and continuing association with their lands, to live according to their traditional culture and lifestyle.
This will be enhanced if they are given secure title to appropriate land, provided that land has not been alienated.
But the document further stated:
We believe that any Federal Government action in relation to land should only be taken where necessary, and only after detailed discussion with the State.

It seems to me that the Opposition is very confused about just where it stands on the question of when the States will make the decision and when the Federal Government will make the decision. When one looks within the Party ranks on the Opposition side, one sees that it is even more confused. I have a headline here `Leaders clash on land rights' and that refers to a debate between Mr Hassell and Mr Ian Tuxworth. I also have here a report of a statement from the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Ian Sinclair which states: `I'll amend land rights promises Sinclair'. He said that he was ashamed to be part of the Fraser-Anthony team that brought in land rights in 1976. That does not really sound like the pious statement made by Senator Chaney a little earlier this afternoon when he professed to be trying to get some sort of rational and informed debate going on this subject. Here we have the Leader of the National Party turning tail and saying he dissociates himself from the former Fraser Government in terms of its implementation of land rights legislation. Yet, in the 1984 election campaign, Mr Ian Sinclair on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation PM program stated:
. . . a need for uniformity in the area of land rights because of the distribution of Aboriginal populations.

I have no idea what has prompted Mr Sinclair to change his mind. I can only assume that it is the pressure that has been brought about by the mining companies and others who are prepared to give in to the racists in this country.

I quote also from a former Attorney-General and Federal Court judge, the Hon. R. J. Ellicott, QC, who opened a seminar on the Ombudsman on 7 September 1985 in Canberra. He said that since the late 1970s Australia had been going through a period of considerable inertia and law reform. While he acknowledged that there had been some significant reforms, he mentioned in particular family law reform, the Federal Court and Aboriginal land rights. He said:

Current attempts to undermine the right of Aboriginal people to say whether mining took place on their land can properly be regarded by the Aboriginal people as another act of dispossession. If a white person had taken away by the legislature the right to say whether mining took place on his or her land he or she would regard it as an act of expropriation by the State. To take that right away from the Aboriginal people, it having once been given, is an act of injustice. But who, among the mandarins in power who supported it are now defending it?

So we seem to have here confusion and contradiction in the ranks of the Opposition. I think that it is well past time that, as leaders in this country, we all came to some sort of agreement and that a pact was reached between all political parties to stop using Aboriginal people of this nation as political footballs. The situation that has developed, as was pointed out by another speaker, is that the debate about entitlements for Aboriginal people and recognition of their dispossession in Australia has swung completely the other way from that of the 1970s. That is a tragedy and it is something for which many people on all sides of the debate about Aboriginal issues are responsible. If we do not come back to the fundamental issues in recognising Aboriginal land rights in this nation, and that a Federal Government does have responsibilities, we are looking forward to a period of very serious turmoil in 1988. We have only two years. In fact, we have less than two years if we are to give to Aborigines what they are entitled to.

The issue we are debating this afternoon is perhaps the oldest and the most divisive issue ever to face this country. It is an issue that will not go away in the face of the sort of tactics that the Opposition has used here this afternoon. The Government's record is clear. The Government is committed to consultation. If that consultation appears to have been rather protracted, if the Opposition believes that we should have ignored the need to consult and just rushed in an put a piece of legislation before both chambers without consultation, I am sorry. We would rather have this delay, which has, I suppose, protected the political debate out there in the community, but at least we have been consulting Aboriginal people.

In conclusion, historic research is already under way which shows that the issues we are debating were already apparent before 1850. In 1848 the then Imperial Government established conditions for settlement and leasing of land which predicted Aboriginal land rights and use and occupancy thereof. That particular Imperial Government, of course, was talking for the whole of Australia because that pre-dated the establishment of Australian States. The question of Aboriginal land rights was seen as a national issue 140 years ago, 12,000 miles away, and it was recognised by an English aristocrat. Yet, here we are in 1986 still debating whether or not a national government has that responsibility.

The insight of the then secretary of state for the colonies, Earl Grey, has yet, it appears, to break into the closed minds of members of the Opposition and, I might add, many people out there in the Australian community. The coalition suggests that Australia is incapable of establishing an international personality. We are no longer a colonial nation; we are one nation with State governments. Of course those State governments are entitled to consultation. Of course we assume that in some cases State governments will respond in an appropriate way in introducing land rights that is in line with national land rights legislation as proposed. It is irresponsible of the Opposition to bring into this chamber this afternoon this motion that suggests that a Federal Government can just abrogate its responsibilities as a nation two years before Australia's bicentenary. The major interest in Australia when people travel overseas is the conditions for Aborigines. The world spotlight will be on this country in 1988. Therefore, we have not got much longer to stop the political grandstanding and to get on with the job, which is precisely what this Government is about to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is hardly an irresponsible motion, as stated by Senator Reynolds. In fact, we are debating a matter of urgency, the need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth constitutional powers to achieve Aboriginal land rights. That commitment is stated in the Australian Labor Party's Federal policy on Aboriginals and islanders. That policy calls for State or Territory legislation to provide for Aboriginal land rights or, failing that, for the Commonwealth to introduce its own legislation. Since coming to office the Federal Government has been promising to meet its policy commitment to introduce national land rights legislation but, as my colleagues Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney have indicated, the Federal Australian Labor Party Government's land rights policy and its attempts to implement it have been confused, disorganised and plagued by the factional struggles within the Australian Labor Party over the land rights issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The most recent accounts of the disagreements within the Labor Government over land rights indicate that the Labor Party Caucus Aboriginal Affairs Committee has called for the adoption of legislation in line with the Party's platform. Recent Press articles have quoted Mr Gerry Hand as saying that the Australian Labor Party has an obligation to live up to its previous commitments and promises to the Aboriginal people. The recent doubts which have been raised over the Federal Government's intentions have led to the unusual situation whereby the head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Charles Perkins, has publicly called for decisive action on land rights. In breaking his silence on the issue he has broken with the convention that public servants not involve themselves in political debates. That is a very interesting situation.

No doubt these promises and commitments which both Mr Hand and Mr Perkins want the Federal Government to honour would encompass the right of veto over mining on Aboriginal land and compensation to Aboriginals for lost land. But it is clear, and it has been clear for over a year, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other members of the Government are shying away from their commitments. Having promised Aboriginal people the world prior to coming to office, the Labor Party is now having to face the fact that it has promised something which it just cannot deliver. No doubt the Government is paying some heed to the poll conducted last year which showed that something like 80 per cent of Australians were opposed to the introduction of Federal land rights legislation. I think it is time that the Federal Government had the courage to admit that it has raised the expectations of Aboriginal people, as others have said, in a vote buying exercise at the 1983 and 1984 elections, and that the fact is that the land rights package which has been promised is not going to eventuate. The time has come for the Federal Government to be honest with the Aboriginal people and, for that matter, with the Australian community in general. The Government has been leading them, and all Australians, up the garden path for some two years.

Mr Holding, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, early in 1984 came out with his five principles, one of which was the right of veto over mining on Aboriginal land. He has since circulated hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of the much vaunted preferred model to Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia and other parties with an interest in the land rights debate. In the lead-up to the 1984 Federal election the Prime Minister was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 October as having said:
The general position of the Government is that we don't believe that the right of veto is an integral part of having fair and effective land rights legislation.

What are the Aboriginal people to make of that? In fact, what is any Australian to make of that? The confusion does not extend only to the Australian community; it seems to begin with the Prime Minister, for before the 1984 election he said in a Press conference on 3 October:
We will be making quite clear before the election what the position of the Government is.
Only two weeks later, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 October, he was reported as having said:
I don't believe that we're going to be able to clarify the land rights issue before the election.

More recently, we have had the continuing saga of this equivocation on land rights prior to the Western Australian election. There we saw the Labor Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke, promise to resign if the Federal Government forced land rights legislation on that State. This undertaking was met with assurances from Mr Hawke that he saw no problem with Mr Burke's position on land rights and he stated that the Labor Party would not be losing Mr Burke. Surely the clear inference which one can draw from this is that there will not be any uniform Federal land rights legislation. But the people of Australia are entitled to more than veiled suggestions; they are entitled to a clear and unequivocal statement of the Federal Government's intentions on land rights. How many elections must we have before the Government comes clean and states its true position? How long will it take for the Government to acknowledge that its policy on land rights and the requirement of Federal land rights legislation is impractical and undesirable?

The Government has already started to talk about a State by State approach to land rights. While that at least is a step in the right direction-and indeed the Opposition's policy on land rights states that we regard this as a matter for the States, which Senator Reynolds was kind enough to read out to us-the Government should now give us some detail on what is proposed. Is it intended to enact legislation which is in accordance with Mr Holding's preferred model, including a veto over mining on Aboriginal land and compensation for lost land on a Federal or State by State basis? There has been plenty of widespread community opposition to Mr Holding's preferred model. I certainly have been made aware of the feeling of Territorians and people from the States of Australia on the preferred model. I have had numerous comments from people who are opposed to it. I hope that the Government will not confuse the issue any further by foisting unwanted legislation on the States and that the Federal Government will recognise that the matter of land rights is one for the States and Territories. The Commonwealth should not impose such legislation. The States and Territories should be permitted to assess the needs and priorities of their respective Aboriginal communities and to enact appropriate legislation.

As has been said by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney, a very good example was enacted in South Australia. The Northern Territory provides a slightly different situation. Surely the Federal Government has learned from the experience of the Northern Territory and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act that the implementation and success of and support for land rights is very much dependent upon the account which the legislation takes of all those people, including non-Aboriginals, who have an interest in land use. State and Territory governments are in a far better position to examine the issues affecting Aboriginal people in their own regions and to take legislative measures. The Aboriginal people in the States and the Territory are part of them and will have their say as they do now.

The legislation in the Northern Territory, while it was formulated and enacted with the best intentions, has been shown to have many problems about which I have spoken several times already. The legislation has been in place for 10 years and practical experience of its operation has shown that many elements of the legislation require urgent amendment. I point out that where it was estimated in the first place that perhaps 23 per cent of land would eventually be made available to Aboriginals, the situation now is that more than about 30 per cent of land has been granted to Aboriginal people. All in all, with grants and land under claim at present that figure would be very close to 50 per cent. Amendment is required since both alienated and unalienated land can be claimed under the Act. If honourable senators wish to look at that matter further, I suggest they refer to my Bill, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill, which is before the Senate.

I believe that the people of the Northern Territory are in the best position to judge what those changes should be and the Northern Territory should be responsible for its land rights legislation just as State governments should control State land rights legislation. One of the unfortunate consequences of the operation of the land rights Act in the Northern Territory has been a lessening of support for Aboriginal policies, apparent not only in the Northern Territory but around Australia. It has had a very detrimental effect in so many quarters. This is most unfortunate and is why I believe that the Federal Government has a responsibility to get its house in order. If the Federal Government is seriously interested in improving the conditions of Aboriginal people it will not force unwanted legislation on the States and will rectify the situation which already exists in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should pass your Bill.

—Yes, Senator Baume; I note that comment. I make the final point that of all the comments which have come to me on Mr Holding's preferred Federal model, not one has been supportive, whether it be Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal. His proposals are not wanted and are not warranted. I suggest that the Federal Government consider examining the private member's Bill which I have prepared to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. I point out as a matter of interest that elements in my Bill appear to be similar to some of Mr Holding's proposals but other aspects would be more readily received by those in the Northern Territory who have been affected by the operation of the land rights Act. I am not talking only of non-Aboriginal people but of Aboriginal people who have lost their land against other Aboriginal people. The Northern Territory should have the authority and responsibility for its legislation. My Bill is a genuine attempt to reconcile the interests of all those involved in the land rights debate within the economic and social realities of the Northern Territory. That is what is needed, I suggest, Australia-wide. This principle should apply too to the States of Australia, State by State, not through a centralist platform. But first, can the Prime Minister and his Government take a firm stance on Aboriginal land rights legislation? If it is possible, we await it with interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter for discussion before the Senate is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its commitment to use Commonwealth Constitutional powers to achieve national Aboriginal land rights.

That proposition suggests not only-by inference I suppose-that the Government abandon its powers under section 51 (XXVI), but also that the Parliament in the foreseeable future abandon its powers under that section.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or not try to exercise it.

—Yes. As I understand the proposition put by the Opposition, and Senator Baume will correct me if it is not so, instead of the Commonwealth entering into a uniform land rights Bill and enacting legislation on that line, the States should be left to enact legislation applicable to each jurisdiction.
—And encourage it.

—Yes, but I find some difficulty with the proposition which I understand was put by Senator Baume who was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the coalition Government from 3 November 1980 to 7 May 1982 and who served that office with great distinction. The same might be said about Senator Chaney who preceded him in the period from 5 December 1978 to 3 November 1980. It is a fair proposition that both those gentlemen would much better serve the Aboriginal community than would many of the State Premiers and State Ministers responsible for Aboriginal affairs. These two honourable senators who have so eloquently and properly served the Aboriginal community want to abandon the opportunity to do that again and to give power over to the States which have been criticised by both sides of the House today. Senator Baume or Senator Chaney said that the New South Wales legislation left a lot to be desired. The sort of legislation in operation in Queensland has been criticised by this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the record of the States in the area of Aboriginal affairs has been very poor indeed. How can we as a conscientious parliament clothed from 1967 in powers to enter into this field abandon that power? Is there any situation that Senator Baume, Senator Kilgariff or Senator Chaney can envisage in which they would use this power to override the States under section 109 of the Constitution to overcome an injustice that the States were perpetrating toward Aborigines?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—If there is such a situation what is it? In a situation in which Aboriginals, as Senator Macklin said, have been denied land rights for decades is it not proper for this Parliament to deal with the land rights by using the power with which it is clothed under section 51 (XXVI)? Senator Chaney was quite correct when he said that there is great opposition to land rights and that it has developed in recent years. His answer to that was to say: `Leave it to the States. Let each State work out its own destiny'. That proposition must result in a situation in which some Aborigines would have better and more extensive rights than others because their rights would vary from State to State. The very proposition that the decision be left to the States or a Territory suggests that. Would it be a good thing to have Aboriginals around Australia with different rights depending on where they live? If they lived one mile to one side of a border, they could have secure rights; if they lived one mile to the other side of the border, their rights could be very much reduced.
—That is similar to the situation in the Territory and the States now. The Territory's rights are on a different basis.

—That is absolutely correct. As Senator Kilgariff says, that very sort of thing is going on at the moment because there is no national land rights legislation. Senator Kilgariff has made a suggestion which must inevitably lead to the proposition that there has to be some uniform land rights legislation. Senator Kilgariff said: `Leave it to the States. Leave the legislation to the Northern Territory'. Is Senator Kilgariff willing to guarantee that, if tomorrow this Parliament gave the Northern Territory Assembly the right over Aboriginal affairs, the Northern Territory would retain the excellent Act which his Government enacted in 1976, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act? How long would the provisions in that Act last if it were left to the Northern Territory Government?
—They are giving land rights to Aboriginal people on parts of leases where there is no legislative back-up now.

—Do I take it from Senator Kilgariff's answer that, if this Parliament gave the Northern Territory Assembly such power, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 would remain in operation?
—You can never go back on what exists.

—So we have a guarantee from the senator from the Northern Territory that the Northern Territory will preserve the full impact of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle spoke on that Bill in 1976. I see she is here now and I believe she ought to be quoted in this context. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the passage of legislation to grant land rights to Aborigines in the Northern Territory will be a most significant and progressive step in the social and political history of this county. It will at long last signal Australia's acceptance of Aborigines as a people having a unique and distinct culture within Australian society.

She was not then minded to say that this would apply within the Northern Territory, within South Australia or within Victoria. She referred to Australia. I suggest that in those days, in the halcyon days when there was a bipartisan policy, the legislation was seen as a matter of national triumph-indeed, a step that I am sure Senator Macklin would have welcomed.

What has happened to the bipartisan policy? It is said that the Government has destroyed it. But there is an easy way out of that. Senator Chaney said that the Government has been in a dilemma. He said that it had made promises and had had the effrontery to raise the expectations of Aborigines. That was one of the criticisms. I do not think he meant it in those stark terms but the inference from what he said is that nobody should raise the expectations of Aborigines; that they should be left in the state they are in now. Again, that has been eloquently described by Senator Macklin. But does the Opposition say that it is wrong to raise the expectations of people, in particular, Aborigines? Does the Opposition believe it is wrong to suggest that there should be legislation to enable Aborigines to live on the land of their origin, that they cannot go back to any land occupied by their grandfathers or great-great grandfathers and so on? Is it wrong to raise their expectations? That is the criticism made by the Opposition in this debate.

Senator Peter Baume asked us to think about the history of this country since European settlement. Again, that is a reason why this legislation should be left very much in the hands of the Commonwealth. We should think about the policies that took place before the 1976 land rights Act, the policies of protection and segregation which led to children being taken from their parents. There are Aboriginal people, now in their late twenties or early thirties, who do not know where their parents are or who they are. This happened as a result of policies perpetrated, no doubt in all sincerity, by the States. That is the reality of the matter. Are we to go back to the days of the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s? In the 1950s Sir Paul Hasluck developed a policy, certainly at a Federal level, to have Aborigines integrated into society. Again, that did not prove successful.

Land rights policies after all those years have proved successful; they are policies of the national government. In 1967 the people of Australia, by the greatest majority ever in a referendum, said: `Look. You, the Commonwealth Parliament, should look after these matters'. If that is the will of the people, we as the Commonwealth Parliament are obliged to do something about it. There is one way that it can be done. Senator Reynolds pointed the way. She said that we ought to have a bipartisan policy on this issue in the way that we had in 1975-76. Senator Chaney, who preceded her in the debate, also said this. Of course, Senator Chaney said that the Government has a clear majority in the Senate to be able to get Aboriginal legislation through because it has the support of the Australian Democrats. He asked why the Government did not have the political courage, as he put it, to put through this legislation if that is what it wants. Of course, that is one way of looking at it. But the trouble is that it is not only a matter for the Parliament; it is also one for the people outside the Parliament, the electorate.

The one way to overcome the opposition of the electorate, to show the electorate that there is a way forward, is for the parties in this Parliament to have a bipartisan policy. I suggest to the Opposition that that is how to overcome the problems which it says rack this issue. Why do not the parties in this Parliament get together and solve the problems in a bipartisan way, as they did in 1975-76? In that context I wish to quote a statement made by Mr Whitlam in 1972. He got the land rights issue under way. He laid the background for the legislation which was introduced by the coalition in 1976-the legislation which, if it were left to the State branches of the Opposition parties, would soon be dismembered. In 1972 Mr Whitlam said:

More than any foreign program, more than international obligations which we meet or forfeit, more than any part we may play in treaty or agreement or alliance, Australia's treatment of its Aboriginal people will be the thing upon which the rest of the world will judge Australia and Australians-not just now, but in the greater perspective of history.

What is done by the Western Australians, the South Australians, the Queenslanders or those in the Northern Territory is not seen in terms of that State or Territory but in terms of what Australia will do. Australia has an obligation primarily to the Aborigines. It also has an obligation to its own reputation. The sorts of things that are said about Africa and South Africa should never be said about Australia. The opportunity should never exist for that to be said. In Australia's own interests, it should act as a country and should exercise the power that the people of Australia in 1967 so resoundingly said it should have and it should bring in uniform land rights legislation. It is an abnegation, a refusal to carry out our duty if we simply say: `We are too frightened. We are not willing to take on the opprobrium of the people outside, whether they be miners or anybody else. We will not do that. We will duck behind the issue and leave it to the States. We will adopt this new policy of federalism.' But what is the policy of federalism? What does it mean?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERVISING SCIENTIST FOR THE ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The legislation that brought about the development of uranium mining in the Jabiru region and provided for its administration, co-ordination and control has now been in operation for several years. When one looks at those controls and at the responsibilities of the Supervising Scientist and the various authorities relating to this development one wonders how on earth the administration of this area has been carried out with any degree of efficiency. The introduction of the annual report of the Supervising Scientist of the Alligator Rivers region states:

The Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region, a statutory officer appointed under the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978, performs his functions within a network of interlocking legislation, agreements and regulatory instruments. These institutional arrangements recognise the regulatory responsibilities of the Northern Territory as a self-governing territory, as well as national park and Aboriginal interests, and the more general controls in relation to uranium mining and export exercised by the Commonwealth. An outline of the principal legislation and the agencies involved is given in Figure 1.

Figure 1 shows that the implementation of environment protection in the region involves the Commonwealth Minister for Territories, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Minister for Resources and Energy, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, The Attorney-General and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, while from the Northern Territory we have the Minister for Mines and Energy, the Minister for Conservation, the Minister for Health and the Minister for Community Development. When one peruses all these various responsibilities that these Ministers have, whether Commonwealth or Northern Territory, one sees that there is an immense horizon.

The point that I put briefly to the Senate tonight is this: I believe that these various Acts which give the various Ministers authority and set up the Supervising Scientist, at times have been too unwieldy. There are too many authorities, too many regulations and too many people with their fingers in the pie. I believe that after this period-this system has been in operation for some 10 years-there should be a review of the whole administration. Surely it is not necessary to have so many agencies. Surely this system could be much more efficient and less costly to the nation. I think this is a very good point and I would like to hear from the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans as I know that he has a real interest in this area. I believe that it is time for the Government and for all those various authorities to have a review to bring about a more efficient system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that the annual report of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region is a document which, as the preceding speaker, Senator Kilgariff, said, spells out the procedures that take place. But I think we have to go back to basics. This is a national park. Uranium mining should not be allowed at all in this national park. The procedures that allow it are really immaterial; we should not have any uranium mining. On page 22 under the heading `Review and Assessment of Environmental Impact of Mining Operations', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A growing company concern at Ranger is an excess of about one million cubic metres of water that has accumulated within the Restricted Release Zone.

According to the report, it turns out that much of this problem was caused by Ranger itself because one million cubic metres of water in excess of requirements were imported during 1982 when it was thought there might be a shortage of water. What a terrible way to operate a mine. These people are in charge of radioactive substances. The report states:

Ranger is studying a number of measures to reduce its water surplus, including spray irrigation, subaerial tailings management, better segregation of clean water within the RRZ, building a further water management/evaporation pond and discharge of water of suitable quality to Magela Creek.

I have seen all these operations. In fact I went out there and talked to the people at Ranger and they said: `If we are not allowed to release water we will have to shut down by March'. Ranger itself has admitted that all these options will not work except for the release of water into Magela Creek. The report also states:

Finally, neither biological science nor our knowledge of the ecosystems of the Region is adequate to enable confident predictions to be made of all effects that could arise and their ecological significance as a result of water release to the creek systems-particularly in the long term.

That is in the report of the Supervising Scientist. The Government, on its part, has said as recently as 6 November 1985 that it will allow no release of water. I quote from the Canberra Times of 6 November 1985 which States:
A spokesman for Mr Cohen said yesterday that the Government had already decided that there would be no water release from the mine during the coming wet season.

He said that Ranger had made a `series of blunders' including over-estimating the rate of evaporation, under-estimating precipitation in the area, and miscalculating the density of tailings suspended in water.
`Their mistakes have led to the problem', he said. The Government was not disposed towards the release of contaminated water into Magela Creek.
That is good stuff. But what happened then? The Ranger release of water, which the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) said would never take place, was allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said contaminated water. That is what you read out. There is a difference.

—The Minister, Mr Cohen, said that it was all right to release this water on 2 February because it was being released in an area where there was natural contamination. In fact he approved of the release of this water and it is contaminated water, make no mistake. The Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry recommended that a policy of total containment be followed by that mine. Now it turns out that the man who could actually control this release is sitting in this chamber at this moment. It is the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, in whom the power resides to control releases in this area, yet apparently he is not exercising this power.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Senate and I put it to the Minister as well that the Government is simply not taking its role seriously. In the first place, mining should not be allowed at all in a national park. It would appear that Ranger has blackmailed the Government into going along with its release program by saying: `We will shut the mine down if we do not get our release program okayed'. The Government has caved in to this. I think it is high time that the Government lived up to its responsibility to the people of Australia to control Ranger in a manner which will make it safe for the environment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The tabling of the science and technology statement must be a significant disappointment for the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones). The statement is a drastic diminution of the Minister's top project, the national technology strategy. It no longer represents a statement of government intent but rather is merely a vague framework to assist in the formation of other policies. I know not why the Government has taken this attitude towards such a project. The shelving of the strategy will mean that more than two and a half years of continuous preparation by a number of task forces and departments, as well as 250 submissions from industry, government and community groups, will all come to virtually nothing.

For all that, the Opposition supports many of the aims set down in this statement although, of course, we may differ on the means of achieving those aims. The Opposition agrees that there is a need for increased student participation in education and the Opposition adds that measures that would lead to increased study in the science and engineering should be encouraged. The Opposition supports greater research effort by industry, increased interaction between research institutions and industry and greater use of technology by industry. The Opposition in particular will promote collaborative undertakings between industry, universities and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation as we believed the technology strategy was going to do. The Opposition supports the principle that industry contribute directly to these and related public sector institutions-a move which will almost certainly bring about a greater degree of relevance of research and lead to greater utilisation of Australian's technical resources. The Opposition also supports much greater exchanges of personnel between industry and research institutions.

According to the statement, one of the priority actions that the Government believes will lead to increased private sector spending on research and development is the 150 per cent tax concession on research and development expenditure. Although the Opposition is heartened by the apparently strong response to the announcement of the concession there are a number of concerns about possible deleterious effects of the move. The first concern relates to the bias in the legislation against individual inventors, partnerships and smaller innovation-based firms. The bias against these smaller inventors and innovators is manifest in the following ways. Firstly, the foreshadowed criteria explicitly rule out the concession being available to individual partnerships or trusts. Secondly, applicants must be able to point to past performance on research and development and this severely disadvantages new and small firms, as does the third criterion, that is the requirement that spending on research and development in a particular year exceeds $50,000. Do we want out research and development, or do we not?

The Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office points up the folly of such a policy. For example, individuals account for 71 per cent of new domestic-based applications for patents, but 79 per cent of such applications lapse. Clearly, ideas for potentially exciting new projects are not reaching production stage, yet the Government's policy flagship on research and development ignores and indeed discriminates against this important reservoir of innovative talent. So many might-have-beens fail to get off the ground because support at the vital stage is not available.

Other reservations the Opposition has include the possibility that the concession will lead to a distortion of the most efficient distribution of investment resources. The experience of the effect of a similar tax concession, for instance in the film industry, is illustrative in this way. Quantity, not quality, was the result. Such a prospect occurring in research and development must be carefully considered and avoided. Another concern is one related to potential abuse of the concession by firms not genuinely interested in research and development. Finally, the Opposition, with these concerns in mind, would like a commitment that the greater than expected cost of the tax concession will not mean a reduction in other research and development programs which are of greater benefit to smaller innovators. In closing, it must be noted that the Opposition has serious reservations-and this is by no means an exhaustive list-about the flagship of the Government's technology statement. But the Opposition supports the aim of the statement. The statement is a useful handbook but unfortunately no more than that. The high prospects of 1983 have gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement on science and technology documents the policies and activities, and to a certain extent the budgets, of an extraordinary large number of departments and government and semi-government organisations which are grouped under the umbrella of science and technology. The number is extraordinarily large in the terms of the normal meaning of the term science and technology, because this document includes research into such matters as the social sciences and the humanities. The amount of money spent on research and development in the whole area of science and technology would seem huge. One wonders why Australia has not benefited from this large expenditure of money. Why have we not benefited to the extent that other western nations have from such a large infusion of capital? It is quite clear from reading this statement why Australia is falling behind its competitors.

SPEECH.PARA: First, we are spending on research and development nowhere near the amount of money being spent by such countries as the United States of America, Western Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Switzerland and the Netherlands, all of which have in excess of one per cent of their entire work force employed in research and development, whereas Australia has only 0.65 per cent. Similarly, the United States of America, Western Germany, Japan and the United Kingdom spend over 2.5 per cent of gross domestic product on research and development, whereas Australian investment, from all sources, amounts to only one per cent of GDP. We obviously are not taking this matter very seriously, and it shows our declining status in relation to the western world.

Secondly, those elements in our society who should benefit most from this technology and scientific achievement have generally refused to accept a great deal of responsibility for funding the necessary research. In the United States, for example, the business community spends more than three times the amount on research and development than does government. Similarly, in Switzerland business enterprises spend eight times more on research and development than does the Swiss Government. By contrast, Australian business contributes only one quarter as much as the Government does. As the Minister points out, the problem in Australia is not so much with government funding of research and development but with private sector funding. It is ironic that millions of dollars are available for investment in corporate takeovers which are virtually non-productive, but very little is available for entrepreneurial development. Unless we make heroes of the research scientists rather than the Holmes a Courts of this world, I do not think the situation will improve a great deal. Until the private sector does more to help itself, we will continue to suffer from lack of international competitiveness.

Thirdly, Australia has achieved excellence in many areas of science. Our universities are held in high regard, particularly the larger ones, and we have a wealth of internationally regarded scientists and researchers in the universities and government laboratories. But unfortunately many are leaving this country because there is not enough scope or money for further development and achievement. Just last year we lost three of our top polymer graduates to the United States. As a result Australia's future opportunities to cash in on this area remain grim compared with many European countries. Polymers are crucial in aerospace, electronics, and medical fields. Also they are used in techniques to purify water, techniques which could be vital to a country such as Australia. But rather than invest in our future, we allow out top scientists in this area to be pirated by our competitors.

Fourthly, it would appear that many of our research projects that receive funds are of questionable merit of application. Considering the limited resources we have, I believe we must apply those funds to the greatest benefit for future development. For business to become more involved in research and development, the universities would need to change some of the scope and direction of their research in order to apply more of their funds to applied work for the benefit of industry. Research must become tailored to the market and to the development of products and processes which can be turned to national advantage. In other words, universities could direct more of their research towards industrial research and development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making some remarks on the Science and Technology Statement 1985-86, there are three matters to which I wish to draw attention. First, it is most disturbing to look at the figures which appear in the table on page 19 of the report. They show the extent to which private enterprise in its contribution to gross expenditure on research and development in Australia has been dragging the chain. The figures there indicate quite clearly that from 1968-69 when private enterprise provided 32 per cent of the total funding as a percentage of GERD that figure declined in 1983-84 to a figure of 17 per cent, the lowest figure it has ever reached.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Archer said that, while the Opposition welcomes in principle the establishment of the 150 per cent tax concession for private sector expenditure on research and development, we feel that there are a number of problems in this sphere. I wish to point to three. The first is the extent to which the scheme is likely to benefit foreign companies at the expense of Australian companies; secondly, the extent to which it is likely to benefit existing and established companies at the expense of start-up and innovative companies; and the third, without going into details, is the question of expenditures which under the current guidelines are not allowed but which in my view ought to be allowed. Of those I believe the most important and significant is the expenditure on patent and copyrighting.

Anybody who has any knowledge of the significance of patent and copyright legislation in turning good ideas and good research into commercially viable undertakings will come to appreciate that not to allow substantial costs in that area as a deduction under the scheme will prejudice its operation. In particular I refer to those occasions where a company has to apply for and file patents outside Australia and has to keep those on foot by renewing them in the United States and in Europe on a fairly regular basis so that they do not lapse. This is indicative of the rather sloppy attitude taken by the Government to the published guidelines. It is a disgrace that at this stage all we have to go on is a series of Press statements by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). Despite the fact that this scheme has been in operation since 30 June last, the scheme still has no legislative backing. Indeed, we have not seen a piece of legislation subject to possible amendment by this Parliament as to what is and what is not an allowable deduction. It is a disgrace that we are almost twelve months down the track of the scheme's operation and have not seen any degree of legislative backing for it.

I wish to emphasise a point made by Senator Archer. I refer to the craven abandonment of the national technology strategy by the Government during the course of this year. All the hype and hyperbole which has come to mark Mr Barry Jones's administration of his Department has once again turned to dust in his mouth in terms of any concrete achievement for the Australia scientific and technical sector.

The last point I wish to make is referred to in passing on pages 2 and 3 of the statement. I refer to the analyses which have been conducted this year of the various research and incentive schemes. For example, we have had this year a report by the Australian Science and Technology Council on computer-related technologies in the metal trades industry; a report by the Centre for Technology and Social Change on high technology indicators. We have also seen a report from Nicholas Clark & Associates; the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences report; the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board report; the Bureau of Industry Economics report; the Price Waterhouse report; and three other ASTEC reports dealing with research funding in Australia. None of those has yet been substantially replied to by the Government. They all advocate changes. They all advocate needed improvements. Yet the Government has taken no steps to indicate what it proposes to do about any of these schemes in terms of the recommendations with which they have been presented by a number of expert bodies. To that extent, once again, the paucity of action compared with the superabundance of rhetoric we have had from the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in the operation of his portfolio stands as a very sorry condemnation of the record of this Government in what is a vital sector for Australia and the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very pleasing to see that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), unlike his Government, remains committed to the link between science and technology. Currently there is general concern about Australia's poor export performance and our dependence on massive imports of high technology products. Most experts agree that this situation can be improved only through the transfer and development of research results into technological manufacture of high value-added products. For this reason I view with great concern the trend towards decreasing research and development investment in Australia. This is exactly what the science and technology statement tells us.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister points out, the major cause of the trend is the very low level of private business investment in research and development. The private enterprise share of research and development funding decreased from 32 per cent in 1968 to 17 per cent in 1984; that is, the proportion of research and development done by business in Australia has almost halved in less than 20 years, as Senator Puplick has pointed out. The Government has taken some measures to stimulate private investment in research and development through its 150 per cent tax deduction scheme offered to businesses for research and development. But, as Senator Puplick also has said, it relates only to existing large companies and does not handle the small company.

The Australian industrial research and development incentive scheme is also a very valuable help to industry. However, the dominance of Australian business by overseas-owned parent companies, whose primary loyalties lie outside Australia means that this problem is likely to continue unless the Government obtains commitments from the parent companies to invest in Australian research and development. The offset policy has not been a success. I might even go so far as to say that many firms consider it to be a farce. Most offset investments in Australia have been of low level technology, such as label engineering. Occasionally they may involve some technology transfer. However, positive research and development investment has not resulted in any large extent from the offset program.

The figures showing trends in Commonwealth Government support for research and development are also fairly disquieting. These figures show that even government-funded research and development is getting a decreasing share of Australia's gross domestic product. Since 1981, the Hawke Government's total outlays on research and development have decreased from 0.51 per cent of GDP in 1981 to 0.48 per cent of GDP in 1986. The trend is continuing. This means that Australia is reinvesting less and less of its output in research and development. The long term effect of this is quite frightening. Already we are suffering from the lack of research and development investment in the past. It is noteworthy that Australia earns its major export income from its rural and mineral industries and that it is in these areas that most of Australia's research and development effort is and has been concentrated. If we concentrated some research effort on some other areas we might be able to compete in them.

Another example is defence spending. Defence spending has decreased over the years. It is extremely important, if we are to keep a strong, independent Australia, that we give affirmative support to Australian industry and, particularly, use some of our defence money to promote both defence and the development of local products we can support locally.

In manufacturing, whilst there has been a small increase in research and development expenditure, the failure of this trend to reach our business enterprises means that we are not likely to see a turnaround in performance in this area. The time-lag between the investment of research and development moneys and its payoff can be of the order of ten years. We have ten years of problems ahead of us because we have not been investing in the manufacturing sector. We have been neglecting the energy field. We are screaming about the cost of energy. The most disturbing trend is the rapidly diminishing research and development effort in transport. In a country as large as Australia, with such long distances between its cities, such wide and sparsely inhabited inland, a country so far from the major markets of the world, whose defence and trade are so vulnerable to transport problems and whose public transport systems are in tatters, this trend is incredible. We have to start spending more in these areas. In conclusion, I point out that Australia has dropped back in its research and development effort compared with most other member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a short statement on the subject of water release from the Ranger uranium mine in response to comments made by Senator Kilgariff and Senator Sanders earlier in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it may be helpful to clarify the present situation with respect to water release at Ranger in the light of comments that were made by Senator Sanders, in particular, in his discussion of the report of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. It is important to appreciate that there are two separate situations. One is in relation to water accumulations outside the restricted release zone. The second is the problem of water accumulation within the restricted release zone. I believe that there has been some confusion in a number of reports about developments at Ranger as between those two areas.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place I shall deal with the water release which has recently occurred at Ranger and which has been subject to some Press reports that contaminated water has been released into the Magela Creek. The water that has recently been released came from retention pond No. 4 which is located outside the mine's restricted release zone. This pond is a storage pond which collects rainwater runoff. It certainly does not contain contaminated mine water. Nevertheless, it is tested before it is released and is released only if it meets standards which have been agreed to by parties represented on the co-ordinating committee for the Alligator Rivers Region, including the Aborigines and the Kakadu National Park management. I make it quite clear in that respect that, insofar as water has been released, it has been from outside the restricted release zone. Certainly no authorisation has been given by me or anyone else for the release of water into the Magela Creek from within the mine's restricted release zone. No such application for such release of water has even been sought or has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they going to transfer contaminated water into that area?

—I will get to other situations in a moment. Just to finish my comments with respect to the recent water release, I am advised that there have been reports that large quantities of mussels have aborted following the release of water recently into the Magela Creek. However, those reports are wildly exaggerated. Whilst it is true that last year there was some `fish avoidance'-as described by the scientists-and short term impairment of the reproduction of mussels in the vicinity of the outlet pipe, the significance of this, honourable senators will be pleased to know, is, I am told, unclear. The Supervising Scientist, whose staff reported the early release of mussel larvae, is of the view that the release of the retention pond No. 4 water recently will have virtually no environmental effect.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the larger, continuing problem of accumulations of water within the restricted release zone, which are prima facie contaminated, the situation is as follows: It is the case that high rainfall and less evaporation than originally forecast, and maybe some of the other factors that Senator Sanders referred to, has led to the build-up of excess water within the restricted release zone at Ranger to the point where mining could be impeded. Senator Sanders will no doubt regard that as a good thing, but nonetheless so long as the mine exists and makes the contribution it does to our resource sector, that is a situation the Government would wish to avoid. Ranger had hoped to release so-called clean RRZ water to the Magela to reduce its water holdings. The Supervising Scientist was of the view that this would not imperil the environment, but a number of groups with interests in the region remained concerned and alternative measures were sought.

Ranger then submitted a report to the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments in which it set out its proposals for the best practicable technology in water management. That report was considered by the co-ordinating committee in December and was felt to be useful. However, the Supervising Scientist is of the view that the report does not go far enough to serve as a basis for determining the best practicable technology. Ranger has now agreed to bring into commission a water treatment plant and, in the absence of a settled BPT regime, the unanimous consensus of the co-ordinating committee was that water treated in this plant to agreed criteria could be safely disposed of by spray irrigation. Provided there is no extreme rainfall, water treatment and irrigation should permit continuing operation of the mine without the need to consider the release of water and should slowly reduce the water holdings. Only in extreme circumstances, I am able to assure the Senate, would the question of water release be reconsidered and then only of rain water accumulated in the project area.

I conclude by saying it is the case, as I understand it, that as the Minister for Resources and Energy I have ultimate authority under section 41 of the Atomic Energy Act to set conditions, including the authority to impose a condition prohibiting absolutely water release of the kind that is in issue here. I make it clear, however, that many other authorities are vested with responsibility: Indeed, Senator Kilgariff identified a number of them. It would be only in exceptional circumstances that I think it would be appropriate for me to come in over the top. However, I have very strong personal views about the undesirability of there being a water release from within the restricted release zone and would certainly need an enormous amount of persuasion for any other form of release than that which has occurred so far and been accepted as appropriate by the co-ordinating committee to take place.
