SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to make a few comments on the operation of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. I start off, as I usually seem to, by giving credit to Mr Jim Fitzpatrick, the Chairman of the organisation, for the way he has got the business organised and runs the ship. He runs it very well. A couple of interesting things have arisen and need to be referred to. Firstly, I mention arrears. The report states that there was a relatively low level of claims and that this was matched by a significant fall in the numbers of arrears cases as at 30 June 1985. This is one of the marks that go with a period of rising prices and buoyant markets. When those circumstances arise and in times of apparent prosperity on the part of home buyers, arrears are very low. There is a reverse to this situation. If the situation changes and the market starts to fall, or the appearance of economic growth ceases to take place, we could expect a change in the level of claims and arrears.

I shall draw attention to another matter because it is in line with business generally and is an Australian disease at present. The financial results show that premiums earned rose at a slower rate and were up 10 per cent to $9m and that operating expenditure increased by 19 per cent. It needs to be borne in mind that business generally cannot continue to be run when expenses are rising at nearly double the increase in incomes.

The report again draws attention to the secondary mortgage market. In 1964 I was involved fairly substantially in the housing business. At the stage when the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was being formed we were looking to the formation of a secondary mortgage market which was properly organised and which had the necessary legislation to make its operation quite simple. The position now is that there is a small secondary mortgage market but it is not operating adequately. There are still restrictions which make its operation less than easy. For the time ahead of us when we will be dealing with a tight money supply and difficult business circumstances, I urge the Government to consider seriously taking away any impediments to the establishment of a proper secondary mortgage market.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take this opportunity of making a few comments about the Health Insurance Commission which, in its report, addresses some of the facts and figures that it is very important for honourable senators to know. They are certainly figures that are sometimes modified or bent, depending on how the argument needs to be shaped. Certainly Medicare has taken its fair share of abuse. I draw honourable senators' attention to the details and facts contained in this report. They should allay the fears about Medicare. The data indicates the facts about Medicare. We should not skate over the issue because of what I sometimes think is prejudice by some honourable senators.

It has been quite interesting to observe the establishment and continued development of Medicare, and in fact its consolidation over the year 1984-85. I think it is reasonable to accept the report's claim that Medicare has become accepted by the people of Australia as a stable, effective and understandable health benefits scheme. Also in this report, under the heading of `Medibank Private', is a brief description of the fortunes of Medibank Private, which in fact showed a fall in membership with the introduction of Medicare, and then a rise in the early part of 1985, to the point where Medibank Private covered 1 3/4 million people up until June 1985. This, says the report, supports the claim that the Australian population wishes to maintain a dual, that is, a public and a private, health care system. This is certainly evidenced by the acceptance of the Medicare scheme and by the participation in a private health scheme, as outlined in this report in the Medibank Private history.

The Medibank Private operations over the year actually resulted in a national surplus of some $43.8m, compared with a surplus of $27.4m in 1983-84. So I would presume Medibank Private could take some heart from that. That is interesting, given the report of some fall in membership before a kick-up again. The total figures for Medicare make interesting reading, too. A total of $2,296.2m was paid out in Medicare benefits during the year and $107.6m in management expenses, which very closely approximated the Budget appropriations for those two categories. In fact, over the year under reporting, there has been no major change to the health insurance arrangements. However, the change with the arrangement between the Federal Government and New South Wales on 2 April clearly has implications for both Medicare and Medibank Private-in particular for Medicare because of a reduction in the number of patients having Medicare status in public hospitals. I would presume that the implications of that will flow more into next year's annual report.

It is also interesting to note that in this report there are some very comprehensive statistics on how many people have been issued with cards and how many people are on cards for individuals as against those who have cards that cover more than one person. I am very surprised to find that some cards cover 12 and more people, although very few people in this country draw their Medicare benefits under a card with 12 persons listed on it. The report contains very useful information and hard data, so I hope it is referred to by honourable senators in future deliberations on Medicare.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am pleased to rise to speak to the annual report of the Commonwealth Department of Health for the year 1984-85. Again, I am not sure that other senators will take the same interest as I do in the remarkable tables, but if they want to go to the back of this report they will find there the most entertaining bedside reading. I discover that there are notifiable diseases listed in the report of the Commonwealth Department of Health that I have never even heard of, much less am able to pronounce.

Even to pick out some of the diseases that I do have some recognition of makes for a most interesting understanding of the health status, if not of the illness status, of the Australian population. For instance, I find it quite shocking to discover that leprosy still occurs in Australia and that there were cases of leprosy reported for both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in Australia, albeit in small numbers. I was also interested to observe the numbers of tuberculosis cases that were notified in the year of this report. If one wanted to be mischievous one could go to the breakdown by State of the notified cases of venereal disease and draw some very interesting, albeit insufficient, conclusions. But I do not wish to deliberate on that section of the report except to make comments on the comprehensiveness of these statistics and their usefulness for looking at notifiable diseases and also at benefits, bed days, occupancy rates and any number of statistics of all sorts that are the concern of this Commonwealth Department. The report is interesting because it has a new format. The report starts off:
Regular readers of this Report will not have failed to notice changes in its format . . .

I would be very interested to meet a regular reader of the Commonwealth Department of Health annual report. I suspect that such people are largely within the Department of Health. But I take account of the fact that there is a new format, and perhaps it is because of the way that it is set out that so many of these tables and statistics and so much of this data are so readily obvious and available to anybody looking at the report.

The change in format of the report matches the change in structure of the Health Department, which has undergone considerable re- arrangement. The report talks about the anatomy of re-organisation, and these sections are headed `Change by Government decision', `Change by Ministerial decision', and `Change by management decision', followed by further descriptions of the various sub-sections in the Department. The report is, for anybody interested in the Commonwealth Department of Health much less the many areas covered by this Department, a very lucid elaboration of what the Department's structure is now and the reasons for how it has been so arrived at.

I wish to commend the Department not only on the comprehensive coverage of any number of other areas-such as the drug matters, the Better Health Commission, the Institute of Health, and even the difficulties with which the Commonwealth Department of Health has had to contend as a result of the presence and increase of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the Australian community which is a most worrying problem-but also I would perhaps as predicted, like to commend the report on its clear, obvious and comprehensive section of women's health and equal employment opportunity matters. I suppose Health is a department that might be expected to have a fair awareness of women's issues. It is true, as the report says, that the Department has perhaps been slow in looking to the needs of women and women's health in times past, but this is currently being redressed both within the Department and its structures and within the areas of health and preventative health provisions covered by the Department.

In 1975 there was, to correspond with International Women's Year, a highly successful conference, `Women's Health in Changing Society', and in 1985, the period covered by this report, a second national health conference was held in South Australia to which the Commonwealth Health Department contributed $30,000. It was a very useful, comprehensive conference which looked at issues concerning women's health. In the few seconds remaining to me I draw the attention of honourable senators to this report. It is excellent, comprehensive and very clear.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REFORM OF COMMONWEALTH PRIMARY INDUSTRY STATUTORY MARKETING AUTHORITIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian research grants scheme provides grants for research to individuals and groups who are not employed directly by the Government. While the scheme does allow for funding of private research projects, it is noteworthy that in 1985 only seven such projects were funded out of a total of 1,453 grants awarded. Is it possible that the failure to transfer research effort into viable technological industry is related to the concentration of our research efforts in universities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other such institutions?

Most universities and colleges are government funded. Research is an essential component of the work of both lecturers in universities and colleges of advanced education lecturers and of the education of tertiary and post-graduate students, yet it is very difficult to get accurate figures of the proportion of university and college grants that go to funding the research activities within these institutions. So much so that science and technology statements by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) have omitted these figures from the reported figures of government spending on research and development in universities and colleges; just simply, these figures are probably not available. However, most university and college staff are united in agreeing that this funding is most inadequate.

Most of the ARGS funds are spent on supplementing the universities through another door rather than stimulating greater levels of research in Australian industry. The competition for ARGS funding by university departments is a matter of life and death to those departments. If a department fails to win grants for at least some of its staff to undertake reasonable research projects, that department stands to lose its better qualified and most energetic teaching staff, its students lose the opportunity for post-graduate research and look for other avenues in other departments, and so student numbers fall in those departments and possibly in the whole set of courses serviced by the departments which so suffer. Since universities fund departments on the basis of their student numbers, the rot sets in and it can take many years for a department to recover from even a year's hiatus in its research grants from ARGS. The consequent imbalance in teaching quality has a major effect for many years on the graduates who move from those departments into industry, commerce, teaching and other occupations.

In 1968 Australia was amongst the middle range of research and development performers in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It was comparable to Switzerland, Sweden, the Netherlands, Canada, Belgium and Italy. In 1986 Australia is barely above the median level of the research and development investment of the small research and development performers of the OECD. These countries include Finland, Norway, Denmark and Austria, which spend more on research and development than Australia. New Zealand, Ireland, Iceland and Portugal are below, and only just below, Australia in their research expenditure. For a country of such great natural wealth, with a population which has selected the most adventurous immigrants from amongst many nations of the world, this performance is very hard to understand. How have we let ourselves fall to this level? How long will it be before we pull ourselves together to work for the future?

The OECD report on science and technology in Australia underlines Australia's falling research and development expenditure and its low level of expenditure compared with similar OECD countries. The OECD report also underlines the dramatic decline in funding available to individual university researchers compared with researchers in the government sector. The report also points out that, in carrying out their work, many universities have to put up with obsolete equipment which has high maintenance costs.

I commend the ARGS system and I wish that the Government would put a lot more money into the scheme because Australia needs longer term planning of research programs and teaching commitments through a planned triennial funding of research grants. The ARGS grants are on an annual basis. Australia needs greatly increased funding of normal research programs for university and college within their normal funding; increased funding of individual projects through ARGS funds and extra ARGS funds for upgrading equipment; and funding for the training of research and technical assistants who are essential to good research. I commend the ARGS report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In October last year I addressed the annual conference of the Marriage Guidance Council of Australia in Hobart, which I regarded as something of an honour. Included in my remarks at that conference was the recognition of the fact that the limits of tolerance of ordinary taxpayers, many of whom have had to keep their marriages and families intact in difficult times, had been reached in regard to funding the abdication of responsibility by a father or mother who could afford to contribute to the maintenance of a child of a dissolved marriage. We all know that the Institute of Family Studies has done considerable work in this area. Not only the information from the Institute but also the information available from many voluntary and community organisations impresses one. The cumulative evidence shows that there is very strong argument for higher maintenance orders which are enforceable. That latter phrase, `which are enforceable', needs to be emphasised. To take only one statistic, sole female parents, as shown in the Institute of Family Studies report, on average were $78 worse off vis-a-vis their pre-separation position, and non-custodial men living alone were $72 better off. In other words, many men could afford more than the $20 per child which seems to be the norm, the rule of thumb, and which, as I say, in any case is not vigorously enforced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Melbourne-based family welfare agency, the Mission of St James and St John, in an independent survey-I do not know how scientific its basis really was; nevertheless, it made a very interesting finding-found that some 75 per cent of fathers it surveyed, and who were divorced or separated, ignored rulings by the Family Court of Australia on maintenance payments for their children. That was an extraordinarily high number in the area of concern to that particular voluntary organisation.

The fact is that these matters are well reported and known, I think, to the general populace and have led to a strong sentiment amongst ordinary Australians that the resources of the non-custodial parent should be the first consideration in determining the size of a maintenance order. At that stage the impact of available social security benefits should be ignored. Of course, if those resources are inadequate to provide a reasonable standard of living for the custodial parent and the dependent children, the Court should take into account the social security system.

The general thrust of the first clause of Senator Durack's Family Law Amendment Bill 1985 is one that many would agree with in principle; namely, that the public purse should be used as a last resort and should not be dipped into as a substitute for parental responsibility, if I can put it in those terms. I understand that that is the main thought behind the private member's Bill which Senator Durack has presented to the Senate.

I may have got a little carried away in that particular conference forum because I put an emphasis on government expenditures, which are considerable in this area. Senator Durack pointed out in his second reading speech that expenditure last year on the supporting parent's benefit rose to some $889.6m, with 153,589 recipients receiving that particular benefit. An enormous amount of money is being paid by the community in support of parents who have dependent children and meagre resources to call on of their own. I do not want to put the first emphasis on the matter of protecting revenue, nor would one want to do as some have done-I do not accuse Senator Durack of this-in placing a moralistic insistence on the obligation of the non-custodial parent, which is coloured sometimes in language which suggests that we are trying to put a pecuniary penalty on the non-custodial parent for the divorce and separation. Rather, we should be concentrating on the terrible poverty into which children and the single supporting parent are so often degraded upon separation and the dissolution of the marriage. Indeed, it is well known that in the last decade or so patterns of poverty in Australia have changed. Certainly when I was a child we would have expected poverty to be amongst the elderly; now the situation quite clearly has changed and poverty is amongst young children, particularly in households where the only income to sustain them is the supporting parent's benefit.

Our real focus should be on the obligations of both parents, custodial and non-custodial, and then of society-in that order-as is suggested by Senator Durack's Bill, in dealing with and trying to alleviate the poverty that develops upon separation and divorce. I am sure that the rest of the community is prepared in a practically compassionate way to come to the aid of such households only when it is clearly perceived-this is the question of equity, fairness and justice as understood in the community-that the non-custodial parent has not sufficient resources to call on to aid sufficiently the household that has only meagre resources.

Of course, it is not merely a question of setting a maintenance payment which is adequate, but of enforcement and compliance with the maintenance order. I will come to that later because I believe that that is the weakness in the overall scheme of Senator Durack's approach, which I think he admits. He cannot do everything in his Bill. It may lead the Senate to think that it is not appropriate at this stage to pass the Bill into law without some of the further elements to do with compliance and enforcement which are so important and essential and really the key to the successful lifting of many poverty-stricken Australian households for their situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it would be a first step.

—It would be a step to be taken in conjunction with the other steps which are necessary. It is quite correct to place primary responsibility on the non-custodial parent. That goes to the matter of equity and fairness which the gallup poll shows is a matter of great concern to all Australians. I do not know whether Senator Durack has had a chance to look at the gallup poll of 21 January 1986. It indicates:

SPEECH.PARA: Most Australians (76%) believe parents who do not pay child maintenance when ordered to do so by the courts should be forced to do so. Almost two in three people surveyed (64%) also approve of the Government collecting child maintenance and then paying it directly to the child's supporting parent.

In a sense, that answers Senator Walters's question. Questions are put to people and they answer in the context of a series of steps which need to be taken. It is not merely the inadequacy of the $20 rule of thumb, it is the matter of compliance with and enforcement of the order which is also perceived by the public to be very important. We need to pay attention to that. It may also be of interest to know that the following question was put to the respondents to the gallup poll:

In some countries, child maintenance is collected through the Tax Department. The Government directs the employer to deduct the maintenance from the parent's pay each week. The Government then pays the maintenance directly to the child's supporting parent. They were then asked `Do you approve or disapprove of the Government collecting child maintenance?'
. . . 64 per cent of those surveyed said they approve of the Government collecting child maintenance, while 16% disapprove and 7% can't say.

Once again, that is an important indication of what the Australian community now perceives to be necessary in a move away from court-based compliance and enforcement strategy to one that uses administrative procedures. I keep emphasising this because I believe that it is important. I will return to it. Let us look at the Bill. Senator Durack purports to tackle some of the legislative mechanisms which are said to have encouraged this situation to develop. I am greatly attracted to the principal amendment, clause 3 (1). Proposed new sub-section (3) in part states:

The Court shall not take into account . . . the eligibility of a party to a marriage claiming main- tenance . . . for a pension, allowance or benefit under the Social Security Act 1947 or the Repatriation Act 1920 . . . but shall determine the proceedings as if there were no such eligibility--

when awarding maintenance. On the whole, that is a principle to which I am attracted but in my view it ought to be stressed that that clause emphasises an approach which the better judges anyway of the Family Court of Australia take to be the law. For example, Mr Justice Fogarty in a celebrated judgment in F and F (1982) FLC *91-214 stated:

The problem arises from other payments (such as widow's and supporting parent's pensions). There a good deal of pragmatism is required because of the divergencies of fact which arise in individual cases and also it needs realistically to be taken into account that two family units frequently impose financial burdens which one income is unable to carry. The community in those circumstances may be obligated in the interests of its members, but more particularly the children, to shoulder part of the burden. But to say that is not to overlook the fundamental circumstance that the primary responsibility for maintenance is that of the respondent, that is the other spouse or parent as the case may be in an individual case. To the extent that that respondent is able to contribute out of his or her own income or other financial resources maintenance for the support of the other spouse or children then he should be ordered to do so.

That statement by Mr Justice Fogarty, which I know is followed by Mr Justice Wood in Tasmania, really indicates the situation although there is an element of discretion which the clarification in this Bill-which is how I would describe this clause of the Bill-would do away with. It would make it very clear where the primary obligation falls and where the community obligation comes in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not just pass the Bill?

—Please allow me to develop my remarks. I think that I have been rather generous so far. I now move to those clauses which I do not find quite so attractive. For example, proposed new sub-section (4) contained in clause 3 (1) requires the court to give priority to:

SPEECH.PARA: The needs of a party to the marriage or of a child of the marriage over responsibilities or commitments assumed since the marriage as is just and reasonable in all the circumstances.

As I understand, particularly from Senator Durack's second reading speech, it is really designed to give priority in the disposal of income of a non-custodial parent to the first family over the current-second-family situation in which that person finds himself. I find it difficult to find satisfaction in the notion that the Parliament should assume that one can ignore the requirements of the new dependent wife and children.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes against nature, does it not?

—I find it difficult to understand why Australia should not allow deduction for current dependants. No other country, by the way, with similar legislation does that. As I understand it, this is what Senator Durack's Bill would bring about. The consequence could be that there would be two families in relative poverty. It seems to me that to deny support to a current wife and dependent children in favour of a former wife and dependent children in an absolute way, as seems to be envisaged by this clause, is to be too dogmatic. As Senator Missen said, it is perhaps even against the natural urges of a person in that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the Family Law Council which has suggested something along the same lines but to the effect that other financial obligations of the parents certainly should take second priority, in other words, payments for a hi-fi, a car, a holiday, a trip or whatever. The first priority for disposable income should be the support of both the current household and the spouse and children of the former marriage. The assertion in this clause that the first family should always have priority over the current family in the distribution of the disposable income of the non-custodial parent does not seem to me to be very wise.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about step-children of the second marriage?
—Senator Durack is bringing in even more complications. There is another clause in the Bill that I find not particularly attractive in its absolute status or approach. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A maintenance agreement made after the date of commencement of this sub-section shall not make provision . . . as regards the rights of a party in respect of the maintenance of a child of the marriage.

It cannot be denied and it is a fact that many of these agreements amounted to sweetheart deals which were designed, among other things, to maximise pension entitlement and to bring about a situation in which a court-approved agreement denied a reasonable contribution to the maintenance of the former spouse and dependent children. Once again, the Family Law Council has come up with a better suggestion, namely, that if one were to legislate in this area, one would require the court to ensure that a balance is achieved between the public interest and the interests of the parties. Clearly, the public interest does not lie in the maximisation of pension entitlements and the abdication of responsibility by the non-custodial parent to provide reasonable sums of money for the preservation, if possible, of a reasonable standard of living for the former spouse and dependent children. To exclude altogether from such agreements any arrangement in respect of maintenance seems to me to be too draconian. It should also be noted that a matrimonial property inquiry is being conducted at the moment by Professor David Hambly of the Australian Law Reform Commission, which is expected to report in the middle of the year and which will deal very much with these sorts of matters. I think it would be wise for the Senate to await the report on that matter.

Finally, the increased use of imprisonment in this Bill as the sole offering as a means of securing compliance with and enforcement of maintenance orders seems to me to reveal something of the inadequacy of the approach of the Bill. Senator Durack, in his second reading speech, quite freely admits that in this respect the Bill is deficient. It certainly is because it seems that the purpose of the deletion of section 107 of the principal Act is to bring about a situation in which a person could be imprisoned for simple default in maintenance payments. I can understand imprisonment being retained as a last resort to be used against somebody who wilfully and persistently is in contempt of court in refusing to go along with repeated injunctions by the court to make payments. But to present a Bill to the Senate, when there is widespread discussion in the community about the means of compliance and enforcement, and to rely simply on imprisonment as the means which the Senate should endorse, seems to me to be totally inadequate. It seems to me that, if one could locate a defaulting person in order to imprison that person, it would be far better in the normal run of events to leave that person in the community to earn a wage or salary so that that person could make a contribution to the former spouse and dependent children. It seems to me to be too draconian a means of compliance and enforcement.

As I showed in my reference to the gallup poll, 64 per cent of Australians are prepared to countenance a situation in which the Government, through the Australian Taxation Office, would use administrative means to take money weekly from the pay packet of a person against whom a maintenance order is made, or who has entered into some maintenance agreement. This seems to be one possibility, although I do not say that it will necessarily turn out to be the preferred option.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Government has spent three years talking about doing something like this.

—Yes, various models have been put forward. One suggestion has been the maintenance collection and enforcement agency, which seems to me to be a very costly and cumbersome creature. I am certainly not convinced that that is the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The New Zealand model is sometimes put forward. As I understand it, it is called a liable benefit contribution scheme and the beneficiaries get a particular benefit. Under the scheme, the state collects money from the liable parent but the money goes directly into Consolidated Revenue. There is a breaking of the link between the liable parent, the non-custodial parent, and the household to whose maintenance the person should be making a contribution. That scheme does not appeal to me very greatly. But the idea that maintenance should be collected automatically out of income, like a tax-not simply by garnisheeing wages which is normally done after some history of default, but right from the start, every week, so that the tax system is used to take money out of the pay packet of the person against whom the order is made-seems to me to be a very sensible and efficient means of ensuring the enforcement of maintenance orders.

It is fair to say that among those possibilities there are at least some options that ought to be considered by the Senate before it gives its imprimatur to this Bill, which would lead to an impression in the community that the Senate is so bereft of ideas that it has resorted to imprisonment of defaulters as the sole means of dealing with this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Senate could not actually set up a scheme requiring further government expenditure, like the tax one. The Government would have to co-operate.

—I agree that there are some difficulties, But, as I understand it, this Bill has the status of a private member's Bill. As I understand it, therefore, it is not a government Bill; also I would be interested to hear whether it has the status of a Bill endorsed in its entirety by the joint party room of the coalition parties.
—Of course it is. It is our policy.
—No, it is not.
—That does not matter. We have a constitutional problem about introducing legislation to set up a new burden on the people, have we not?

—I did not see anything in the second reading speech which indicated which of those various other models Senator Durack would prefer, in supplement to imprisonment, if that is what he is saying. From the dispute on the Opposition backbench at the moment, it is not clear to me whether this is merely Senator Durack's Bill or whether it comes from the coalition as an endorsed project. But I am not here to go into that. I do not want to score political points.

SPEECH.PARA: My point is that the first and basic principle which I think Senator Durack has tried to incorporate and embody in the first clause of his Bill is something which on the whole many members of this chamber would be attracted to but I do not believe that the Bill as a whole deserves the support of the chamber at this moment. I believe it would be fair to leave it to the Cabinet, which has publicly stated that it has set itself a three-month task to determine the best means of dealing with this problem. Dr Meredith Edwards has been seconded to the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in order to do further work on this project. We know that these things are going on. It is good that the Senate should, as it will do in the course of this debate, express its concern about and support for the principle in a non-partisan way. As to the machinery to be adopted, it would be of greater service to the community if the Senate were to have the benefit of further deliberation and consideration of this matter.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill is a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Durack in an attempt to reflect the community's attitude to family responsibilities. I was particularly interested in Senator Tate's speech because in Tasmania in October last year Senator Tate advocated changes to the Family Law Act along the lines of this Bill. It was then that I explained to him, through the newspaper, that he had voted against the amendments put up by Senator Durack in September 1983. However, he now agrees with the amendments and agrees basically with Senator Durack's Bill. Senator Tate's speech tonight was an attempt to hide behind the fact that Senator Durack did not spell out exactly what system of maintenance should be implemented. Senator Durack pointed out that the Senate was not the place to put forward such changes and that the Government should formulate a maintenance policy. His Bill specifically asks the Government to take a step in that direction. Senator Tate admitted tonight that he was in favour of such a step, so I do not understand why he is rejecting the Bill. He quoted from the Bulletin, which indicates that 75 per cent of the community says that, as a general rule, the parents of the children should take responsibility for the maintenance and bringing up of children and that, in the case of divorce when custody is awarded to one parent, both parents should equally be responsible for the bringing up of the children.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Act, introduced in those heady days of Mr Whitlam and Senator Murphy in 1975, certainly has a lot of problems attached to it. Until recently we never had the violence that has been directed to judges of the Family Court of Australia. We are all well aware that there has always been bitterness in this area but the violence that has recently erupted as a result of decisions made by the Family Court is a great problem. It is seen by the community as a whole as an area that needs much attention. Senator Durack's Bill is one step towards fixing just one of the problems. As I said earlier, in September 1983 Senator Durack put up amendments to the Family Law Act, but they were voted against by both the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. Yet now Senator Tate says that he is rather attracted to Senator Durack's Bill but, although he supported these ideas in the Mercury back home, evidently he is not attracted enough to vote for the Bill. I challenged him at that time and he has not taken up the challenge.

Since the introduction of the Family Law Act supporting parents benefit payments have increased tremendously, but that area alone does not give the whole picture. We must also look at class A widows. In the ten years from 30 June 1974 to 30 June 1984, in the class A widows section, the number of divorced wives with dependent children receiving pensions has gone up 255.4 per cent. Deserted wives with dependent children also come under the class A widows category. The supporting parent's benefit group is the one we usually refer to, and the figures for those separated wives receiving a supporting parents benefit has gone up 782.3 per cent, from 9,442 to 83,305. Ten years ago the supporting parent's benefit did not apply to husbands but now nearly 9,000 men receive it. The number of beneficiaries formerly in de facto relationships has also gone up incredibly, by 481 per cent from 3,160 to 18,381. The costs are quite incredible. In constant 1983-84 dollars supporting parent's benefit payments went up from $115m on 30 June 1974 to $889.6m on 30 June 1984-an increase of 673 per cent. According to the Institute of Family Studies the figure is now $1 billion. Also receiving payments is a small group of just on 43,000 never-married mothers-it is not usually understood that that group is so small. Payments to them, along with payments to others in the family break up category, went from $281.8m in 1974 to $1,247.4m in 1984. That is the cost, in pensions alone, of family breakup.

Those figures have been disturbing us in government and in opposition, and because of those great increases in costs this Government has now become interested. These higher costs and the attitudes that have developed since those heady times of the early 1970s have been encouraged by legislation because section 75 of the Family Law Act says that judges, when considering the maintenance of children, must take into consideration the eligibility of either partner to a social security pension or benefit. Consequently, judgments now require husbands to pay just enough maintenance so that wives' entitlements to social security are not affected. The result is that the taxpayer picks up the tab which in many cases should have remained the responsibility of the parents.

As Senator Tate indicated in his speech, we have a whole new group of poor people. Single parents-usually single mothers-are not being paid any additional money by the other spouse for looking after children. We have figures which show that 40 per cent never pay maintenance and 20 per cent pay only partial maintenance. Indeed, the Family Court estimates that the figure is not a combination of that-60 per cent-but that 70 per cent of parents who should be paying maintenance never pay it. So we have a situation where large numbers of mothers with dependent children are now very poor and are surviving on the supporting parents benefit. There are, of course, cases of hardship. Those cases of hardship certainly should be getting social security. There is no reason why the taxpayer should not be supporting those children. But in those cases where the father is well off financially there is no reason why he should not support them. As I have said, Senator Durack's Bill is trying to overcome those trendy attitudes of the early 1970s and get back to the family responsibility that 75 per cent of the community believes we should get back to.

As a member of the joint parliamentary committee which reviewed the Family Law Act I know that we discussed this matter very thoroughly. Indeed, an argument put to us as to why the taxpayer should pick up the Bill on all occasions was that there would be security in regular payments to the mothers; that they should not have to wait for maintenance to be paid by husbands who were either late in paying or just did not pay at all. Another argument was that if access was not a happy affair a father would refuse to pay and just say: `If I cannot have as much access as I want I will not pay for the bringing up of the children'.

When I asked Justice Evatt what possible reason there could be for the husband not to support his children she said that the second relationship should not be hurt in any way. She said that, if a husband takes on a second relationship following a breakdown in his marriage and a divorce, he should be able to freely look after that second family and that relationship should not be interfered with. When I said that surely he should think about that before absolving himself of his first lot of responsibilities, the judge thought that that was a ridiculous statement. So the taxpayer is expected to foot the bill. Many women object very strongly to being reliant on the taxpayer. They say that their husbands can well afford to look after the children and support them while they are bringing up the children. Indeed, they say that he is just having a good time and living in a very high fashion while allowing the taxpayer to take over his responsibilities.

Senator Tate said that this matter has been debated in the community for several years. As I have said, in September 1983 Senator Durack put up amendments which the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats voted against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just that one amendment which Senator Tate says he now supports.

—This is what I said earlier. Senator Tate has now said that it is a very good idea but he voted against it on that occasion. He is suddenly seeing the light but he still will not vote for it in this Bill. He is at liberty to make some amendments and we can look at the amendments but he is not prepared to do that. I am afraid that he has been caucused and will vote according to party lines even though he has expounded his own private opinions in the Mercury. But I have already gone into that.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of explanation, I have not been caucused on this. I made my remarks of my own free will.
—Then all I can say is that Senator Tate's statements in the Mercury are at complete variance with what he has told us he is going to do tonight.
—How do you know what I am going to do tonight?

—Senator Tate may be voting with us, and I sincerely hope that he will. I take him up on that interjection. I sincerely hope that he will cross the floor and vote according to his conscience. We, as a committee, put forward a recommendation to the government of the day that the Department of Social Security should assess the ability of a spouse to pay maintenance and that the Social Security Department should pay the maintenance and collect what it thought was a fair thing from the spouse who should be paying the maintenance. The Family Law Council has put forward a recommendation. It said that the Australian Taxation Office should make the claim. The Institute of Family Studies also put forward the suggestion that the Taxation Office should pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago the Government set up a national maintenance committee and it came out with a report. I do not blame Senator Tate for saying that its recommendation was something he would not agree with because I would not agree with it either, but that committee recommended the setting up of a complete Commonwealth authority at a cost of $2m and, guess what, an annual running cost of an additional $13m. I do not blame Senator Tate for saying that. I am sure that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, would have something to say about that, too, if he were here, as it could be done very successfully by either the Taxation Office or the Social Security Department.

Senator Tate spoke about the provision in Senator Durack's Bill which refers to the fact that there should be no prison sentence for default. The Family Law Act states that there should be no prison sentence for default. Senator Tate has criticised the part of Senator Durack's Bill that states that that should be reintroduced. He said: `If they were in prison they could not earn the money anyway and therefore there was not much point in sending them there'. He would know the practical situation because he is a lawyer, even though I do not think he has practised law privately. That situation is that if one says to a man `You are behind in your payments to the tune of $X and unless you pay up, mate, you will go to gaol', the man suddenly finds the money and pays up; he does not go to gaol. The garnisheeing of wages is a possibility but none of these things is entered into seriously. Indeed, the Family Law Act abolished the provision that allowed for the gaoling of someone who defaulted on making maintenance payments.
I was interested to hear Senator Tate agreeing that a prison sentence should be available for legitimate cases as a last resort-I think those were the words he used-for people who deliberately--

TALK.START.PARA: —Persistently.

—For people who persistently and deliberately refused to pay maintenance. All I am asking Senator Tate to do is to make a small amendment if he does not like Senator Durack's exact words. He should put forward his amendment and we will see whether we can accept it. He agrees that the family should accept responsibility. Perhaps I should read from Senator Tate's news release in the Mercury. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ordinary taxpayer is having to pick up the tab for a partner who won't come to the party on maintenance . . .
The limits of tolerance have been reached and Parliament must change the Family Law Act to reflect this.
The article in the Mercury continued:
Senator Tate said that the first claim for maintenance should be on the resources of the non-custodial parent, and that social service benefits should be seen by the courts as `a last resort'.

I wrote to say that I was interested to see Senator Tate advocating a change in the provisions of the Family Law Act which requires the court to take into account the fact that a parent should look after the child. In a letter I challenged Senator Tate to vote with us because, I pointed out, he had voted against that very thing in 1983. I also pointed out that we would be bringing the matter up, and indeed that Senator Durack was already framing a Billl. I said that the Bill would be brought up in February and that it would give Senator Tate the opportunity to vote. I shall be most interested to see which way Senator Tate votes tonight. I know that he always votes according to conscience. I admire that unusual streak in a member of the Australian Labor Party.

This is the very first step in the change to the Family Law Act. It is a step in the right direction-a direction that even the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, has been advocating. The Family Court, or at least some Family Court judges, has been advocating this for quite some time. If all these reputable bodies, including the Family Law Council, the Institute of Family Studies and the national maintenance organisation which was set up by the Government, say that it is imperative that something be done about the position, surely Labor senators will vote for the first step in that process, a process put in train by Senator Durack tonight. I assure Senator Tate that this will be watched very carefully by all Tasmanians, by the Mercury editors and by the journalists who have printed his stuff in the past. They will be watching carefully to see how he votes on this occasion tonight.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill is a private member's Bill which has been introduced by Senator Durack and which makes a valiant attempt to correct some of the problems inherent in the Family Law Act with regard to the provision of maintenance following the breakdown of marriage. Among other things the Bill would amend the Family Law Act 1975 to prevent the Family Court in determining a person's liability to pay maintenance from taking into account the eligibility of a party to the marriage for any benefit under the Social Security Act 1947 or the Repatriation Act 1920. This part of the Bill has caused considerable concern to some people who believe that in an attempt to ensure that the custodial parent has regular income, judges are taking into account the custodial parent's access to social security benefits under the supporting parents benefit and then using maintenance from the non-custodial parent as a sort of top-up measure. Many people in the community rightly believe that it would be more equitable if the reverse were the case, namely, if the non-custodial parent were to accept a primary responsibility for contributing to the maintenance of the children and the social security department were left to pick up any excess.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill would also give the obligation to maintain a spouse and children from a former marriage priority over obligations subsequently acquired, whether by a subsequent marriage or by entry into a de facto relationship. Again, a large number of people in the community believe that a person's responsibility for their children does not end when the marriage ends and that some acknowledgement should be made of the children that result from a first marriage. Certainly it becomes particularly ludicrous when not only does the non-custodial parent's responsibility to, say, a second family get taken into account but when that person's responsibility in other economic areas is considered-for example, when a commitment to a finance company is taken into account. It is possible therefore for some non-custodial parents who want to pay very limited maintenance to run themselves up a sizable financial burden on their incomes and have that taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the step-children of a second marriage who may have a non-custodial parent who should be looking after them?

—Indeed, it can ripple out across the board, as Senator Durack implies, but, as Senator Tate said, it becomes particularly ludicrous when hire-purchase agreements for cars, boats and videos are also taken into account as an excuse, shall we say, for not expecting the non-custodial parent to pay a reasonable amount towards the upkeep of the children from an early marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: The third element in the Bill seeks to prevent court-approved maintenance agreements being used as a mechanism to evade the obligation to pay maintenance for the children of a marriage. Indeed, we have all heard of numerous occasions when tidying agreements have been reached between departments of the marriage that has been or is being dissolved so that the non-custodial parent, for example, picks up the tab for the children's private school education, or the tab for the mortgage on the house in which the custodial parent and the children are to reside, or that the non-custodial parent will provide the custodial parent with a new car on the dissolution of a marriage, which from that point onward would limit the financial assistance in terms of actual cash to a minimum. This is encouraged by the fact not only that courts take into account the availability of social security payments to the custodial parent but also that the taxation office regards maintenance payments as income and therefore as eligible to be taxed. It is therefore in the interests, particularly of wealthy families, for non-cash arrangements to be agreed on by the parties concerned which then leaves the taxpayer picking up the tab.

Finally, the Bill intends to amend the Family Law Act 1975 to enable persons to be imprisoned for failure to comply with maintenance orders. Frankly, I share Senator Tate's concern that that is a rather illogical and futile position to be taking as it gets us back to a Dickensian situation whereby people were put into gaol and debtors' prisons simply because they had run up debts which they could not pay on demand. While they were in prison, of course, they were not in any position to earn any money in order to pay off the first lot of debts, so they stayed there indefinitely. Indeed, Dickens and a number of his contemporaries suffered that fate for some time. So there is certainly very real concern about the fourth part of Senator Durack's Bill. Certainly, most people in the community and, I imagine, most people on both sides of this chamber would agree with the general principles expressed in Senator Durack's Bill, even if they do not necessarily agree with the method by which Senator Durack is going about correcting an increasingly concerning problem.

There is a very real concern in the community about the poverty in which many women and children are currently living following marital breakdowns because their ex-husbands, the ex-fathers, are defaulting maintenance payers and the social security benefit is particularly low. Furthermore, having got themselves into the situation of being reliant almost entirely on social welfare payments and very limited maintenance, if it is forthcoming, they are immediately prevented from lifting themselves out of that poverty trap by being able to get into the work force. Even though the Government has allegedly moved to eliminate poverty traps by raising the exempt income level, it is very difficult for most women who have dependent children to look after to get above it. There are very few part time jobs around and certainly a very limited number of permanent part time jobs. Even if they were available, accessible child care is just as limited. Women who are able to get part time child care are in a minority. It is extremely expensive in comparison with full time child care. Either way, they are going to lose.

There is growing concern in the community, too, about the increasing number of non-custodial parents-mainly male-who are flouting their responsibilities and the law and getting away with it. They are getting away with it for a number of reasons. First, whilst the courts are extremely anxious to enforce access orders, they are a little less enthusiastic, it seems to me, and it certainly seems to those people who are on the receiving end of all this, to enforce maintenance orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Their powers are restricted.

—That is certainly true. Nevertheless, it takes a woman who is owed maintenance quite a considerable amount of trouble to try to get an order enforced, and not just an amount of trouble, but a large amount of cost.
—Because their powers aren't adequate.
—Certainly.
—If you supported this Bill the powers would be much greater and much more simple.

—I am coming to that. Do not rush me. The fact is that at the moment it is extremely difficult for these women to get maintenance orders enforced. They are very rarely entitled to legal aid. By the time they have been to and from several lawyers it is economically non-viable, to use a fairly unpleasant expression, to proceed any further. The experience of the women who come and see me indicates that men are very rarely absolute defaulters in the sense that they never pay any money. In the main they are, shall we say, malicious or nuisance non-payers of maintenance in that they have a tendency to hold off payment of maintenance until they are about to get into serious difficulty. They then pay enough to get out of it and the whole cycle starts again. In the meantime, their ex-spouses have given up trying to get orders enforced and are struggling as best they can on the supporting parent's benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: There are men who disappear entirely, change their names, move to another State and so on, but they are in the minority. I gather that they are the people whom the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, and other enthusiastic supporters of identity cards are aiming at. However, I suggest that if Dr Blewett thinks he is going to stop the process of maintenance defaulting through the identity card, he has rocks in his head, because simply identifying somebody is not going to make him pay up. So there is no doubt at all that there is a very real problem in the community, both for those who are on the receiving end of the supporting parent's benefit and what little they can get from the non-custodial parent and for those who believe that their taxpayer's money is being, if not misused, at least perhaps excessively or unnecessarily used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Less than adequately.

—Less than adequately and certainly less than equitably, when one considers that most women would probably be better off if the defaulting parent paid a fair share into the first family's economy because that is commensurate with the responsibility that defaulting parent should have for the children of the marriage.
—Wouldn't it be a good idea to accept the recommendations of our Committee that said that social welfare should assess the ability of the spouse to pay?

—I am just about to come to a system which has been mentioned tonight and which I think perhaps we ought to give a little more attention to before we rush into anything else. I refer to the much talked about New Zealand system whose social security people assess-in concern and after discussion and consultation with everybody else concerned; it is not some sort of dictatorial thing-what the non-custodial parent is entitled to bear by way of financial responsibility. Some time down the track, if circumstances change significantly, there can be a request for reassessment. What happens in that instance is that, once the assessment is made about the capacity of the non-custodial parent to pay, the Taxation Office effectively takes over. The money is then deducted from the salary or wage of the maintenance payer-as is tax, contributions to health funds and insurance companies and all the deductions that many of us have taken out of our salaries-paid along with tax into Consolidated Revenue, and goes back to the custodial parent. The scheme has been operating in New Zealand since April 1981. Its predecessors go back to 1973. It operates concurrently with the private law main- tenance scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: In New Zealand income support for lone parents-that is custodial parents with dependent children-who are not able to support themselves and who are not receiving maintenance through the private legal system comes in the form of what is known in New Zealand as a domestic purposes benefit which is essentially for the purposes of this debate equivalent to the supporting parent's benefit. To qualify for the domestic purposes benefit the mother or father of each child in the custody of the applicant must be identified in law. So safeguards are built into the system. The non-custodial parent is then required to contribute to the cost of the domestic purposes benefit. The scheme, which was referred to earlier by Senator Tate, is called the liable parent contribution scheme. Maintenance orders are suspended during payment of the domestic purposes benefit and the liable parent contribution scheme comes into effect. Once a liable parent is identified that person has to reveal full financial details to the Department of Social Welfare. The Department then assesses the level of contribution applicable in terms of the New Zealand Social Security Act. Contributions never exceed the level of benefits paid. Care costs of living are taken into account for the liable parent and a minimum contribution of $15 applies. It seems to me that the New Zealand system is a particularly simple system and one that Australia could look a little more seriously at adopting since the only people who are able to avoid payment are those who cross the Tasman. Of course that will happen whatever system we operate under. At least this one gives the maintenance paying parent less discretion about whether that parent will or will not pay all or some of the maintenance on time. Therefore it makes for a much more stable living situation for the custodial parent and the children.

Comment was made earlier about the fact that this Government has done nothing in order to combat the problem of maintenance defaulters. I remind the Senate that something like 12 months ago the Bankruptcy Act was amended so that people who were owed maintenance were classified as creditors and this has been of some use to some women. For example, I have had cases of women writing to me complaining that their husbands are being very tardy, not to say unenthusiastic and unco-operative, about paying the maintenance that is due and they are doing things like rearranging their business affairs and then threatening to have themselves declared bankrupt. The last letter I received on this matter was about three months after we had passed the amendment to the Bankruptcy Act that allowed women who were owed maintenance to be classified as creditors. I wrote back with some glee to the lady concerned and said: `Don't wait for him to declare himself a bankrupt. He is probably only bluffing you anyway in order to encourage you to stop pestering him. Just write to him, let him know that the Bankruptcy Act has been changed and tell him that if he does not come good with the money, you will petition for his bankruptcy'. The Senate will not be at all surprised to know that that matter was satisfactorily sorted out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a few threats have always worked wonders.

—They do in all sorts of circumstances. I go back to the concerns that have been expressed by everybody who has spoken so far this evening. Maintenance is reaching a position where governments will have to adopt quite stringent methods to make sure that not only is maintenance paid when it is due but also that a reasonable amount of maintenance, under whatever the circumstances are, is paid and that the social security system is not relied on absolutely as a first port of call, so to speak, for family income support after a marriage has broken down. I am not by any means sure that Senator Durack's Bill is the right way to go about it. I am certainly not happy about the enablement of persons to be imprisoned for their failure to comply with maintenance orders.
—A very effective method.
—It is a fairly effective deterrent, I would certainly agree. However, I am at a loss to understand how people can raise the money once they are imprisoned.
—They don't go in any more than they go bankrupt.

—It is almost the equivalent of bankruptcy but one has to realise that the custodial parent has to go through some quite long and expensive procedures to get a person in that state, I suggest longer and more expensive procedures than they are currently forced to go through. However having said that I have to say that Senator Durack is to be commended for the concern he has shown about this issue. He has had the time and the patience to put together some sort of solution to this problem even if it is not one with which everybody agrees. As I have said I would prefer, as a first instance, for this country to look at the New Zealand system. It is simple; it involves consultation between all parties; it provides the social security system as a backup but it places the primary responsibility for the care of children on both parents and does not allow the one who does not have custody of the children to escape that responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Family Law Amendment Bill which amends the Family Law Act 1975. Senator Durack's private member's Bill is designed to overcome one of the big problems that are in this law. We do not disagree about the problem; we disagree about the solution. A solution of a failure to pay maintenance has been sought in many countries which have the same problems but they have not yet achieved an agreeable solution. Maintenance is one aspect of the Family Law Act which is obviously not working satisfactorily. There have been many other problems in the early stages of the Act because I think some attempt was made to implement it `on the cheap'. A lack of judges, a lack of suitable premises and many other problems led to early difficulties, but they have largely been overcome. However, maintenance remains an outstanding one, one which has worried those who have been interested in this subject for quite a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to demonstrate to honourable senators that it is not just a question of the enforcement of maintenance; the whole problem is also one of the assessment and collection of maintenance. The whole system has broken down. Undoubtedly there are a great number of cases where maintenance orders are not met and where people are flouting the obligations which they could, by any reason, pay. The result of all this is that something like $500m is paid out in social security payments to deserted wives for themselves and children, and that amount is unquestionably too great. It could be and would be reduced if maintenance payments were enforced better.

The 1980 report of the Joint Committee on the Family Law Act completed a lengthy investigation of this matter. The all-party Committee considered the problem and the solution which Senator Durack has now put forward but it did not favour it. However, it affirmed that a maximum of nearly 40 per cent of Australian orders are fully complied with and that from the very start somewhere near 40 per cent of Australian orders were never paid at all. So the non-payment of maintenance orders has been occurring to a very considerable degree. As the orders have got older compliance has been worse, and that factor is found regularly throughout Australia. The fact is that no simple solution we find will cure this situation entirely; there will always be some people who refuse to pay maintenance. Studies in other countries indicate, in a rough fashion, the presence in each system of a large and irreducible group of cases where support from the absent father is not and will not be forthcoming. That appeared in a study by one Mary Anne Glendon in 1981. The survey also shows that a great deal of poverty is involved in single parent families who are often forced to rely on pensions and do not get any contributions from absent husbands who could well pay. In 1981-82, up to 60 per cent of all single parent families had incomes below the poverty line, an increase of 38 per cent over 1978-79 figures. So the position has been getting increasingly worse.

Moreover, in an international comparison, taking Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures on government assistance given to families with children, Australia ranks fifteenth out of 19 developed countries. This, of course, justifies the conclusion which the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act drew, that `persons without adequate means of support should be entitled to sustenance from the state to the extent of their need'. So we will not eliminate the need for some sustenance. It is people in this situation who often suffer from poverty and this makes it all the more important that the assessment of maintenance and collection of it is taken into account, not just the enforcement of it.

If one looks at it in a different way, widows class A pension recipients are very often deserted wives and likewise for the supporting parent's benefits. In August 1975, not long ago, only 25 per cent were receiving maintenance from a non-custodial parent, so there is a very considerable need in those cases for people to receive more income from their husband or spouse.

Another important factor to bear in mind is a survey which McDonald of the Institute of Family Studies made in 1985, which showed that 77 per cent of female sole parents were worse off than they had been at the time of separation by a factor of $78 a week. In contrast, 75 per cent of unre-partnered men who were living alone when interviewed were better off financially than they had been prior to separation by a factor of $72 per week. So there is a very considerable difference, to the detriment of wives and of children, who are generally with wives, following a separation.

These are important factors which we must bear in mind when looking at this problem. We must consider whether the solutions proposed, for example, in this private member's Bill are adequate or whether the many other suggestions should also be considered. I have here piles of documents which I have studied for a considerable time and which bring forward various suggestions. But let us look first at the four proposals in the Durack Bill. Frankly, I do not find them adequate to cover the situation which we have before us. One of the suggestions, which was also put forward before the Joint Committee but which was not accepted by it, is similar to an amendment moved in 1983 when amendments to the Family Law Bill were made, to the effect that we should substantially delete the clause which allows a reliance on social security so that that could be taken into account by people making maintenance orders. Certainly the terms set out in this Bill are a little different from that, but it is basically the same proposition, which I did not then find acceptable and which I do not find acceptable now.

It seems to me that to wipe out that consideration may well lead to larger maintenance orders, but large orders may well lead to more people going to north Queensland, the north of Western Australia and the more remote parts of Australia, and to more husbands who no longer take any interest in their families. There is, economically, no reason why they should stay around when they cannot, they may feel, meet the payments and are not prepared to do so. That important fact of life must be taken into account. There is no point in making a decision on this Bill or any Bill which punishes the children and does not punish the parents-because the children will be punished if in fact more parents are not around to give some assistance and guidance to the children in their early years. Such a person might not be a very good husband and might not be very good at paying maintenance, but if he is around the children do have a better chance of a normal and stable upbringing.

I find that the proposal to remove this clause to say that account will not be taken of social security is not adequate at all. A better suggestion is made by the National Maintenance Inquiry which suggested the amendment of section 75 (2) (f), the taking into account of social security, by inserting such words as `with a view to ensuring that resort to social security eligibility in reducing the quantum of maintenance is only to be had where the total resources available to the respondent are inadequate to meet the need of the applicant without causing the respondent financial hardship'. In other words, it is a more limited method-if the spouse has the means, one does not take any account of the social security benefit, but one does where he does not have the means.

What I am suggesting in the whole of this speech is that we should not want to pass any such Bills at the moment, but we should really investigate and put together the ideas that have come forward and see what is the best of all solutions. That is the first proposal which is in the Bill. The second is a proposal which I think has not been mentioned tonight, except by Senator Tate. That is that section 87 agreements should not include any reference to maintenance. This is putting the cart before the horse. What has gone wrong is that, under the implementation of the Act, we did not put into the hands of the Family Court, with the counsellors, the financial advisers and other people, these questions of the approval of maintenance agreements and maintenance orders. They are to be done by any magistrate-a magistrate who has no expert assistance whatsoever. It is true that he gets constantly put before him agreements which are convenient for the parties. The husband may give property to the wife-he may give a car, he may give other things-but give her the minimum amount of maintenance so that she has the maximum of social service benefits. Of course, those things should not be approved. The answer is not to say that they cannot be approved, but to say that the right body should be approving them. That body is, of course, the Family Court. I proposed this in the minority report which I made to the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, the idea was floated by the Family Law Council and was supported by the Law Council of Australia and by the judges of the Family Court. It has never been put into force, and it is a disgrace, in my opinion, that that has never been done. In my consideration, it is a much better solution than the solution that is in this Bill-namely, that we cannot allow child maintenance in agreements that are approved.

The third of the proposals made is the idea that the responsibilities of maintenance shall be taken ino account only for the first family and not for the second family. To suggest that somehow this will work and that people who have left the first family and are living with another family, having re-married and then had other children, will somehow not provide for sub- sequent children goes against any sense of nature. One may say that the first family deserves quite a bit of encouragement and ought to have some preference. Perhaps that is so. But let us look at what happens in other countries in the world, because it is not as though we have the last word in understanding in this matter. The overseas practices vary tremendously. In the United States of America, legislation generally reflects priority for the first family, although the actual practice is quite different. It does not work out that way in practice. In New Zealand, on the other hand, the legislation explicitly allows for liability for non-custodial parents to support earlier children to be reduced as new responsibilities are taken on. I think it is reasonable that they should be reduced where that is a responsibility for the upkeep of children. As Senator Tate and others have said, it is not right that people should be buying expensive items and putting those things ahead of their later responsibilities. But in New Zealand, it is a matter where obviously there can be change. In Sweden, the principles are that every child of a taxpayer has a claim to an equal treatment and where the non-custodial parent's means are limited, priority of claim is given to the children of the current family. So there is no uniformity around the world on this matter.

I think it is unwise to rush into a situation in which we may find that we are imposing orders that are too great where orders are to pay full amounts for the first child and therefore the husband cannot pay for the maintenance of his wife and children. It is punishment for the children of the second marriage. Recently, in Sweden and the United Kingdom in particular, there has been great concern that the amounts of child maintenance have been set too high and that they are possibly jeopardising the viability of the current family. So we would have not only one destroyed family but a second destroyed family if we pursued this line. Therefore, one has to be very careful before that idea is taken up.

The fourth proposal is the suggestion of a general right of imprisonment instead of imprisonment for contempt, for example, for wilfully failing to pay a maintenance order. This would revert us to the pre-1975 situation. I sat on the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee when it considered the Bill at that time and I remember that people who gave evidence before us variously described the imprisonment of people as contrary to human rights, a barbarous practice and an evil extreme of sex discrimination. Senator Durack and others have said tonight that if imprisonment is threatened, people will comply.

I practised in this jurisdiction for 25 years before I came into this place and I know that many people went to gaol determined not to pay and others disappeared because there was a great risk of imprisonment. Therefore, one must be very careful before we revert to what was a very bad system in the pre-1975 situation. It is true that a court can punish for deliberate dis- obedience and it is true that this power is under-utilised at present and should be utilised more; but the National Maintenance Inquiry, which considered this matter at length, did not favour that and thought that contempt proceedings should be more widely availed of. It did not believe that there should be a general recommendation of imprisonment for failure to pay.

Although the object is desirable, and we all agree on that, I do not think that the proposals in the Bill are the solution. I propose to go now to the other matters which have been suggested as solutions because I think it is desirable to lay them before the Senate. I will move an amendment later suggesting that all these things be considered by a Senate committee because I do not think we should resolve on one only solution tonight. The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act finally reported in 1980. Its report has never been fully implemented but, to the credit of Senator Gareth Evans, parts of its recommendations certainly have been. The recommendations in regard to maintenance were handed over to interdepartmental committees and lost in the sands of time.

A brief summary of the recommendations is as follows: Firstly, the establishment in the Department of Social Security of a national agency modelled on the Western Australian or South Australian enforcement agencies. I will come to that later because that is more extensively dealt with in the National Maintenance Inquiry. Secondly, the administrative assessment of maintenance rather than it being left at large at the discretion of a judge. There have been later studies which have indicated strong support of that by many experts. Thirdly, there were new provisions based largely on the New Zealand liable parents contribution scheme to enable the Department to assess maintenance payments to be made by a liable parent and to act directly to recover them. That is referred to later. That obviously finds commendation in the eyes of Senator Haines. I think a liable contribution may be part of the solution, but not the whole solution.
