Certainly it has some desirable effects. The Department of Social Security has shown little eagerness to have this responsibility and that is a problem. Lastly, the Joint Committee suggested various improvements in the method of enforcement provided under the Family Law Act and regulations, and a number of those were introduced. The recommendations have not been vigorously pursued by governments since that time and I think that is a great pity.

I will not go into the question of the liable parent benefit, which was an important part of the recommendations, as Senator Haines has dealt with that. I think that that, together with the suggestion that one may determine maintenance not by a judge's discretion but by an administrative formula, provides us with two recommendations that deserve very close attention. When the present Government came into power it appointed the National Maintenance Inquiry, which produced a report in 1984 entitled `A Maintenance Agency for Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fine report.

—I think it is a good report. We are in agreement on that. However, I do not understand why it was not debated in the other chamber and when it came into this chamber it was debated for only 10 minutes. Senator Haines was about the only person who made much of a contribution to it. I think that report, which is a massive report--
—Law reform is a bit unfashionable and I think we have to acknowledge that.

—I do not know that it is unfashionable. I regard this report as very informative as to what happens in other countries and what efforts they have made. It also recommends that there should be a separate national authority, one which would have the job of collection of maintenance and one which would have interstate connections. It is true, as someone said tonight, that it would cost about $13m a year, but it is estimated that it would save the Commonwealth $46,300,000 a year. Nobody can guarantee those figures but certainly it seems it would be a valuable thing. I notice there that we will not get rid of the $500m, no matter what we try, but I think we can get rid of quite a bit of payment, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, by a more effective method of doing this. The National Maintenance Inquiry also considered the idea of the taxation treatment of maintenance, which I believe is currently favoured by the Government and is being considered, but it did not find this a very desirable way of doing it. I will come to that matter in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The report has been attacked by a writer who said that it had very limited terms of reference. I think that is true. The writer said that the report did not offer a very cheap alternative, but to my mind it remains the best. I say that we must consider all the recommendations that have been made. There is then what one might call the child support tax-the proposal which was put forward in recommendations in two papers by Harrison, Harper and Edwards called `Child Support-Public or Private', and `Child Support; Obligations of Parents, State Responsibilities and the Rights of Children', both Institute of Family Studies works of last year.

These papers adopt a rather different method. They also point out the very low rate of maintenance. It is all right to say yes, take the maintenance orders, if in fact they are sufficient to keep the children in reasonable order. However, it is suggested by the survey by the Institute of Family Studies called `Economic Consequences of Marriage Break-down' that non-custodial parents in the lower income capacity were only contributing about 19 per cent of their income in child maintenance, those between $250 and $349 were only contributing 13 per cent, and above that even less. It suggested that there is also a necessity to concentrate on a better assessment of maintenance, to have a formula which will set it out and thus get away from the sporadic decisions which judges tend to make and which very often do not properly cover the needs of the family.

I feel that this taxation system has various answers which should be considered. Questions must be asked. Is the Taxation Office here to handle family problems? If some mechanism such as PAYE is used, will there not be additional costs imposed on employers required to handle payments? How well will the Office deal with the necessary variations of maintenance or tax as the circumstances of the parties vary? Will employers take steps to rid their firms of such employees so as to reduce administrative costs? I therefore say that there are very many unanswered questions.

The proposals are very similar to those which the Family Law Council adopted in December 1985 and which are now reported. I think it would be convenient to honourable senators if I sought leave to incorproate in Hansard the 18 recommendations in that report which set out the structure which the Family Law Council then adopted.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows-

In December 1985 the Family Law Council adopted a Report which is, in essence, an expansion of this scheme incorporating both the ``formula'' method of assessment and the use of the Taxation Department as the method of enforcement. For convenience I set out below the 18 recommendations then made by the Family Law Council. They are:
(1) The determination of amounts of child maintenance payable should be set by a formula which should be kept as simple as possible.

(2) Child maintenance payments should be determined in the first instance, administratively rather than judicially in all cases where the custodial parent is in receipt of a social security pension or benefit. Alternatively it could also apply in all other cases where an application for maintenance is made.
(3) There should be a right of appeal to the Family Court against administrative assessments of maintenance liability.
(4) The formula should be applied to the disposable income of the non-custodial parent.
(5) A percentage levy should be made on the ``disposable income'', the percentage increasing with the number of dependent children for whom the non-custodial parent is required to pay maintenance.
(6) The income of the custodial parent should be taken into account where it exceeds a certain maximum.
(7) Step-children living with the non-custodial parent should only be treated as his/her dependent children when their natural (non-custodial) parent is not supporting them.
(8) Where the custodial parent remains in occupation of the former matrimonial home assessment of child maintenance in accordance with the formula should be capable of adjustment.
(9) The Council strongly favours locating as part of the Taxation Office the Agency responsible for assessing and collecting child maintenance and locating non-custodial parents.

(10) Under the administrative system the amount of maintenance to be paid could be assessed by the Child Maintenance Agency within the Tax Office in accordance with the formula and collected along the lines of the PAYE system or the provisional tax system.

(11) If a court-based system of maintenance is regained for those cases where the custodial parent is not in receipt of a pension or benefit legislative provision should be made to ensure that court orders for child maintenance are consistent with maintenance assessed under the administrative system.

(12) If a payer of court ordered maintenance falls into arrears of two weeks or more, the matter could be referred immediately to the Agency to arrange for collection of future maintenance and the arrears through the taxation system. The amount of future maintenance to be collected would be in accordance with the court order.
(13) Custodial parents should be responsible for providing information about the non-custodial parent e.g. his/her whereabouts, employment, information necessary to establish paternity.
(14) The Council considers that it should be possible to suspend or remit maintenance payments during periods of extended access.
(15) The Council considers that the proposed child maintenance system could be phased in over a two year period.

(16) The cost to establish the proposed child maintenance agency should be considerably less than that quoted in the Report of the National Maintenance Inquiry for establishment of a new separate Agency.
(17) There should be considerable savings to Government revenue under the proposed system.
(18) The Council is very firmly of the opinion that in order to increase the standard of living in sole parent families there should be a guaranteed minimum child maintenance payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the method, in more detail, by which the taxation system could be used. It may well be that this may be the final method. All these things amount to a statement that we must not settle suddenly on one proposal and say that this is the only thing that can be done. I do not think that punitive measures are really the things to adopt. It would be more effective to have a probing agency and possibly the use of taxation and possibly a liable parent scheme or something of that sort. It is desirable that this Bill come forward to be discussed. For too long it has remained on the Notice Paper, being fobbed off by a lot of people. It is important that it now be considered well. I think that a Senate committee should do that. I do not think that we should go ahead with adopting one of the proposals. Therefore I move as an amendment to the second reading motion:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `That', insert `debate on this Bill be deferred to enable consideration of the reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, or such other standing or select committee that is able to handle the inquiry, of the provisions of the Bill and other proposals already made or subsequently brought forward to provide a scheme for the effective assessment, collection and enforcement of maintenance payments (whether by order of a court, agreement or otherwise), so that both parents and spouses will pay adequate maintenance from their own resources before reliance is made on pensions or other payments by the Government'.

We must bear in mind that we are in general agreement that the system has broken down; clearly the Government is paying moneys that should not be paid and perhaps payments are not enough in some respects. We must find the best method of collection. We can do this. I know that the Government is considering a tax scheme. It has people in the departments doing so. It would be useful for a Senate committee to look at the mass of detail which has come forward as a result of a lot of people's study and to put forward some recommendation at the same time. It is inherently in the interests of this Parliament to do this rather than run into a divisive Committee stage debate on this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a private member's Bill presented by Senator Durack, the Family Law Amendment Bill. It seeks to amend the Family Law Act in respect of payment of maintenance. The measures proposed in this Bill which we are assured reflect the thinking of the Opposition on this matter have two serious defects. Not only do they fail to provide an improved mechanism for the payment of maintenance, which is surely one of the crucial deficiencies of the current system, but also they introduce an unacceptable rigidity into the decision-making process of the Family Court of Australia and a degree of punitiveness which I believe is unacceptable. Newspaper reports of this Bill have already engendered anxiety in the community, especially that aspect which provides for the use of imprisonment as a routine method of dealing with defaulters. Although we all know of cases in which defaulters could easily fulfil their commitments and, in fact, go to great lengths to avoid doing so, a more frequent state of affairs concerns the stretching of meagre resources where inability to earn a living will certainly not solve any problems and in the vast majority of cases will simply exacerbate them.

SPEECH.PARA: Imprisonment may also introduce bitterness and a desire for vengeance into an otherwise reasonable relationship, not to mention the expense to the community and the dubious value of gaoling debtors. If punishment is necessary I would like to see it more adequately fit the crime-for hard cases something like a community activity, preferably in the service of destitute women and children. There is another serious problem with these amendments-the arbitrary requirement to give priority to the first family. Surely it is desirable, if not essential, that judges of the Family Court have the maximum discretion to view all the relevant facts in every case. There are so many variables as we all know-earning capacity of the partners, home ownership, health of the partners and children, age of the children and other dependants who may be within the family relationship, not to mention variations of relationship in reconstituted families.

It seems to be naive in the extreme to believe that one formula such as that advocated in these amendments would possibly be appropriate more than occasionally. It is unwise to assume, for example, that stepchildren have another parent accessible and able to provide maintenance, as was suggested earlier by Senator Durack. This will often be the case but, as we all know, parents are mortal and they may be ill, disabled, unemployed, simply inaccessible, too old to work, for some other reason unable to work, or have a new young family of their own to support on a low wage. In fact, there may be a chain reaction of marriage breakdown if priority is given arbitrarily to the first marriage. Undoubtedly, as a result there would be increased reliance on social security so that rather than saving money that is currently being paid in benefits we may find that we are paying more.

This Bill's attempt to have social security eligibility disregarded in setting maintenance has a superficial attraction but only if it is reasonable to assume that the level of maintenance awarded is likely to be much higher than at present. According to our calculations if the proportion receiving continuing payments doubled and the circumstances of the recipients were similar to those of existing recipients, the savings would be marginal. This assumes that these payments will be made. Here we come back to the essential weakness of these amendments, the lack of any mechanism by which there would be a minimisation of default and a way by which it could be made difficult for the non-custodial parent to avoid properly determined commitments.

This Bill will not solve any of these problems for the Government or individuals. It may well impose greater hardship on supporting parents. Western Australia has a model of relatively effective maintenance collection and the matter is under active consideration at the Federal Government level. I believe that it would be redundant and a duplication of effort that has already been made for the Senate to refer this matter to a standing committee as advocated by Senator Missen. He has quite accurately canvassed many of the questions that remain to be addressed, that have to some degree been dealt with by the inquiries into maintenance collection. But as far as hard policy decisions are concerned there is still an enormous amount of work to be done. This work is in hand. Within a matter of months proposals will be before this Parliament to deal with some of the more difficult questions, such as the initiation of maintenance action, under what circumstances should maintenance action be a condition of Commonwealth support, should it be a condition of Commonwealth support and is other action required to encourage sole parents to seek maintenance.

With good reason a very high proportion of supporting parents feel that it is far better for them to be assured of a fortnightly social security payment than to be desperately waiting for that cheque in the mail which never comes from an unwilling ex-partner. The question of whether maintenance arrangements should be common to all sole parents or whether special arrangements should be made for social security recipients has yet to be addressed. What about non-custodial parents who wish to opt out of any special arrangement? What guarantees should we require of them to allow them not to be covered by any sort of systematic payment of maintenance? How should we treat other than natural parents; for example, a parent who is a stepfather, a legal guardian or, for that matter, a stepmother?

There is a wide range of assessment options. What should be the appropriate basis for maintenance contributions? Should we look at guidelines or a formula having regard to the capacity of the non-custodial parent to pay? How do we view the income and relevant deductions to be allowed? How do we set a contribution rate and minimum and maximum contributions? These issues are so closely related to decisions that must be made as matters of policy by the Government which will actually have to carry out these policies, find the resources and put in place the structures and mechanisms that it should best be done, as is currently the case, within the portfolio of the Minister for Social Security.

We must develop an appropriate approach to determine the capacity of the custodial parent to pay. As I have said, there are dozens of variables which affect that capacity. We need to know whether the operation of guidelines or a formula should be an automatic administrative process or be subject to some degree of flexibility such as a judicial or other appeal process. We want to know how to ensure timely operation of an assessment process and how non-income forms of maintenance and home ownership should be taken into account. We are all very well aware of the fact that the ownership of a home, the possession of a family home, makes a great deal of difference to the standard of living of whichever parent has the custody of the children.

We may indeed have to look at appropriate personal taxation treatment of contributions paid and received. In fact, this is a form of distribution of maintenance which is receiving a great deal of consideration. We want to know what is the appropriate treatment of separate parents who share custody of their children for extended periods of access. For example, does the parent who has the children over the school holiday period receive maintenance from the other parent for that period although the other parent may for the rest of the year have custody of the children? In fact, should it be exactly the same amount or will some recognition be given to the fact that one parent buys all the clothes or the other parent pays the school fees, et cetera?

On the issue of collection mechanisms, there is the extent to which simple voluntary funds transfer can be used, for example bank transfers, which I think might be the method of choice for many professional people whose incomes would not be accessible to regular income tax deductions through the pay as you earn system. These matters and a whole list of other concerns are currently before the Minister. They are receiving urgent attention. As I have said, I believe that within a very short period we will be in a position to put before the Parliament a series of firm recommendations that will allow the degree of flexibility that we do not find in Senator Durack's Bill, that will allow a degree of discretion with Family Court judges who will need to take into account a wide range of variations in circumstances and that will not simply add to the burden on supporting parents in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Family Law Amendment Bill 1985 which was introduced by Senator Durack. I was rather intrigued by the remarks of Senator Giles when she said that this matter is under active consideration by the Federal Government and that we can expect something within months. The problems associated with the Family Law Act of 1975 have been known for quite a long time. Senator Durack brought in a Bill in 1983 that did not get anywhere. He brought in this Bill in 1985 and we are just debating it today. So much for the urgency portrayed by Senator Giles.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole business of the family and the breaking up of families is a very important matter, not just in the costs that might be incurred in supporting the broken families but also the social costs. I often wonder how these matters get into such a mess. It has been said that, if one wants to muck up something, one puts it in the hands of academic lawyers or a committee. Families have had the unfortunate and disastrous attention of both over a long time. It is not coincidental that, since the passage of the Family Law Act 1975, there has been an extraordinary increase in the number of divorces and people receiving social security benefits as a result of that. Between 1974 and 1984 there was an increase of 255 per cent. The total number of beneficiaries as a result of family break-up has increased from 50,416 to 171,488 which is an increase of 235 per cent. The total cost in constant 1983-84 dollars has increased from $282m to $1,250m. In 1986 the direct cost to the Commonwealth Government is estimated by Mr Jim Crawley of the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia to be $1.5 billion with a further $1.5 billion in other costs to the Commonwealth and State governments. This represents approximately $500 per year for every taxpayer in Australia.

We are confronted with two very serious problems. The first is the growth in the divorce rate which is devastating on families, and in most cases a severe trauma on one of the partners, and the children who are the innocent victims. The other problem is the enormous burden that family break-up has put on to the taxpayer. The two are closely related. Under section 107 of the Family Law Act, no one can be penalised by being sent to gaol for not paying maintenance ordered by the courts. In addition, the potential to obtain social security payments is taken into account when determining maintenance.

I know that concern has been expressed about using gaol as the ultimate penalty for people who do not pay maintenance. However, something has to be done. Those people who have practiced in this field will appreciate that often the threat, the warrant served, will serve to get the recalcitrant party to pay the maintenance due. This has brought with it two attitudes. People may walk away from the responsibilities they have created and have no concern for contributing to the maintenance of those responsibilities. In the main, although not entirely, it is women with children who are disadvantaged. I would like to quote the remarks of Mr Kim Beazley, a former Federal Minister for Education in the Whitlam Government. Mr Beazley is reported in a newspaper as saying:
I can desert my wife, divorce her and the law courts will do virtually nothing to collect maintenance.

In the article he then referred to the principal of a school with which he was involved and said that the principal was getting six letters a week from mothers saying that their husbands had taken off. The article, quoting Mr Beazley, continues:

``When the Family Law Act was being debated-and it was really the work of Mr Whitlam, Senator Lionel Murphy and Keppel Enderby, all QCs with as much idea about poverty as Marie Antoinette-they said that justice would be done in the sharing of property,'' . . .
``They couldn't conceive apparently the people without property.''

Mr Beazley further said that he found that one of the problems, which I think is something that we have all struck in situations where a split has occurred, is that the remaining parent looking after the children tends to take out the bitterness on the children. He said that teachers were going back to the kindergarten four nights a week to teach the mothers budgeting, cooking and child care because some of the women were bashing their children. The Chairman of the Family Law Council, Mr Justice Fogarty, has also made numerous criticisms of maintenance and maintenance enforcement. He is quoted as follows:
. . . maintenance enforcement in Australia was scandalous. Forty per cent of orders were ignored and another thirty per cent were only partly complied with, he said.
``There's an ethic in our society these days and you're a mug to pay maintenance because no one else does.''

Mr Justice Fogarty said abuse of the maintenance system attracted the greatest criticism of the Family Court, but the court could do nothing about it. ``Only the Government can act and it must have the will to do so . . .
He agreed that the existing system encouraged the practice of determining maintenance agreements, using the supporting parent benefit as a starting point.
``We want to see that change,'' Mr Justice Fogarty said. ``What courts should do is judge what a husband can reasonably afford and disregard social security payments.

``But what you get is sweetheart deals among lawyers, who come into court with a consent maintenance agreement between the parties with the husband agreeing to pay $40 a week. You know full well that they're just topping up the social security and there's nothing you can do about it.''

An amendment is sought to section 75. There is no doubt that parents should be required to fund their original responsibilities before funding their new responsibilities. This in itself would be a real incentive to make people think before walking off in a fit of pique. It would be a curb to false pride. Parents must be made to realise that even though their marriage may come to an end, whether it be the fault of one or if there is no blame, their duty to support their children does not end when the marriage ends. It is their first responsibility before they move to another relationship.

The Bill seeks to amend section 123 to make provision for the enforcement of maintenance orders. I doubt whether there is a person in this chamber who has not been told by a constituent or has had even a closer experience of solicitors involved with Family Law Court matters telling clients that they are wasting their time seeking maintenance as for practical purposes it is impossible to enforce. The Bill to amend the Family Law Act is a step towards redressing the major problems which have been found through experience to exist in the implementation of the Family Law Act 1975. The amendments seek where possible to make people responsible. They do not seek to affect adversely those in genuine need, who suffer because of marriage breakup. Quite the contrary. There are families on the bread line in Australia whose ex-partner or ex-parent could be termed wealthy. This is occurring because of the implementation and practical operation of the 1975 Act. As mentioned earlier, it is the anomalies that are being corrected by this amendment Bill. It is not just a matter of equity for the partner who has the children that is important, but the unnecessary burden on the taxpayer. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack's Family Law Amendment Bill seeks to amend the maintenance and enforcement of decrees provisions in the Family Law Act 1975. We would all agree that something has to be done to redress the situation whereby the cost of the supporting parent's benefit has risen dramatically since 1975 whilst the payment of maintenance by fathers has become almost non-existent. Senator Giles told us that the Government was going to do something about it. That sounds very good but prior to the introduction of Senator Durack's Bill the Government had been very slow to think about it at all. It is sad to say that 10 per cent of children have experienced the divorce of their parents by their 10th birthday and 18 per cent by their 18th birthday, so we are talking about a large number of children having to be maintained other than in a normal family situation. Senator Parer outlined for us the tremendous cost to the nation of maintaining all these children.

SPEECH.PARA: All people in society depend for their security on a package consisting of family, work and the state, and the components change over the life span. Various figures suggest that work and the state are assuming more responsibility and the family less. At the International Society on Family Law world conference held in Brussels last year it was pointed out by a number of experts that the current reluctance of men to support their children after divorce was foreshadowed by legal precedent and deeply ingrained norms. One lobby group, the Campaign for Justice in Divorce, argued that it was quite happy for husbands to pay for children but not for the women who provide care for them-a statement which, according to the Institute of Family Studies, sits poorly with the pitifully small amounts of money being transferred. Clearly the responsible attitude for parents to take is to regard the child's support and welfare as the most important factor, not the hostilities between themselves. The family is the basic unity of society. We have to be cognisant of the need for support and welfare of the child. Unfortunately, however, achieving that will require the restructuring of a system which has been built up over centuries.

A myth which has been inculcated into our system of law for centuries-that of fear of supporting the parasitic woman-has resulted in the shaping of laws designed to facilitate the escape of fathers from dependent children. As a result of this entrenched disregard for main- tenance responsibilities the taxpayer is now faced with the enormous and unjust burden of having to pick up the pieces and provide additional taxes for maintenance payments. The figures cited by Senator Parer were certainly large. It is costing the Commonwealth Government $1.5 billion to help fathers escape from their dependent children, meaning that the Federal Government has to pick up the pieces and collect additional taxes in order to make maintenance payments. This is the main reason Senator Durack has felt the need to introduce this Family Law Amendment Bill. I certainly congratulate him on so doing.

I acknowledge the point, which some legal people make, that fathers become bitter when courts find in favour of the woman in custodial cases and in so doing order fathers to pay maintenance while severely curtailing or completely restricting their visiting rights. Another situation brought to my notice concerned wives going interstate, so the husbands are unable to have access to their own children and hence refuse to provide maintenance. I can see some substance in this excuse but I cannot understand a father's refusal to provide his children with the financial support necessary to ensure their education and well being. It does not seem to indicate much love or responsibility on the part of the father. Then again, I suppose that if he goes off and leaves his family, that does not show much love on his part in any case. Regardless of what animosity he has towards the mother, and vice versa, the children are his and not the taxpayers' collective responsibility. I suppose it seems fairly easy these days to go off and leave one's wife and children, or in some cases one's husband and children, when the Government is going to pick up the tab and one does not have to be responsible for the maintenance of the children. I guess some people do not have the capacity to pay. It is just a case, as I see it, of walking away from one's responsibilities.

I am one of the old brigade who still maintains that young children need a mother. It does not help when the mother is forced to go and take a job because she is receiving insufficient maintenance from her divorced husband to care adequately for her children. Honourable senators might say to me that there are other cases, of course, where husbands are left with the children and the wife goes off. I suppose that this is where child care comes into being. Most certainly there is a great need in cases such as this for adequate child care. I believe that the best child care of all is that which I saw not so very long ago in one of our Brisbane suburbs-women in a district are willing to take children after school and look after them until the mother or the father is able to get home in the evening.

The first six years of life are the most crucial to the development of a child's full range of capabilities. It is during these six years that the child will form his or her personality and coping mechanisms. The added stress of a marriage breakdown does nothing to instil in the child a sense of belonging, of being loved consistently and of being cared for in a happy family situation. Why would anyone want to make his or her child suffer more by refusing to provide the financial security which is also so vitally important? I certainly support Senator Durack's Family Law Amendment Bill. I am glad that he has brought it into the Senate because there is a very big need for it and I am hopeful that fellow senators will also see the need to correct this glaring anomaly, not just for the sake of saving taxpayers' money, but also to help promote a more caring and more responsible approach to family life in this country. It most certainly is very much needed, and we do not want to forget that children are this nation's greatest resource.

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, after definition of `Schedule airport' insert the following definition:

Page 3, clause 3, at end of the clause add the following new sub-clause:

Page 31, paragraph 56 (4) (c), line 2, before `the basis', insert `shall specify'.

Page 31, paragraph 56 (4) (d), line 4, before `the reason', insert `shall specify'.
Page 37, paragraph 72 (2) (c), line 43, leave out `offices', insert `officers'.
Page 38, paragraph 72 (3) (c), line 21, leave out `offices', insert `officers'.

I think the amendments speak for themselves. Amendments (1) to (4) are amendments to clarify, for instance, the definition of `securities' and to make more clear the language in a couple of clauses of the legislation, particularly clauses 3 and 56. Amendments (5) to (8) result from typographical errors in the Bill. These would normally be sorted out in the other place by what are called chairmen's amendments. In this place they would not be sorted out at all; we would just change them. TALK.START.PARA: —You would not think it was sloppy government?

—It is nothing to do with the Government, Senator; it is to do with the House. I think it is a combination of the Clerks and a few other people over there. But these are typographical errors which in this place we would have fixed, quite sensibly, by just changing them. But these people on the other side think we have to do this formally, so I suppose we will do it.
