SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, after paragraph (2) (b), insert the following paragraphs:
`(ba) ensures that, as far as is practicable, the level of noise at airports is not such as to be detrimental to the communities near airports;

`(bb) ensures that, where land at a Federal airport is to be used for a purpose not directly related to aviation, being land in respect of which a lease, licence or authority has been granted to a person (other than the Commonwealth), the use would, if the land were not in a Federal airport, be allowed by the law of the relevant State or Territory (including laws made by a relevant local government body);

`(bc) ensures that where a building is to be erected on land at a Federal airport for a purpose not directly related to aviation, being land in respect of which a lease, licence or authority has been granted to a person (other than the Commonwealth), the design and construction of the building would, if the land were not in a Federal airport, be allowed by the law of the relevant State or Territory (including laws made by a relevant local government body);
`(bd) ensures that the Corporation and the communities served by Federal airports are good neighbours;'.

These amendments are basically to ensure that the Federal Airports Corporation Bill takes into account the wishes and desires of local government agencies. Members of the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council-AMAC-originally came to the Australian Democrats last year with a list of 12 requests as to where the Bill should be amended from their viewpoint. Nine of these requests were later dropped but three remained. Basically they involved, firstly, environmental functions of the Corporation, secondly, the planning, development and building control of the councils over the FAC and, thirdly, the payment of rates to the councils. We had a good look at this. We listened to AMAC and we consulted the Department of Aviation, through the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), and we found that there were areas in the Bill which were unsatisfactory. One of those was the environmental area. It is extraordinary that the FAC has no environmental functions, when we consider that we are dealing with something as contentious as aircraft noise; there are no environmental functions in this Bill.

The report of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise entitled `Aircraft Operations and the Australian Community', which has been tabled but not responded to by the Government yet, states that the FAC should take into account the environmental aspects in its legislation. Recommendation 30 of the report states that the legislation establishing the FAC `should specify consideration of environmental functioning of the Corporation'. Yet the Bill does not consider this. Unfortunately the control over flight paths, which is basically the major concern for local communities, is not within the jurisdiction of the FAC. In other words, people are far more concerned about aircraft noise when aircraft are flying over their heads than they are when aircraft are running up on the ground. However, this is no reason for the FAC not to undertake, within its jurisdiction, to abate noise and operate as a good neighbour-an operation which will not offend its neighbours. Amendments (ba) and (bd), circulated on the good neighbour principle, are drafted to be reciprocal as is the case where the good neighbour principle is used in agreements.

Another issue brought up by AMAC which we, as Democrats, considered and agreed to had to do with the planning and development and building controls of the FAC. There is no reason why the FAC should not adhere to local building requirements. The possibility of the FAC allowing a 15-storey hotel in a local environment where only five-storey buildings are allowed must be foreshadowed and dealt with in the Bill. In fact there is a case at this time concerning Jandakot Airport in Western Australia where the local government has strict controls over the usage of its own land or area under its own control. The Department of Aviation has allowed a go-kart track to be built, much against the wishes of the local residents and local government but, since it is on govenment land, the local people have no control. This bothers the local people. It bothered the mayor in that area, who came to see me. This must be guarded against. But the local council should not be in a position to stipulate how buildings specifically related to aviation can be built. In other words, if the local government regulations call for a certain type of structure and this would be in conflict with the aviation needs of that structure, the aviation needs should receive precedence; it is only logical. The Democrats amendments (bb) and (bc) are designed to resolve this dilemma responsibly. Where buildings, et cetera, are not directly related to aviation they must adhere to the relevant State or Territory laws, including local government regulations and ordinances. The amendment agreed to by the Government is attached.

There is a third area considered as important by local government, and that is the payment of council rates. The councils would like the FAC to pay rates rather than have the present situation where the Government pays rates minus services and land taxes already paid for by the Commonwealth in the form of guaranteed ex gratia payments. All subsidiaries of the FAC and activities outside the direct area of operation of the FAC will pay full rates and taxes under the legislation. The problem is that section 114 of the Constitution exempts the Federal government from payment of local government taxes and rates. Tenants and lessees are Federal government tenants and lessees on Federal government property, and under the existing contracts the Federal government assumes responsibilities for such things. To alter these agreements would be fraught with enormous difficulties, if possible at all. On the other hand, it would be constitutionally difficult with widespread ramifications in other areas for the Government to reverse section 114, and this has quite a bit of legal opinion behind it. As a solution the Democrats have asked the Minister to agree to give an undertaking on behalf of the FAC that the ex gratia payments will be no less than the applicable rates and taxes. This statement has in fact been made by the Minister, who in the House of Representatives said this week:

The Democrats raised with me the matter of ex gratia payments in lieu of rates of FAC airports. I would like to place on record that it is the intention that the FAC will be required to conform with Government policy to make such payments and to continue without diminution the payments currently made by the Commonwealth in regard to commercial activities on airports.

I draw honourable members' attention to the reference to this matter contained in my speech in the second debate. We have attempted to take a good look at this Bill. We agree with it in principle. We felt that it needed some amendments to make it more acceptable to the community. We have moved those amendments and recommend them to the Committee.

Earlier much was made of a media release from Bruce Lloyd, shadow Minister for Aviation and National Party member for Murray, about exactly what it meant and whether it referred to privatisation. The media release is fairly loosely written, as would be expected, because the Opposition did not really understand the issue very well, as could be seen from earlier contributions. In the first place the coalition parties believe that another quango or statutory authority subject to excessive ministerial direction is not the best way to achieve greater efficiency and public accountability of aerodromes such as Mascot and Tullamarine. Later in the release the Opposition states:

The Opposition believes that there are too many statutory authorities, and that the better way to efficiently manage our major airports is to establish individual boards of management. This would create a body that is separately accountable and would allow more independent management decisions.

When these two statements are taken together, one sees that the Opposition is either promoting privatisation of the airports or promoting the transfer of airports to State governments or local government or the establishment of separate statutory authorities for each airport. If the Opposition argument regarding quangos is accepted, the third option disappears. So we are left with privatisation or the transfer of airports to State governments or local government. If privatisation is to be adopted, which is the stated policy of the Opposition, there is an assumption that separate companies could be formed to take over the airports, otherwise only profitable airports would be taken over and the balance would remain a burden on the taxpayer. The likelihood of the Government being able to sell off all airports, even if it wished to do so, is highly questionable. One wonders about the business acumen of the Opposition.

Privatisation of a monopoly would also require the imposition of considerable government control to ensure that the public interest was protected and the monopoly situation not exploited. The imposition of such controls would run counter to the concept of independent management espoused by the Opposition. The Opposition argument therefore tends to defeat itself, which it often does. The transfer of airports to State or local governments could be achieved only if those governments were prepared to take them over. South Australia and Queensland have already indicated that they would not be prepared to do so in respect of major airports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Are these arguments relevant to your amendments?

—No, probably not, but I find that much of what goes on in this House is somewhat on those lines. The Opposition will no doubt spring to its feet complaining mightily about these amendments, but it will probably not have done its homework on these amendments as it did not do its homework on this media release or on the Bill itself. I take your implied criticism on board, Mr Chairman. Since I have already obviously explained with great clarity the amendments and the need for them, I will resume my seat and urge the Committee to accept the amendments in the spirit in which they were meant, which is to improve an already excellent Bill.
—I and the Government do not have much trouble with the first three of these amendments.
—Aren't you thinking?

—Your criticising my thinking would be something akin to Satan condemning sin. They are good amendments. They ask us to ensure that the level of noise at airports is not such as to be detrimental to the community, and that is fair enough. No one can argue with that. I suppose no one can argue with the first three amendments. However, I have a bit of a problem with the fourth one. I would perhaps ask Senator Sanders to put his mind to that because it asks us to ensure that the Corporation and the community served by Federal airports are good neighbours. I am not sure that constitutionally the Federal Government can legislate to ensure that people are good neighbours. I am not sure that it is possible for anyone to legislate for people to be good neighbours. I like good neighbourhood as much as I like motherhood and all those sorts of things, and it gives me a bit of a warm inner glow to see such an amendment. At times we should perhaps make it clear in our legislation that we have feelings of this type. I do not sneer as do Opposition members.
—Make it compulsory.

—There are several things I would like to make compulsory about you, Senator, and surgery would be one. I would question whether the fourth amendment would be worthwhile, but I would not go to the barricades on it. It is important that we talk about good neighbours and all those good things because too many bad things are talked about in this place. However, I ask Senator Sanders perhaps to question in his own mind and in his colleagues' minds whether we can constitutionally do that. The rest of it the Government has no objection to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very strongly against the first of these amendments by the Australian Democrats or whatever flag they are flying today. I do this in the hope that the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, and other members of the Government will give up the habit of trying to think on the run. They are not too good at thinking at any time, but when Senator Grimes and Senator Evans try to think on the run, we often come unstuck. I am very concerned about the business of noise at airports. The Australian community has a very large investment in airports. We abide by general noise requirements which apply through the International Civil Aviation Organisation and other bodies and standards are set as to what noise aircraft can make. I have no quarrel with that. But the proposal put forward by Senator Sanders reflects his abysmal ignorance of the whole aviation scene and of the Australian community in general. He knows nothing about either field.
—He probably flies more than you do.

—I doubt that. I have probably been flying for considerably longer than Senator Sanders, but I do not get up and slap myself on the back and talk about my involvement in the American aerospace industry, and it is probably bigger than Senator Sanders's involvement in the American aerospace industry. I do not want to get into that sort of thing. I am happy to stand by my record. I do not have to promote it. Having listened to Senator Sanders talking about aviation, I realise that he knows as much about it as I know about theology. The point I wish to make is that the Australian community has a very big involvement in real estate in airfields. I am opposing amendment (ba) on behalf of the aviation industry in Australia and the interests of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Sanders that the facts of life are that the airports in Australia preceded the urban development around them in nearly all cases. As for my own State, as I consider the airfields that serve Queensland, I cannot think of one that was ringed by houses when it started. The point I would like to make briefly and succinctly, so Senator Grimes can understand it, is that people chose of their own free will to buy land around airports. They bought it because it was cheap at the time. That might have been 30, 40 or 50 years ago. I would like Senator Grimes to consider the fact that airports are an essential part of the Australian infrastructure, both for overseas travel and for travel within Australia. In a very real way airports are comparable to seaports in a bygone age, a century ago.

The community has an investment in travel and communications within the country. People who, for whatever reasons, chose to buy land by airports did so in the full knowledge that aviation was taking place on that mile square field or whatever it was thirty 30 or 40 years ago when the airports started. It is absolutely unconscionable for those people to weep now and say that they are upset by the noise of a light aircraft flying overhead, or something like that, or coming the act, as people do around Archerfield and Acacia Ridge, of saying that a light aircraft might fly into a school and kill 50 or 100 people. As an aviator, I would be terribly distressed if an aircraft went through a school and occasioned injury to anyone, let alone killed a number of people. However, the facts of life are that the airfields were there first.

The very important point is-if Senator Grimes had the maturity to understand it and look at it objectively-that the community has an interest in maintaining this asset. The Government cannot win this argument. Let us take the case of Melbourne, whose airport was moved from Essendon to Tullamarine. All the smarties, the rapid real estate developers, moved in and ringed Tullamarine with houses.

We do not need to set up a new airport for Sydney. All we need is a parallel runway system. A move in that direction would save the Australian aviation industry maybe $20m or $30m a year in fuel burn. If we did that we would not need another airport at Badgerys Creek, Wilton or wherever the Government wants it to go in New South Wales, wherever Nifty wants to hive off a bit of real estate. If the airport goes out to the bush, one will soon find a housing development around it and within 10 years there will be pressures for a new field. So, on those grounds, I do not support amendment (ba). It is entirely contrary to the interests of the aviation community of Australia and to the best interests of the Australian community. I move:
Leave out paragraph (bd).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to get some information from the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, regarding a couple of provisions of this Bill before I turn to other matters. My concern is the inter-relationship between the provisions in clause 10 (1) (b) and clause 71 of the legislation. Clause 71 of the legislation transfers to the Federal Airports Corporation the responsibilities currently exercised by either the Minister for Aviation or the Department of Aviation under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act. That includes the power to call for, adjudicate on and award contracts and tenders. Clause 10 (1) (b) allows the Corporation to establish, form, or participate in the formation of a company that would be a subsidiary of the Corporation. What I want to know from the Minister is whether the Corporation can form a subsidiary company and then, under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act, award it one of its own contracts or tenders.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the example of catering, parking, duty free facilities, cleaning or whatever. If the Corporation establishes its own company and then, under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act, awards the contract to its own company, I want to know whether it is anticipated that that would be the sort of activity in which the companies formed under clause 10 (1) (b) would be engaged in relation to the Airports (Business Concessions) Act or whether, within the legislation or any Government directions, there is any prohibition to prevent that from occurring.

I support the comments of my colleague Senator MacGibbon about the Australian Democrats' amendments and those made by Senator Grimes about the good neighbour amendment. Senator Sanders is fast establishing a reputation in this chamber as the most notorious pilot since Pontius. Nevertheless, one wants to establish some degree of rationality in this debate. Before Senator Sanders goes on to wash his hands of any involvement in a piece of Commonwealth legislation by inserting in it a provision that it is to be required that the Corporation and the communities served by Federal airports are good neighbours-I presume not on the principle that good neighbours are made by high fences-one needs to know not only what it is that is to be done to the Airports Corporation if it does not behave as a good neighbour but also, more importantly what is to be done to the local communities if they do not behave as good neighbours.

The legislation we will be passing will be the first occasion when, by legislative fiat, communities served by airports are required by law to be `good neighbours'. I would hate to take a city such as Launceston as an example, but let us consider, for instance, the case of a committee established in Launceston, representing the local community, which decided that it did not want to be a good neighbour to the Launceston Airport. Senator Grimes has looked up. I thought that comment might provoke Senator Grimes to some degree of interest in this matter. Let us take what Senator Grimes had to say this afternoon about local communities in Launceston or, as he would say, the denizens of Launceston, that is, those inhabitants of Launceston who are not troglodytes. Under the passage of Senator Sanders's amendment, one could contemplate Senator Grimes and his colleagues coming to the conclusion that the communities served by the Launceston Airport are not behaving like good neighbours. Presumably, poor old Senator Watson, Mr Smith and Mr Newman would find themselves in strife under the terms of the Federal Airports Corporation legislation and would be hauled up, undoubtedly, before the Human Rights Commission in order to demonstrate that they should not be punished for not being good neighbours according to the terms and conditions of the Sanders amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they wouldn't know who was making the allegations.

—Not only that, but they probably would not get the right to defend themselves anyway. I believe that that example indicates the nonsense of putting up an amendment to a significant piece of Commonwealth legislation to ensure that people, corporations and communities are `good neighbours'. Senator Grimes has indicated that he is very concerned to ensure that legislation is in its best form. According to him, the only people who muck up legislation are the Clerks and people in the other place who cannot get the legislation straight, and it needs to be corrected as a result. I am even prepared to tolerate the sly look of the Clerk because he is very even-handed about these matters. He is giving me the same look as he gave Senator Grimes when Senator Grimes was speaking, so I really do not mind. The Government will see the sense of opposing at least amendment (bd).

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amendment (ba), Senator MacGibbon quite accurately described the situation, particularly in terms of the relationship between airports and residents. It is exactly the same problem, for instance, that is currently being faced in Sydney. Complaints are being made by residents about the Australian Atomic Energy Commission establishment at Lucas Heights. The establishment has been there for a considerable period. As the result of various local government activities and development, communities have moved closer to the reactor and thus there are now complaints that the reactor ought to be picked up and moved somewhere else. Exactly the same principle applies to airports and this vexed question of aircraft noise. I believe that as the Government has not responded to the House of Representatives committee inquiry dealing with aircraft noise, amendment (ba) which the Opposition will oppose will, I hope, be opposed by the Government. Therefore I hope that Senator Grimes might be persuaded, at least to see some light and some reason for some of the Democrats' amendments, and that he might also be in a position to give me some information about the inter-relationship of the two clauses in terms of commercial operations of the Corporation. It is a matter which I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly support the comments made by both Senator Puplick and Senator MacGibbon on paragraph (ba).
—That is exactly what it is.

—When one sees such rot coming from a political party all one can say is `bah'. Senator MacGibbon has quite rightly indicated what happened at Tullamarine Airport. A deliberate decision was taken by the Government at the time to build a new airport where it would not worry anybody. I can recall-I suppose many honourable senators can-driving to that airport and seeing signs `You are under the flight path approach to runway XYZ. If you build here you will be subject to airport noise'. I do not know what else one can do to protect people from themselves or from their own folly.

SPEECH.PARA: I stand corrected but when the Major Airport Needs of Sydney study was done it was found that a high percentage of people-about 80 per cent-living around Sydney Airport had bought there since jet traffic started operating. Of course we are a lot further down the track now and we have much quieter jets operating. People obviously bought there because the land or the houses were cheaper. They wanted to take advantage of that fact. The old phrase caveat emptor certainly pertains in this case. Maybe a good case can be made for local authorities. When a new airport is built-people in Brisbane are very lucky in this regard-the area around it will be zoned industrial land or something like that so it cannot be built on by people who want to take advantage of cheap land and establish houses on it. When the new Brisbane Airport opens we will be very lucky because, as I understand it, the old airport will become industrial land or ancillary land to the new airport which is bounded by the river and the bay. We will be very lucky so far as noise problems and curfews are concerned. This is really a nonsense amendment. This chamber would do well to get rid of it and treat it with the contempt which it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief points firstly on proposed amendment (ba). I have problems with some of the wording. I am not quite certain what it means; I am never quite certain what the phrase `as far as practicable' means and I am certain that Senator Sanders has no idea what it means. The practicality of a situation where there is an airport is that there is noise. If practicality is to be the measure, the practical fact is that aeroplanes make noises when they come in and take off. The next part of the amendment states: `is not such as to be detrimental to the communities'. I am not quite certain what the word `detrimental' means in this context. Does it mean affecting people's health?
—Mental wellbeing.

—Their mental wellbeing? Obviously some members of the Australian Democrats have been living too close to airports for too long. Is it their psyche? Does it mean affect people's dogs, for example? Obviously dogs do not like aeroplanes sometimes. I am not quite certain what this kind of waffly wording is really supposed to mean. The amendment states: `. . . detrimental to the communities'. I suppose the word `communities' can be defined in all sorts of quaint ways. If the Australian Democrats really want to ensure that there are no airports where there are communities they will set out to cost the Australian taxpayer untold millions of dollars. If this clause does not mean that, it is meaningless and is here simply to appear to be aimed at another special interest group that the Democrats spend all their time trying to appeal to in this typically phoney way. I would think that the odds are that rather than having some meaning, which is obscure anyway, this phrase is absolutely meaningless and is another of their fairly tawdry, sordid attempts to buy some votes.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to deal with one problem concerning the response of politicians to questions of votes. To a degree it is unfortunate that the Federal Airports Corporation will not have the power to impose some sort of economic rationality on decisions about where to site airports. In New South Wales we have had an incredible situation where for years there has been all this toing and froing about where the second airport site for Sydney should be, if one is needed. The clear economic case is for another runway at Mascot and a more efficient use of existing facilities. Where that clear case exists there has been enormous endeavour to defeat that clear case. For example, as I understand it, the Federal Government will make a decision on Monday about a second airport site for Sydney, that is if it does not find it too difficult a decision to make and if it wants to spend another three years-the number of years it has been in power-scratching whatever is appropriate, to bring forth whatever flame comes from its oiled lamp.

The curious matter about which I have been advised is that the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran-who is known, as Senator MacGibbon says, by another name-as I understand it on good authority, has been heavily lobbying for Badgerys Creek to be listed as the second airport site. I do not know why he would want Badgerys Creek to be the site. Maybe he feels that the ground fog there in the morning is particularly attractive and useful for an airport. Maybe he is enthralled by the fact that it has inadequate transport and would cost the Federal Government extraordinary amounts of money to provide it with any kind of links into the city. Perhaps he considers that there are some political advantages in the St George area by removing the problem in order to sustain some position in the State seats around Botany Bay. After all, he has already shown his enthusiasm for doing anything, no matter how detrimental to the economy in that area, by refusing to allow a coal loader, which would be totally enclosed, to be built. Certainly economics, rationality and what is best for the community generally bear no relationship to what Mr Wran would seek to do. If my information is correct-as I certainly believe it to be-I think it would be proper if Mr Wran publicly stated his clear preference for Badgerys Creek so that people would be able to know who to blame if the Federal Government were foolish enough to make that decision on Monday, that is, of course, if it makes any decision at all. The absurdity of going to Badgerys Creek does not simply rely on the fact that obviously a second runway at Mascot is more appropriate, but it is compounded by the fact that if we are going to go anywhere we may as well go to Wilton. I assure the Senate that this is not simply because Wilton is only about half an hour's drive from my electorate office in Wollongong; Wilton is in fact on the main freeway, the Hume freeway into Sydney. It is on the new Dombarton to Picton rail spur, which is slowly being converted from an election gimmick by the Wran Government into a partly built section of track, and which links in to the main Sydney-Melbourne rail line. It clearly has available land that can be purchased at a fraction of the cost of land at Badgerys Creek and, as I said, has these appropriate facilities and is also convenient to my electorate office.

In this situation, I should stress that rationality demands that the second Sydney airport be in fact a second runway at Mascot. Whatever happens, I urge the Government this time to actually make a decision, because the people of Badgerys Creek, for example, have been unable to get any development applications approved by their council for at least the last 18 months. People cannot build anything on their land; they cannot put pools in or whatever it is they want to do such as build extensions or granny flats. The thing is that the Government cannot leave people for this amount of time not knowing what on earth is going to happen to their houses, their land, maybe their total assets or perhaps the small business they have in that area. This has become a total nonsense and all I can do is to urge the Government, when it comes to make this decision-which I hope is Monday-not to do an oil price on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out that this is a very tolerant House. We have just heard a speech from Senator Michael Baume pushing his local barrow which has very little directly to do with this legislation. I just make the point that I find it extraordinary that Senator Michael Baume should get up here and castigate this Government for not making a decision about the second Sydney airport in three years when in seven years of government Opposition members made no such decision at all. They waffled around the place, carried on, and in fact in the years before that they did nothing; but Senator Michael Baume comes in here and complains, has a crack at Neville Wran, who he does not like for holding a record term as Premier of New South Wales and who looks like staying there for another 20 or 30 years, and then really says what it is all about-that he really wants the airport near his electorate office which is in the area that he used to represent. It really is a backhanded way of putting in his bid for what he wants.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure Senator Michael Baume that we will make a decision. The decision will be made on the basis of all the facts; the decision will be made after hearing the views of the citizens of New South Wales, including those in Badgerys Creek and of Wilton; even the Premier of New South Wales may have something to say about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another seven years?

—That decision will be made before seven years. It will certainly be made in a much quicker time than Senator Michael Baume's Government took when it was in power. Senator Puplick referred to clause 71 and clause 10, and I think I can also refer him to clause 8 of the Bill. Clause 71 of this legislation says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in accordance with Part IV, a Schedule airport or another airport becomes a Federal airport, it ceases to be an airport within the meaning of the Airports (Business Concessions) Act . . .

That means that the Airport (Business Concessions) Act no longer applies. What it means though, as Senator Puplick suggested, is that it is theoretically possible for the Corporation to participate, form a company, I am advised, and a subsidiary, and that that subsidiary could take over, if allowed to by the Corporation, the functions that Senator Puplick suggested. I fail to see why it would not; though I doubt that it would. I will seek further information from the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), but on our reading and on the advice I have given here, what he says is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) for that answer. I express a little surprise at the way in which he says that if a subsidiary corporation were established he doubts that it would participate in certain activities. He will recall, no doubt, that when the contract for duty-free shopping came up some years ago in Brisbane, after tenders had been called from the private sector they were all then unilaterally ignored by the Department, which gave the contract to the then Commonwealth Hostels organisation in order to ensure that in that particular area it retained a revenue raising capacity which had traditionally been within the private sector. I suspect that as a method of revenue raising, that is precisely what will occur because some of the concessions such as the duty-free concession, the catering concession and the parking concession, are in fact very substantial concessions. If my memory serves me correctly, the payment to the Commonwealth by the last tenderer at Sydney was a multi-million dollar payment because multi-million dollar revenues are expected out of that particular operation.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I am highly suspicious of an organisation which, by forming companies under clause 10 and awarding itself contracts under clause 71, will in fact be able to transfer out of the private sector into its own hands the capacity to run a number of commercial operations, some of which are extremely large money takers. Looking at the duty-free industry, we are talking about revenue of $70m to $80m a year. If this is the Government's plan, particularly with the introduction of inward duty-free, to which I have referred on a number of occasions and which was the subject of discussion the other day when the Industries Assistance Commission report on passenger concessions came before us, I must say that I am highly suspicious of the Government's intent in moving out of the hands of the private sector and into subsidiaries of the Federal Airports Corporation major commercial undertakings for the purpose of increasing its own Commonwealth revenues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why? Because they make money?

—Well, they make money at the moment. One suspects that there is a reasonable prospect that if the Government's record on this is as good as its record in some of the other areas of administration by the Department of Aviation, they would soon become net losses to the Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other matters about which I have some concern immediately. One is the rationale for clause 69 in terms of scheduled airports no longer being airports within the meaning of the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act and the extent to which the regulations, which include some of the regulations which deal with the question of security, are to be properly replicated in airports under the control of the Federal Airports Corporation. The last matter I raise will turn to the Australian Democrats' amendments, and in particular to amendment (bb). Does the Minister contemplate with the passage of this amendment, the last part of which refers to laws made by relevant local government bodies, that in any undertaking, say, to build a hotel, the Corporation would be bound by, say, the local council's parking ordinances, that it would have to abide by the local council's liquor restrictions or noise restrictions, or, indeed, by local council regulations which might deal with the showing of in-house movies or whatever it happens to be? In other words, is the Federal Airports Corporation to have one set of rules under which it can operate?

Let me take for example New South Wales. To which local council will Kingsford-Smith Airport in Sydney pay attention? There are six local councils which for the purposes of this amendment would be relevant local government bodies. They do not have all the same planning rules. They do not have all the same laws; they do not have all the same restrictions. Which of the codes of the six-or is it all six-have to be abided by by the Corporation? The same is true of Bankstown Airport. More than one council is involved there. Certainly at Hoxton Park and Camden there are more than one, and I am sure that in respect of Coolangatta Airport there would be a difficulty between the restrictions of the law as it effects both New South Wales and Queensland. One is talking there about which set of local regulations or State laws-the laws of Queensland or the laws of New South Wales-will require the Corporation to obey in relation to Coolangatta Airport. Senator Grimes would undoubtedly be aware that it may well be an offence, if it is the Queensland laws, for three people to assemble in the grounds of Coolangatta Airport without a permit because that happens to reflect the laws of Queensland. It will be interesting to see, therefore, if a demonstration takes place at Coolangatta Airport against airport noise, whether the regulations governed by the laws of Queensland are the ones in force. I will continue my remarks at some later stage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question that I do leave the chair and report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Employment Program: Footscray-Balance of Payments

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I asked Senator Walsh, as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, certain questions about a community employment project in Victoria in Mr Willis's electorate of Gellibrand. The project involves the construction of a new swimming centre in the suburb of Footscray at an originally estimated cost of $2.8m. I would like tonight to provide the Senate with additional information about this project and to ask several further questions in relation to it. I have mentioned to Senator Walsh and the office of Mr Willis that I would do so. I do so not only because this project has become, at best, a scandalous fiasco, but also because it raises issues which go to the very heart and integrity of the whole CEP program; it goes to the whole question of whether the unemployed are receiving the benefits that the program was designed to provide.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the CEP program, which the Hawke Labor Government introduced in a blaze of favourable stage managed publicity in the latter half of 1983, has already cost the taxpayers of Australia more than $1,000m. The Government has recently announced that the program will continue for a further three years. On past trends this will involve a further $1,000m or more of taxpayers money. These are enormous amounts. The Government has a fundamental obligation to the taxpayers of Australia to ensure that CEP funds are spent wisely and responsibly, and that their use is fully monitored, audited, and accounted for. In other words, the Australian public deserves and demands total confidence that the CEP program is being properly and responsibly administered.

The story of the CEP Footscray swimming pool project is important in this wider context, as well as in its own particular right. It is a sad story-indeed a tragedy, to quote the Footscray City Council. It is a story which must put an enormous dent in the Australian public's confidence in the administration by the Hawke Government of the whole, enormously expensive, CEP program-and indeed in its overall administrative competence. It raises important questions of both principle and detail that must be addressed by the Minister urgently. Failure to do so would be a grave dereliction of his ministerial duty. I turn to the details of the Footscray project.

Footscray had an old swimming pool which was in need of repair and upgrading. The estimated cost of this was $2m to $3m. The Footscray City Council did not have sufficient financial resources to undertake such a project. For the ratepayers of Footscray to fund the project would have caused a 6 per cent rate rise for every ratepayer. The Council saw the establishment of the CEP program in the latter half of 1983 as a possible source of funds. It appears that on 30 November 1983, some two to three months after the CEP program was introduced, the Footscray Town Clerk made the City's first application for CEP funds. It appears that because of what have been described as `other problems', which are said to have been union problems, the Town Clerk subsequently advised the officer in charge of the CEP program that a management committee had been established to handle the project, rather than the Footscray City Council, even though the Council was the applicant for the CEP funds. The project was approved on 6 August 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long did it take to get approval?
—It took a period of about eight to nine months.
—It was not unduly quick?

—No, that is right. The initial application was at a time when the unemployment market was very different, and so on. The total cost of the project was put at $2.8m, to be funded to an amount of $1.974m from the CEP, and some $800,000 from the Footscray City Council. The first CEP payment of $493,556 was handed over personally by Mr Willis, as the local member and as the responsible Minister, amid considerable favourable publicity, on 8 August 1984, two days after the approval had been granted. On 19 September 1984 three people began work on the project-a civil engineer, a mechanical engineer and one CEP grant person. In early October, a further 14 CEP workers commenced employment. Thus, for two months after the first funding was received, there was little progress in using the funds to employ the long-term jobless persons of the area.

SPEECH.PARA: On 10 October 1984 a shelf company by the name of Elate Pty Ltd was purchased and the Footscray City Engineer and the Footscray Town Clerk became directors, according to documents from the Corporate Affairs Commission. On 22 March 1985, six additional directors were appointed to Elate, of which only two were city councillors. On 3 April 1985-that is, a couple of weeks later-the name of the company was changed from Elate Pty Ltd to Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd, and since then eight CEP grant payments have been made, the latest for $408,000 as recently as eight days ago. Payments to date, according to the CEP secretariat, now total $2,350,593-already in excess of the $1.97m originally approved. Under the original agreement between the Footscray City Council and the CEP authorities, the Council is committed to contribute $800,000 to the project. However, Council's actual contribution to date has been only $200,000. The remaining amount of $600,000 has been frozen by the Council, according to the Town Clerk.

My office has been advised that the CEP secretariat was unaware that the Council had taken this action. This raises serious questions about the extent or lack of monitoring of the project. I will come back to that matter later. It also raises the question of whether, by holding back the $600,000, the Council is breaking its contract with the Government. A visual inspection of the site reveals very little result for the $2.5m spent so far. As well, the project is seriously behind schedule and the cost overruns have been massive. As of today, some 30 per cent of available man weeks of work on the project have been lost through absenteeism and industrial disputes. It appears that the project will never be capable of completion under the existing contractual arrangements. Why was a separate legal entity, originally called Elate Pty Ltd and subsequently renamed Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd, formed to manage this project? According to the Age newspaper today, the Footscray Town Clerk, Mr Ward, is reported as saying that the Council had had discussions with the Federal Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the then relevant Victorian Minister, Mr Simmonds, and that these Ministers had said that CEP finance would not be made available unless the project were administered by a separate entity.

The intention, according to Mr Ward, had been to avoid industrial action which might have arisen if the Municipal Employees Union had resisted the Council's use of building trades unionists on the project. However, this ruse failed to prevent industrial problems. Again, according to Mr Ward in today's Age, the whole project was soon in great trouble as a result of action by the Builders Labourers Federation. In any event, it is difficult to understand the explanation given for the establishment of the private company. The company was not set up until October 1984, yet government approval of the project was given on 6 August 1984 and the first CEP payment was made on 7 August-two months before the company was established. It is essential that Mr Willis explain this apparent contradiction. He also needs to tell us what grounds he and the State Minister, Mr Simmonds, had for virtually forcing the Footscray Council to set up the private company.

I have been advised that a trust deed exists which transfers ownership of the pool from Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd to the Footscray City Council on completion of the project. I am also advised that the CEP secretariat in Victoria is unaware of the formal existence or content of this trust deed. The Minister has a duty to tell us whether he personally is aware of the trust deed. The public must also be told of the legal status of the deed and the reasons for its existence. There is no evidence to indicate that the deed has ever been discussed at a full Footscray Council meeting.

Given the major problems being faced in completing the swimming pool, the important question arises of who is the legal owner of the uncompleted pool. It appears that the Footscray City Council is not, even through it was the official sponsor and procurer of the CEP grant. Furthermore, what is the legal liability of those persons involved in the Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd and, for that matter, Footscray City councillors? I understand that tenders were neither advertised nor called for the pool project and that local government requirements in Victoria are that all projects in excess of $20,000 must go to local tender.

The Minister must tell this Parliament whether he was aware that tenders were not called. He must also explain the legal implications of tenders not being called; for example, where does this place Footscray City councillors in a legal sense? Does it call into question the legal validity of the project as a whole and the CEP payments of $2.35m which have been made to date? The Minister must also tell us how the firm of Trojan-Owen and Associates Pty Ltd came to be selected as the project manager after the Footscray Council had accepted its own inability to manage the project. Trojan-Owen has wide experience of community projects in South Australia, but very limited experience in Victoria. According to corporate affairs records, Trojan-Owen has been 99 per cent owned by a company called Newdok Pty Ltd since July 1984, shortly before the pool project was approved for CEP funding.

Since public moneys are involved, full details of the financial arrangements between Trojan-Owen and the Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd, or the Footscray City Council, should be made available. It appears that the establishment of the Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd has involved the project in significant additional costs. State payroll tax has had to be paid and much higher workers compensation premiums have been paid. How much are these additional costs and how have they been funded, because they were not included in the original project estimates? It is also obligatory for this Government to advise the Parliament as to the financial audit procedures that have applied to the project to date. I understand that the CEP secretariat in Victoria has conducted certain audits of the project through the accounts of Trojan-Owen. However, I am advised that the secretariat has not audited the accounts of Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd and had never even heard of the company Elate Pty Ltd until several days ago. The Corporate Affairs Commission has no recent balance sheets from these companies. It also appears that regular reports have not been presented to the Footscray City Council.

I have recently had a lengthy and constructive meeting with the Footscray Town Clerk, Mr Ward, and the principal of Trojan-Owen, Mr Owen. They told me that, under existing circumstances and arrangements, the project could not be completed even for $10m. The lack of suitably qualified long term unemployed building tradesmen, the attitude of certain of the building unions and the specific guidelines of the CEP program make completion under existing arrangements virtually an impossibility. These gentlemen are extremely concerned about the existing state of affairs, as are the residents of Footscray. I assume that the Footscray City Council is also concerned.

However, I am deeply concerned that, at a meeting of the Council three days ago, a motion was passed without debate delegating to a small group of council officers the power to pay accounts for an unlimited time. I find this decision extraordinary, given the grave circumstances surrounding the whole matter. As all CEP funding for the project now appears to be exhausted, and the pool is very far from complete, there must, firstly, be an urgent examination into past expenditure and the failure to complete as specified in the original estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we know that the money was used for employment generation?

—I will come to that in a second. Secondly, a statement of the Government's refinancing intentions is also essential. It is alarming that of the $2.5m already spent almost $1m has gone on workers compensation, payroll tax, equipment and Trojan-Owen fees and only $1.5m has gone on wages for the CEP participants, despite the very purpose of the scheme being to employ and pay those persons. Only a fraction over 50 per cent has gone in that direction. The people of Footscray and the long term unemployed in the western region of Melbourne and the taxpayers of Australia demand and deserve no less than an urgent and full investigation into this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about some more financial fiddling but on a less grand scale.
—You would be an expert on that. You are an expert at it.
—It relates to the Labor Government and the release today-

—I rise on a point of order. Senator Walsh has clearly breached the Standing Orders. He made an improper reference about an honourable senator. I ask that he withdraw what he just said. He said that Senator Michael Baume would be an expert at financial fiddling. I regard that as a breach of Standing Orders.
—If Senator Walsh made that comment, I ask him to withdraw.
—On the grounds that it is a breach of Standing Orders, I will.
—I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw his remark.
—I withdraw.

—I want to deal with some fiddling of financial books which became evident in the release today by the Australian Statistician of significantly revised balance of payments figures which include not only some quite interesting and quite proper adjustments because of the new basis on which the figures have been collected but also some revisions which put a slightly different light on some of the extraordinary statements made by Government Ministers at the time these earlier figures were released-statements which were aimed deliberately, it now appears, at misleading the financial markets of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer specifically to the November balance of payments figure, which was welcomed by all Government Ministers who had the hide to speak about them, particularly Senator Walsh, who has a curious desire to get involved in muck-raking. Senator Walsh found it within himself, as did many other Ministers at the time, to use the November balance of payments figure, which was a deficit of only $758m on the current account, to try to demonstrate that perhaps these figures did not show in their five-month trend the same serious consequence, the same serious message, that the Opposition was trying to point out. We now discover in the December figures that that $758m was revised upwards to about $800m.

In the figures that came out today we see that there was another $200m left out of the November figures. A document which came out today states that there was a further revision of $200m now revealed due to `an unusual backlog in processing of import entries'. This unusual backlog has taken until February this year to be revealed. It lifts the November figure to about $1 billion. Had that figure been available at the time the Government Ministers, including Senator Walsh, would not have had the opportunity to sound forth about the unreliability of the figures on which we were relying to demonstrate that there was a most unfortunate trend in the balance of payments which was in no way ameliorated by the November figures which are now shown to have been phoney.

Senator Walsh got great pleasure from stressing the significance of those figures which are now shown to be phoney. I do not expect him to apologise to the Senate for that. It is not his style to do so. But I will say that, as a result of these corrections to the figures, we now have a six months balance of payments deficit on current account of about $7.5 billion. This represents a 30 per cent increase revealed in the revised figures over the balance of payments deficit for the same six months of the previous year. Yet when the Opposition called, as it has repeatedly, for the Government to revise its obviously incorrect forecasts, long-standing incorrect forecasts, in its Budget of last August of what the balance of payments deficit would be, we were continually told that it was on track. We were told: `Don't worry about it. We know what we are doing'. I quote from a notice of motion I gave in the Senate on 17 October, which, of course, has not been debated:
That the Senate:
(a) expresses its concern at Australia's worsening balance of payments position evident from the 18 per cent rise in the current account deficit for the September quarter . . .
I repeat that that is now a 30 per cent worsening. The notice of motion also stated:

(b) requests the Treasurer to make available any advice from the Treasury on which he relied for his forecast at an Economic Society meeting yesterday that the current account deficit would fall to 4 per cent of GDP by June next year and then continue to trend downwards;

Since then, as a result of continual pressure from this side, and of course the requirements of the market, the Government has reluctantly admitted, having been dragged screaming to do so, that maybe its target should be extended and that instead of being $10.75 billion it should be about $11.25 billion. There is no chance whatsoever of the $11.25 billion being reached in this financial year and the Government must face up to this reality. It must face up to the fact that, to achieve only $11.25 billion, it will have to cut the average monthly current account deficit to about $0.5 billion and yet the average for the six months so far of this year has been something like $1.2 billion. The Government will have to have an enormous reduction in the rate of deficit per month and there is no chance of that. All I am asking of the Government is that it do what it failed to do last year-to come clean with the Senate, to come clean with the financial markets, about the real forecast of the current account deficit for this year. In the Australian this morning there is a leaked story about advice by an advisory committee to the Government that in fact the deficit for the financial year will be at least $12 billion and probably more.

This Government has deceived the markets and deceived the Senate on this issue for too long. It is about time it came clean. If it has advice that the deficit will be at least $12 billion instead of its target of $10.7 billion it should be honest about it and say so. If in fact the figure is to be far worse, in the Government's judgment, than $12 billion let us hear about it. But let us no longer hear the sort of false information on the current account deficit that Senator Walsh and his colleagues have been giving to the Senate and to the people of Australia. It is long past the time, in view of the seriousness of the current account deficit, that the Senate should be snowed by people such as Senator Walsh on this vital issue.

No doubt this is all part of a scheme, judging by comments in newspapers recently, for the Government to have an early election-another early election. There are such suggestions by Maximilian Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald this week. There is no doubt that all the economic figures we are seeing are all clear and deliberate attempts to delay, to defer, the reality of what is happening in these areas. Clearly, it seems to be part of a scheme of putting it off until later, hoping that things will not get too bad until after the Government has been able to have another immoral early election. Of course, this may be why the Government was reported in a recent Victorian newspaper as having faced Senator Siddons of the Australian Democrats with the threat of going to the polls. A report in the Age of 4 February says of Senator Siddons:

He told an Australian Small Business Association lunch that his party had supported the Government's tax package, which included capital gains tax on small businesses, because Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have threatened to go to the polls.
The article quotes Senator Siddons as saying:
`When we were negotiating with the Government we could only push them so far,' . . . `Hawke and Keating repeatedly threatened to go to the people.'

Apart from the quaint naivety of Senator Siddons in somehow thinking that that would be a terrible thing for the Australian Democrats when, in fact, obviously a double dissolution is the only possible way that, for example, he and presumably most of his colleagues can survive in politics, if Senator Siddons was accurately reporting those conversations and Mr Hawke and Mr Keating had in fact continually threatened in those negotiations to go to the polls, it is a clear warning that this Government will persist with the sort of devious activity which it has carried on in matters such as the current account deficit. It appears certain that the Government will continue that kind of activity. We should be aware of that. Nonetheless, I mention that it is rather quaint that Senator Siddons should have suggested that he was pressed by this threat of a double dissolution to accept what is in fact an intolerable piece of legislation which seriously effects the wellbeing of so many Australians. To that extent I must say that I consider Senator Siddons's comments to be bunk. If he is accurate on the matter concerning the threat of a double dissolution I can only assume that the Government needs one and Australia should be preparing itself for the sort of nonsense and rationalising that will go on when the Hawke Government finds another excuse to have an early election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite mind-boggling that an ex-Patrick Partner could have the audacity to say that anybody should come clean. As for an early election, the only person around here who wants an early election is Senator Michael Baume's friend Mr Howard in order to preserve his tottering leadership of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Short's comments I do have a page of notes supplied by Mr Willis which covers much of the ground over which Senator Short has gone but it does not cover all the items with which he dealt. I will seek a response from Mr Willis on the new matters raised. I can report from this note that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has had recent discussions with parties involved with a view to identifying and resolving the difficulties with the project, and also that the Footscray City Council was the approved sponsor and signed the funding agreement on 10 August 1984. The Council proposed that Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd manage the project and this was approved on the condition that the fee for Trojan Owen be met from the sponsor contribution-the sponsor, of course, being the Footscray City Council. On advice from the State Industrial Relations Task Force the State Ministry of Employment and Training requested that an independent company be established to act as the construction company in order to overcome union demarcation problems between the Municipal Employees Union and building and construction unions. To comply with that request the Council purchased the shelf company Elate to which Senator Short referred. The Council appointed directors and changed the name to Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.03 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telecom Australia: Services in Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Communications enquire into the service provided by Telecom in the Australian Capital Territory, particularly the inadequate number of staff provided for any of the services associated with reminder calls, telegrams, directory assistance or difficulties and faults.
(2) Will the Minister enquire into the lack of adequate lines to lodge STD calls interstate as soon as off peak tariffs apply.

(3) Could the Minister instruct that more staff be recruited to assist those men and women presently on staff who perform their arduous and overworked functions in a most cheerful and efficient manner in view of the enormous profits which Telecom makes each year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom is aware that the heavy demand for some operator assisted services in the ACT has had an adverse effect on the level of the service.
Whilst the staff provided is usually adequate to maintain a satisfactory service some difficulties have been encountered due to absences on sick leave.
Measures have been taken to increase recruitment and it is expected that there should be a marked and sustained improvement in the existing service in the coming months.

(2) The telecommunications network is designed to handle expected telephone traffic during normal business hours and is planned in such a way that it enables telephone calls to be generally connected at the first attempt. However, when concessions are offered on STD calls in off-peak periods both increased traffic and a slight increase in calls failing due to congestion are expected. Regular monitoring of the network is carried out to ensure that calls lost due to congestion or switching malfunctions are within acceptable limits. Where performance is not within limits corrective action is initiated to restore it to normal.

To overcome the problem in Canberra an urgent programme has been implemented to increase trunk circuits. Major relief to the congestion problems was achieved during December and work on this problem is expected to be completed by March 1986.
(3) See (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 13 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the decision taken to hand over the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Schools Authority media services film and sound recording studio to Film Australia.
(2) What was the reason for the decision.
(3) What alternatives were considered.
(4) What notice of the decision was given to the teachers who will be affected.
(5) What agreement has been made with Film Australia to service the needs of ACT Schools.
(6) What was the cost of operating the studio in 1984-85.
(7) What are the contractual arrangements made with Film Australia for the service to be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following response has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The audio-visual studios of the ACT Schools Authority at the O'Connell Education Centre will not be handed over to Film Australia. Ownership and control of the studios will remain with the Authority but Film Australia will use those facilities in servicing Commonwealth agencies and in return will provide audio-visual material for the Authority. The decision was taken to enter into such an arrangement as part of a restructuring of the Authority's production capacity which began in July and is continuing.

(2) The reason for the decision was to maximise the use of the facilities. The ACT Schools Authority will have access to professional film-makers for an agreed amount of time and Film Australia will establish a low-cost production capacity in Canberra for the first time.
(3) The following alternatives were considered:
(a) Closing the studios and putting all work out to contractors
(b) Employing contractors on an ad hoc basis as the need arose
(c) Having a private company run the studios commercially and the Authority use that company to produce its materials.
(d) An arrangement with Film Australia under which that organisation would produce material for the Authority in return for the use of the studios for other Government work.
(4) No teachers will be affected by this decision.

(5) A memorandum of understanding outlining arrangements has been exchanged by the two authorities. It has been agreed in principle that Film Australia will provide the technical staff to produce what is specified by the Authority. The arrangement is to be reviewed after 12 months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government have any plans at all to upgrade the Bureau facilities through the adoption of new technology, the expansion of the automatic weather station network, the more effective use of satellite data and other means in view of the comments made by the head of the Bureau of Meteorology that the system of fire, flood and cyclone warning was in need of substantial improvement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes.

Submissions are being prepared to be brought forward in the Budget context, to upgrade the Bureau of Meteorology warning systems for fire, flood and cyclones and to increase capital funding to replace obsolete equipment and introduce new technology.

These submissions will cover funding for measures recommended in the report `Bushfires and the Australian Environment' by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, and in reports of other Inquiries that followed the Ash Wednesday bushfires.
The increased capital funding will cover items such as:
the upgrading of the basic surface observation network by the installation of additional automatic weather stations and deployment of additional drifting buoys;
the installation of specialised mesoscale networks of automatic weather stations for detection and tracking of cold fronts across southern Australia during fire weather season;
the upgrading of satellite data acquisition and processing facilities, including the installation of satellite data reception equipment at Perth and Brisbane;
the improvement of the weather watch radar network by the use of more sophisticated radars, as well as by increasing the number of radars;
the installation of radio-reporting rainfall and river height records in selected river basins.

In 1983 Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) supported a submission by the Bureau for an increase in funding for capital equipment from the depressed level of approx $1m per year at which it had been held during the 1970s. The Government responded by increasing the capital funding to approx $3.5m in both 1984-85 and 1985-86.

ASTEC also supported in principle an increase in the Bureau's annual funding for capital equipment to $6m ($7.2 at June 1985 prices) for 1986-87 and subsequent years. This further increase was to be subject to the success of the implementation of the program over the first 3 years. ASTEC is currently undertaking a review of the implementation of the program.

I am fully aware of the support for upgrading the Bureau warning systems that has come, not only from the Inquiries that followed the Ash Wednesday bushfires, but also from many organisations and community groups particularly in Northern Australia.

I can also assure you that the Government recognises the importance of the Bureau's warning systems for fire, flood, and cyclones and is aware of the need to replace obsolete equipment and to introduce new technology to support these systems. These programs will be given as much support as is practicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What surveys have been undertaken or are planned for an assessment of numbers involved and of environmental damage created by feral animals (including buffalo, pigs, goats, donkeys and cats and rats) in Australia.
(2) Is the damage caused by feral animals always worse at times of abnormal climatic conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Surveys to assess the numbers of feral animals in Australia or the damage caused by them are undertaken by the States who are responsible for the management and control of feral animals. The Commonwealth co-ordinates activity at the national level.

Surveys of the numbers of feral animals are usually subjective being based on opinions and random sightings by landholders, field officers, forestry workers and others. More accurate, quantitative assessments are expensive to carry out because of the difficulty of sighting the animals. For example, species such as rabbits, foxes and cats take cover in burrows, dense vegetation or are nocturnal.

One example of a non quantitative survey is currently underway on a trial basis in a small area in south-eastern N.S.W. The N.S.W. Department of Agriculture is collecting data on feral animal distributions and densities through its computerized feral animal monitoring system known as FERALFIND.

Another in Qld has been published. In 1981/82 the Qld Rural Lands Protection Board undertook an extensive survey of feral animals to produce a booklet entitled Vertebrate Pests of Queensland. A follow-up survey is presently approaching completion.

A more quantitative survey is underway in N.T. The Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory is conducting aerial surveys of feral pigs, horses, buffalo and some camels. The feral pigs are being surveyed as a component of the jointly funded Commonwealth/State Exotic Disease (Feral Animal Control) Preparedness Program.

Few national estimates of the numbers and distribution of feral animals in Australia have been compiled over the years and those that are published are rapidly outdated because feral animal populations fluctuate dramatically. Nevertheless the estimate in 1980 of the number of feral pigs in Australia, between 8-11 million, is generally accepted as being a good indication.

In the future more reliable national figures should be available. As part of its program of upgrading national awareness and control of feral animals, the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry recently wrote to State and Territory vertebrate pest authorities seeking to co-ordinate survey information, subjective as it is. A national computer-based mapping system for feral animals is being established. Information on feral animal distribution and density/abundance will be collated in a standardised form and entered and stored on a system capable of correlating it with other variables such as topography, vegetation, river systems, roads, railway lines and bioclimatic information. It will be used to facilitate the planning of exotic disease control strategies.

With regard to your question concerning surveys of environmental damage, there have been studies by individuals, research organisations and vertebrate pest authorities on a local basis. The results of these studies and the impact of feral animals, however, have also not been assessed nationally.

We do know, nevertheless, that feral animals and vertebrate pests have considerable detrimental impact on agricultural production and the environment through overgrazing and predation on or competition with native animals. Overgrazing, burrowing and wallowing cause erosion and silt up waterholes and creeks.

Apart from damage to crops and to the environment feral animals also have the potential to cause millions of dollars of damage through harbouring and spreading exotic diseases of livestock. For example, cloven-footed animals both domestic and wild and cattle, pigs, sheep and goats (in that order) are affected by the highly infectious virus of foot-and-mouth disease.
If foot and mouth disease were to spread to feral animals such as pigs it would be very difficult to eradicate. Delays would increase the cost of the outbreak.
The Australian Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated in 1980 that if foot-and-mouth was introduced into Australia the cost in direct losses of rural output would be $2500 million in one year.
(2) A simple answer is not possible to the question is the damage caused by feral animals always worse at times of abnormal climatic conditions.

Much of eastern Australia experienced abnormal climatic conditions during late 1985. Although spring was delayed there was subsequent high rainfall and humidity and mild temperatures. This provided good growth conditions for crops, pastures and vegetation which thus favour both native and feral animals and increased birth and survival rates of offspring could therefore be expected. In this situation it is unlikely that feral animals would cause as much damage to crops as they would in a drought because alternative food supplies are available.

Other abnormal conditions such as prolonged droughts, floods and extremely high or low temperatures assist to reduce feral animal numbers. For example, juvenile pigs are particularly susceptible to extremes of climate. They are highly dependent on water and shade and perish when these are not readily available.

Consequently, although the numbers of feral animals increases in good seasons, the damage they cause is not very obvious. When conditions deteriorate their numbers decline but damage to the environment and agriculture is greater.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a written agreement between the Federal Government and the Bundaberg City Council entered into 2 years ago regarding the level of funding to be provided for the maintenance of the Bundaberg Airport.
(2) Since that agreement was first negotiated has there occurred a reduction in the level of funding.
(3) Has concern been expressed that any future written agreements between the Government and local councils could also be revoked.
(4) Will the Minister for Aviation undertake to reconsider the funding for the maintenance of the Bundaberg Airport with a view to restoring it to its originally negotiated level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the agreement specifies that, subject to certain conditions, the Commonwealth will pay to the Council grants of one half the cost incurred by the Council in maintaining the aerodrome.
(2) No actual reduction has occurred. However, in October this year the Council was advised that the level of funding for this financial year was to be reduced.
