QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Science aware of the alarm generated among Tasmanian pilots, and farmers and fishermen by the proposal to withdraw the weather service office from Launceston by April 1986 and from Hobart by January 1989.

(2) Can the Minister assure the Tasmanian public that if these services must be withdrawn that they will continue to receive the same standard of service from the relocated meteorological office which will assume the functions of the 2 Tasmanian stations for the cost of a local phone call.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am aware of the concern at proposals to close the Bureau of Meteorology Weather Service Offices at Launceston and Hobart. As a result of representations received from aviation and community groups, as well as the general public, my colleague the Minister for Aviation and myself referred the matter to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The Committee commenced an Inquiry on 14 December 1985 with the following terms of reference:
To review:
the extent to which airport weather service offices and observing offices have been providing non-aviation services;
whether these non-aviation services should continue to be provided;
the method of providing and funding these services if they are required; and
the extent to which the costs of such services should be recovered and from whom.

Members of the Committee have visited several of the Bureau of Meteorology Weather Service and Observing Offices, and held public hearings. The Committee's visit to Tasmania took place between 4 and 6 February 1986. Submissions have been received from a wide variety of organisations and individuals on both aviation and non-aviation aspects of the services provided by Bureau officers in provincial centres. Although the deadline for submissions has passed I understand that the Committee is still interested to hear from any person or organisation having a keen interest in the matter.

The Government will not make any decisions on the proposals for closure of the Bureau of Meteorology offices until the report of the Committee has been considered. The Minister for Aviation also indicated on 6 January 1986 that the proposed changes would be phased in and there is no intention of changing present arrangements for the provision of meteorological services at Launceston airport within the next 2 years.
(2) No. There will be some change in the standard of service.

I will explain the background. The proposal to close some meteorological offices, including the Weather Service Offices at Launceston and Hobart, was as a result of a request by the Department of Aviation to reduce the cost of meteorological services for Aviation. These offices were established primarily to provide services for aviation and the costs of their operation are met by the Department of Aviation, which in turn recoups part of the cost from the aviation industry.

If the offices are closed it will be on the grounds of expense and cost effectiveness. There would be some decrease in the standard of meteorological service but this would need to be weighed against the savings involved.

In addition to meteorological services for aviation, the Launceston Weather Service Office, in particular, provides for the general community and community interests in northern Tasmania. Representations made to me indicate that these services are highly valued.

Meteorological forecasts, warnings and weather information for all of Tasmania are originated from the Bureau's Regional Forecasting Centre in Hobart and would continue even if one or both of the Weather Service offices were closed.

Closure of the offices would mean the loss of the input of local knowledge and expertise, local `weather watch', and detailed interpretation of forecasts and weather information, as well as a face to face briefing for pilots.

There is no doubt that the standard of service will be perceived to be lower by those organisations and individuals who require a level of detail and interpretation not available for residents in northern Tasmania through an automated telephone service as well as the media. In the event of closure of the two offices there would be no relocation, only a partial redistribution of some functions and cessation of others. Additional workloads would be passed on to other Bureau offices, necessitating a review of organisation and staffing. The Bureau of Meteorology is examining various options to provide the best possible service to the community.

I must reiterate that no decision on closure or alternative arrangements will be made until after consideration of the report of the Inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many programs, pilots, outlines of program concepts and film scripts have been submitted to the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in each of the financial years the Committee has been in existence, and in each year, how many of these submissions have been rejected.
(2) How many have resulted in substantial modifications after initial advice about potential unsuitability.
(3) What proportion of the material either (a) rejected; or (b) substantially modified, happened because the material was not aimed specifically at an under-14 audience.
(4) What have been the other main causes for rejection or substantial modification of material in each year of operation of the Children's Program Committee.

(5) How many of the projects given a Provisional `C' classification during each year in which it has been used, have later been rejected, or have required substantial modification in order to obtain a full `C' classification, and what has been the major problem in each such case.

(6) What has been the average time for arriving at a decision as to whether a film script should have a Provisional `C' classification since the operation of the children's drama quota, and what has been the longest delay.
(7) What has been the average time for dealing with the submitted finished programs, and what has been the longest delay in assessing any such program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice received from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I should add that the information is a result of considerable expenditure of time and resources by Tribunal staff.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (Nov) 1978-1979: 37 submissions, 8 rejected
1979-1980: 230 submissions, 114 rejected (in addition, further information was sought on 3 submissions and 13 were withdrawn)
1980-1981: 167 submissions, 61 rejected (further information sought on 1, 9 were withdrawn)
1981-1982: 124 submissions, 62 rejected (further information sought on 2, 5 withdrawn)
1982-1983: 99 submissions, 28 rejected (further information sought on 2, 3 withdrawn)
1983-1984: 174 submissions, 53 rejected (further information sought on 2, 14 withdrawn)
1984-1985: 84 submissions, 25 rejected (6 were not classified `C' Drama on script although retained Provisional `C' classification), further information sought on 1, 6 withdrawn
1985-23 December 1985: 39 submissions, 5 rejected, 9 awaiting a decision for `C' drama on script, further information sought on 2.
(2) It is not clear how many programs have resulted in substantial modifications after initial advice about potential suitability.

(3) Children's Television Standard (CTS) 2 (a) states that `C' programs should be designed specifically for children older than 5 years and younger than 14 years. This criteria is the major reason (which is in a ratio of 4:3 to the next main reason, Standard CTS 2f) for rejection and/or need for modification.
(4) For each financial year, except 1979/80, 1980/81 and 1981/82, the reasons for rejection in descending order of frequency have been as follows:
1. CTS 2 (a) CTS 2 is designed specifically for children older than 5 years and younger than 14 years;
2. CTS 2 (f) contributes to the social emotional or intellectual developments of children;
3. CTS 2 (g) is appropriate for Australian children not assuming too much of the culture, dialect or environment of some other country;
4. CTS 2 (b) is designed to entertain children; and CTS 2 (e) fulfills some special need of children;
5. CTS 2 (c) is well produced technically and artistically;
6. CTS 2 (d) can be easily understood and appreciated by children;
7. CTS 2 (h) is not outdated in content or in technical or artistic production.
In 1979/80, 1980/81 and 1981/82 the pattern varied with CTS 2 (f) and (g) being the main reasons for rejection above CTS 2 (a).

(5) No completed program granted a Provisional `C' classification at script stage has later been rejected for a full `C' classification, although many projects granted a Provisional `C' have not yet been resubmitted as complete programs for a full `C' classification.

The number of projects that have required substantial modification for full `C' classification is not clear, although some projects required modification for `C' in 1978/79 (1), 1979/80 (1), 1980/81 (3) and 1983/84 (12) in order to meet CTS 2 (a) and in 1982/83 (2) because further information/pilot was required. In 1984/85 6 scripts were rejected either because the Committee considered it could not assess the programs still at script stage with regard to CTS 2 (c) or because modification was needed to meet CTS 2 (a).
(6) The average time for Provisional `C' recommendation and decision has been approximately 4 1/2 weeks. The longest delay of Provision `C' recommendation and decision has been 12 weeks.
(7) The average time for `C' recommendation and decision has been approximately 4 weeks. The longest delay for `C' recommendation and decision has been 16 weeks.

The timing for the recommendation/decision process depends upon when the submission is received in relation to the Committee's meeting schedule. Delays may also occur if the Committee requires further information from the applicant before making its recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 November (Hansard, page 2470), Senator Kilgariff asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is the Minister too embarrassed to inquire into the extent of the financial losses to our beef trade resulting from the Mudginberri Dispute.
(2) When will the Minister be seeking information as to the extent of the losses suffered and when will he advise the Senate.
(3) What action does the Minister intend to take to explore ways of recovering lost sales.
(4) What action will he take to reassure our overseas markets that the Federal Government will not permit such a situation to develop again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Information available to me indicates that overall it appears that there have been no losses to the beef trade. Any figures involving information on individual companies would include contractual information to which I do not have access.
(3) See (2). Also the industry and the AMLC are continuously promoting our meat products overseas.
(4) The honourable senator will be well aware that it is not possible for this or any other Government to reassure overseas buyers that such a situation will not develop again.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 October 1985 (Hansard, page 992), Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of any plans to change the format of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's news and current affairs programming by doing away with local current affairs segments produced as part of evening newscasts in each state.
(2) Does the Minister agree that any such plan would be a backward step by the ABC particularly in more remote States.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 1 November 1985, the ABC announced that ABC television news would be returning to the 7.00 p.m. time slot from Monday, 9 December. From Australia Day, 26 January 1986, a half-hour current affairs program would be broadcast at 7.30 p.m. The news program will be separately compiled and presented in each State seven days a week. ABC program editors and their staff have had detailed discussion on both the working methods and program presenters to be used as well as the manner in which the State-based news services are to be compiled and presented.

The ABC has also stated that its aim is to present to its audience the fullest possible range, within the constraints of its limited resources, of news and current affairs at the local, national and international levels. Although transmissions times have changed, the ABC has advised that there will be no reduction in the local current affairs content.
(2) As there are no plans to do away with local current affairs segments, this question is not applicable.
